PROCTEXT.PARA: FIRST SESSION OF THE THIRTY-SEVENTH PARLIAMENT

PARA.TAB: The Senate, on 30 June 1995, adjourned to 22 August 1995, unless the President fixed an earlier day of meeting.
Pursuant to the resolution of the Senate passed on 30 June 1995, the Senate met on Tuesday, 22 August 1995 at 2.00 p.m.
The PRESIDENT (Senator the Hon. Michael Beahan) took the chair at 2.00 p.m., and read prayers.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to Senator Cook representing the Treasurer. Why after 13 years of Labor administration—13 years with Mr Keating's hands on the economics lever—does Australia have the worst current account deficit in the Western world?

—Once again we have the opposition trying to talk down the Australian economy. This question is aimed at one of the areas of the Australian economy that is not as good as we would like it to be. But, taking the whole of the economy in its context, in this economy we have: strong employment growth; strong overall growth; a continuing low level of inflation; a high level of investment; and a great deal more confidence among Australians, either in business or as consumers, as a consequence of the innate strengths of this economy than we have had for some time. We also have our own forecasts and the forecasts of private sector economists as well pointing to many future years of strong, sustainable economic growth for Australia. Indeed, I think it was Don Stammer in the BRW about two weeks ago who argued that we are looking at a period of unprecedented six years growth on growth in the future.
—Mr President, on a point of order on relevance: the question was why is Australia's current account so bad. Why is it the worst in the Western world? It is a simple question. What is the answer?
—I am answering the question but it has to be put in context, and I am doing that.
—Are you speaking to the point of order?
—No, I am going on to answer the question.
—I was going to make the point on the point of order that it is a bit early for me to judge.

—The answer to this obviously has to be seen in context. The final point about context that I was making is that we have a number of private sector economic forecasters saying that Australia can look forward to, over the next six years, unprecedented, ongoing, sustainable economic growth. That is something for all Australians to celebrate, and it is in that context that one ought to approach the issue of the current account deficit.

PARA.TAB: One of the reasons why the current account figures are poorer than we would like them to be is that Australia went through a long drought and, as a consequence, our earnings from agricultural exports were less than they would ordinarily be. One of the other reasons why our current account is not as good as we would like it to be is that we have had in the private sector a number of international borrowings—borrowings on the foreign markets—to finance growth in industry.

I do not know that the opposition is going to say that that is wrong but, if it is, it had better go off and explain to the Australian business community why they should not finance growth by borrowing internationally. That shows up in the figures as an interest rate on those borrowings.

One of the other reasons why the current account is at its present level is that we have bought capital goods abroad to expand the capacity of the Australian economy. Because of the buoyant economic conditions in Australia, Australian industry has bought capital goods to expand their operations to take advantage of the burgeoning markets in Asia which has created and underpinned our employment growth.

For all those reasons the current account figures are high, but they are by no means alarming. In the budget we will bring down the level of the current account deficit. As well, because of the consistent work we have done on micro-economic reform and the increase in the competitiveness of the Australian economy, we will grow our exports to a higher level.

The final point I make goes back to the structure of the current account. Australians are confident about their economic future; they are buying consumption goods abroad. That shows up in the current account as well and it is one of the reasons why the figures are high. (Time expired)
