TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, Senator Collins. I refer to media reports over the weekend that federal and state ministers of agriculture had endorsed the principles of the national drought policy and agreed to a review of Commonwealth and state responses to the current drought. Can the minister inform the Senate why such a review is needed at this time?

—The reason is that it is almost a year now since the Commonwealth short- and long-term responses to Australia's serious drought crisis were put into place. It is, as a result, timely to review the responses to the drought not only by the Commonwealth but also by the relevant state governments to assist farmers.

PARA.TAB: The review is designed to ensure, cooperatively, that our policies are both effective and appropriate. My state colleagues had no hesitation at a meeting of ARMCANZ in Perth last Friday in endorsing the Commonwealth's proposals for a review in line with the principles laid down in the national drought policy. I might add that my colleagues agreed to that, with the exception of the Victorian minister who was busy attending a National Party conference in Darwin. Therefore, Victoria was not represented at the conference in Perth at all. Despite having more to say about it than anyone else, the minister was not there.

The state ministers also had no hesitation in re-endorsing the principles of the national drought policy and the framework for declaring and revoking exceptional circumstances. None of the states expressed any desire to go back to the old days when drought was declared under the natural disaster arrangements and Commonwealth fodder subsidies were the go. The reason I mention that is that that is the only proposal for dealing with drought that has so far been suggested by the coalition—which also released that proposal a year ago next week.

The Commonwealth will not have a bar of it, the states will not have a bar of it, and neither will the peak farming organisations. I do not think I can say it any better than the headline that was in The Land, one of the major rural newspapers, last week which said, `Farm leaders back drought policy'. The reason is simple: no-one except the federal opposition seriously advocates revisiting those natural disaster arrangements where assistance was granted to producers—that is, people who gained their income from stock, not from crops—regardless of need or of their current or long-term financial status. Even John Anderson conceded publicly that those fodder subsidies had been `rorted to the back teeth'. No-one wants to revisit a policy that totally distorts the marketplace through fodder subsidies except the federal opposition. It is a discard from the 1980s.

The national drought policy has the support of the Commonwealth and all state governments because it is the correct policy for the 1990s. The review is another step in the continuing evolution of this policy by the Commonwealth in cooperation with the states, which administer it on our behalf. It will allow us to finetune our collective responses to the drought.

The Commonwealth commitment to farm families in the face of this drought has been the most comprehensive ever delivered by any federal government. It enjoys the endorsement of all the key players because they know it is so. Over 10,000 farm families have received the drought relief payment and associated allowances since its inception. In fact, the Queensland minister at ARMCANZ said last week—and I think it was very accurately said—that, if it had not been for this package, rural Queensland would now be on its knees.

The Commonwealth is fully committed to helping rural Australia cope with and recover from the drought. Unfortunately, because of the continuing nature of the drought in regional New South Wales and Queensland and the beneficial statutory requirement that we provided to extend drought assistance by a full six months after revocation, I have no doubt that the full amount of $600 million that has been committed by the Commonwealth will have to be spent.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: Minister for Human Services and Health

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to Senator Gareth Evans as Leader of the Government in the Senate. When your government agreed to fund a private legal action by Dr Lawrence to try to scuttle the Easton royal commission, was the government aware that Dr Lawrence, in her own right, may not have had sufficient standing to initiate that action herself and that it would be necessary to join another party to the proceedings such as Mr John Halden? Was the government also aware that Mr Halden was unable to fund such an action? Why did the government even entertain using taxpayers' funds for a challenge by Dr Lawrence when, in her own right, she may not have had standing to initiate such a challenge? Why didn't the government at the time take steps to ensure that Mr Halden would not be able to piggyback on Dr Lawrence's legal assistance at taxpayers' expense?

—There is no problem whatsoever about either the legality or the propriety of the Commonwealth picking up Dr Lawrence's legal costs in relation to her responses to the Western Australian royal commission, either in terms of the proceedings immediately before the commission or in any collateral action, in the event that it should become necessary for the Commonwealth to do that. There would, of course, be a problem about the Commonwealth picking up the tab for Mr Halden's costs in relation to that action. But, contrary to speculation or misleading reports, the truth is very different from that. The Commonwealth made it very clear from the outset that it was not going, under any circumstances, to bear the cost referrable to any other party that might be involved in the challenge to the royal commission or, in any other way, involved in the proceedings.

PARA.TAB: No payments will be made unless they are certified as fair and reasonable by the Australian Government Solicitor. The Australian Government Solicitor wrote to Mr Halden's solicitors as early as 19 July asking that all expenses in relation to their representation of Mr Halden which do not relate to Dr Lawrence be separately itemised in order to ensure that they can be completely quarantined from anything the Commonwealth separately pays for. All bills submitted by Dr Lawrence's solicitors will be carefully scrutinised to ensure that the government is under no circumstances meeting Mr Halden's legal expenses. It is up to the legal firms themselves and the barristers what arrangements they choose to accept so far as any remuneration they might receive for Mr Halden's expenses.

Might I say that it is a bit of a cheek, a bit of a hide, for the opposition to be raising questions about anybody's costs in this particular matter when we have involved in this matter a really unprecedented exercise of governmental authority by the Western Australian parliament setting in train a royal commission in circumstances which do not amount to an inquiry into criminal behaviour of any kind; do not even amount to an inquiry into the causes of a woman's suicide; do not amount to an inquiry into financial impropriety, criminal or otherwise, or misuse of public funds or misuse of public office for private gain; do not amount to an inquiry into national security; do not amount to an inquiry into maladministration or a failure of public administration; and do not amount to an inquiry into a particular public policy issue—all of which have been the sole grounds for royal commission inquiries in the past.

What we have is an unprecedented and quite extraordinary political exercise designed for one purpose only—to try to bring down a political opponent and distract attention from political problems that are being experienced in the west. It is an inquiry, moreover, which is clearly going to cost Western Australian taxpayers, and maybe even Commonwealth taxpayers when you contemplate that Western Australia receives $1 1/2 billion each year of general revenue funding from the Commonwealth, something over $1 million, $2 million, $3 million—who knows—depending on the circumstances of it.

How can the opposition possibly justify an inquiry costing taxpayers that order of magnitude of money? How can you possibly justify it in Western Australia, coming as it does in the immediate aftermath of the ill-fated and equally extraordinary and equally ill-motivated inquiry and litigation into the Native Title Act which cost taxpayers something like $3 million?

The Commonwealth is absolutely entitled to support Dr Lawrence in the exercise of the carrying out of her functions as a minister in defending herself against a challenge to her fitness to hold public office and, in particular, to carry out her functions as a minister. It is absolutely entitled to do that. That is the nature of the challenge against her. Moreover, she is defending the institutions of which she is a part. She is defending the institution of parliamentary privilege. She is defending the institution of cabinet confidentiality, which is manifestly under threat and in which the Commonwealth has a major interest. There is a very clear legal authority for the particular payment the Commonwealth is making in this respect and we have no doubt whatsoever about the legitimacy and the propriety and the morality of the course we have taken. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Before I call Senator Vanstone, I point out that there have been far too many interjections on my left and on my right.

—On a supplementary question: putting aside, Minister, your complete failure to understand that the commission really is an inquiry into the need for honesty of executive governments and that the Western Australian people are entitled to know whether their ministers have ever lied to them—and that goes to the heart of the parliamentary system and I think it is worth having a royal commission on that—I nonetheless ask you whether Roger Gyles QC is appearing for both Dr Lawrence and Mr Halden? If so, what contribution is Mr Halden making to Mr Gyles's appearance fees? You covered the question of solicitors, but not Mr Gyles. Why was a Sydney based law firm used to run a Western Australian based challenge? Did it have anything to do with the fact that former Senator Stephen `let me at the money' Loosley is a consultant to that firm? What involvement did the government and Stephen Loosley have in the appointment of Dunhill Madden Butler? Is the government yet again helping a string of mates at taxpayers' expense?

—This royal commission in Western Australia is nothing more or less than a disgraceful political rack. It would not have been set in train had Carmen Lawrence not been a minister in this particular government.

—A point of order: you cannot allow ministers to keep coming forward with irrelevant answers. This commission has not been called because she is a federal minister. It has been called because she was a minister there and there is a suspicion that she lied. That is what it is all about.
—Order! There is no point of order, but I ask you, Minister, to get to the point of the answer.

—I will finish that point which was stimulated by the opening of Senator Vanstone's supplementary by saying to her that in answer to a question on 4BC radio yesterday from Julie Flynn to the effect that if she was just an ordinary member of the community there would be no royal commission, Senator Vanstone said, `Well that may be.' Of course that is the fact. Of course you know it. The only reason that royal commission has been set in train is not because it is Dr Lawrence citizen, it is because it is Dr Lawrence federal member of this particular government. As to the question of the funding of Mr Halden's legal expenses, the cost of Mr Gyles or anybody else, that is a matter between Mr Halden, his solicitors and his counsel. It is of no interest to the Commonwealth and we have made that clear in correspondence which was on the record as early as 19 July.

—My question is directed to the Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Multicultural Affairs. Yesterday the minister announced that the federal government would fund a training project by the Australian Institute of Judicial Administration to improve awareness of cross-cultural issues amongst the judiciary. What is the government doing to ensure cross-cultural awareness in the field of education so that Australian law students begin their careers with a thorough understanding of those issues?

—I take this opportunity to thank Senator Cooney for this particular question. Drawing on his long experience not just of legal matters but also of matters affecting migrant communities and generally migration law as well, and coming from that part of Melbourne where he has his office, he would have a background well steeped in this area.

PARA.TAB: The government is as concerned as you are, Senator Cooney, to address the issue of how to make the legal system fairer and more accessible to all Australians. It has been one of those issues of concern to the government for some time. We realise it has been a particularly pressing issue for clients of non-English speaking background. They would only get a fair go in the legal system—

TALK.START.PARA: —Follow the Carmen Lawrence principle.

—They obviously would not get a fair go if Senator Kemp had any say in it. They will only get a fair go if the legal system understands and is sensitive both to their cultural and religious backgrounds and to how language often acts as a significant barrier to justice from their first visit to the solicitors office to finally the court.

PARA.TAB: There are a number of levels on which governments can and should respond to this particular issue. As you point out, Senator Cooney, the Deputy President of the Australian Institute of Judicial Administration, the Hon. Justice Buckley, and I announced yesterday that the government will support a major cross-cultural training program for the judiciary. We will fund the program with some $350,000 under the three-year community relations agenda, which is administered by the Office of Multicultural Affairs.

The institute will develop the program in cooperation with OMA, conducting research and holding extensive consultations within both the judiciary and ethnic communities across the country. In a pilot program, a three-day workshop will be held at a particular court of jurisdiction and a resource package will then be developed and made available to other interested courts.

Your question also goes to the issue of educating Australian law students and having them begin their careers with a thorough understanding of the issues in this area. I am pleased to inform both you and the Senate that the government is not only working with the judiciary but also concerned about taking a comprehensive approach to the education of law students and is therefore encouraging law schools to develop cross-cultural training in their curricula.

My colleague the Minister for Employment, Education and Training, Simon Crean, and I are announcing today funding for five high quality research programs at Australian universities. The projects will total $257,000 in costs and will be funded from the national priority reserve fund for this year. The universities involved will be Griffith University, Southern Cross University, Australian National University, La Trobe University, University of Melbourne, University of Western Sydney and University of Wollongong. I congratulate and commend all those universities for putting up proposals which reflected a high standard, diverse, flexible and highly practical approach ranging from flexible training and skills modules to the production of trigger videos.

Senator Cooney quite rightly raises an issue which is of concern to a large number of people out in the community. This issue goes very much to cultural awareness in the judiciary and in law schools and the legal profession. It is an issue which quite often can affect the rights of citizens in our community. It is one the government is addressing through these two measures at this particular moment.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: Minister for Human Services and Health

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to Senator Bolkus in his capacity as representing the Attorney-General. I refer to the existing guidelines for the provision of assistance to Commonwealth government ministers in relation to the defence of legal proceedings, which state that the guidelines apply `where a minister becomes involved as a defendant in litigation arising out of the performance of his or her ministerial duties'. I ask the minister: since the litigation did not arise out of the performance of her ministerial duties, will he explain to the Senate why the Attorney-General has claimed and used his discretion to act contrary to these guidelines in supplying legal costs to Dr Lawrence? Will the Attorney-General release cabinet documents supporting his decision?

—There needs to be a couple of points placed on the record in respect of this: One is, of course, going to the inquiry we are talking about, the need to recognise it was initiated by those who are attacking the fitness of a particular person to be a minister of the Commonwealth. I must say to you, Senator Spindler, that in circumstances such as this, historically, aid has been provided; but it is first provided by the government which initiates the inquiry.

PARA.TAB: It is very much up to the Western Australian government to provide assistance in this case. I suppose, from the federal government's position, it is very important to place on record that we are still awaiting a response from the WA government in respect of this particular matter. We have taken no decision to fund proceedings in this matter, but we are waiting for the government which historically has the responsibility to provide funding—responsibility based on notions of fairness. Certainly, that responsibility and those notions are well established in instances such as this. I think we should, in the first instance, place our focus on the WA government. If the WA government does not eventually decide to assist, then the Commonwealth government will not allow a minister of the Commonwealth to financially destroy themselves and place themselves particularly in such sordid situations. We will have no option but to step in if WA persists in abdicating responsibility here.

In terms of your reference to the guidelines, Senator, I think it is important for you to look at the guidelines, to look at them as they are formulated and to look at some of their history. It is consistent with precedent of the Commonwealth paying legal costs of ministers obliged to defend themselves by reason of their ministerial function. Not only is there Commonwealth precedent, there is also precedent at the state level for this matter. There were no guidelines, for instance, until 1984. When guidelines were introduced, those guidelines were intended to cover proceedings in which a minister was a defendant.

If you look at the title of the guidelines, they are `Guidelines for the Provision of Assistance' for certain people `in Relation to the Defence of Legal Proceedings'. If you look at the actual guidelines, they list the sorts of proceedings we are talking about, both civil and criminal proceedings. They go very much to situations where ministers and parliamentary secretaries find themselves in defence of proceedings, not in respect of royal commissions. There were no guidelines intended to cover royal commissions in 1984, nor were there guidelines in place before 1984 when the government put these guidelines in place for these particular circumstances.

In terms of what happens in the absence of guidelines, what happens now is what has always happened. For the last 50 years or so, in circumstances where a minister has had to defend his or her fitness before a royal commission, governments have assisted them—Commonwealth governments, and there are instances there, and state governments. Two great examples in recent days of state governments acting to provide legal assistance for members of those governments were both the Fahey government in respect of Nick Greiner just a few years ago and the recent Tasmanian government in respect of Robin Gray. Assistance was provided for those members not only to appear before the commission but also to contest the ambit of the commission.

We have taken this decision. We have done it consistent with subsections 4(a) and (b) of the Parliamentary Entitlements Act. As Senator Gareth Evans said earlier on in question time, there is legal entitlement to do it, there is precedent to do it, and there is precedent from both sides of parliament to do it—precedent going back some 50 years or so. As well as those that I have mentioned, there are also important legal issues that have arisen in this inquiry and that are always going to arise. There is parliamentary privilege and, as we saw just a few days ago, the whole question of cabinet confidentiality—cabinet confidentiality which is quite critical to the running of government on both a state and federal level. There are issues that are not just dormant and relevant in Western Australia but also relevant on a federal level and nationally.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, on a point of order: I ask the minister to table the guidelines to which he referred. At the end of his answer, I believe I have the ability to raise a point of order and to ask the minister to table the document.
—It is not a point of order. You can ask him to table the document. It is up to him whether he does it or not.

—There are two points that arise out of the minister's answer. Firstly, has a decision been made or not? For a while he sounded as though it was conditional on the WA government providing funds. So has a decision been made or not? Secondly, the phrase in the guidelines that is the key phrase is `performance of his or her ministerial duties'. To the extent that that has been disregarded—
—Like Greiner in ICAC and Gray in Rouse.
—Robin Gray was a crook.
—can the minister refer me to where the guidelines provide for—
—Order! There are too many interjections on both sides. Senator Spindler has the floor, and he has the right to be heard.
—Mr President, on a point of order: you would have heard the interjection from Senator Sherry referring to Robin Gray's character. I ask you to ask him to withdraw.
—If that is what you said, Senator, I suggest you withdraw it.
—I withdraw the interjection.
—Can the minister refer me to the point in the guidelines which gives the Attorney-General the discretion to depart from the clear formulation of the guidelines?

—In terms of a decision, I think I made it very clear that we are still awaiting a decision from the Western Australian government. The matter is coming up. Ms Lawrence is appearing on 13 and 14 September. It is getting very close but we anticipate a reply before then. Historically, precedent and fairness dictate that they should reply, and reply positively. But we will not allow a minister of the Crown, in defending his or her reputation, to go without assistance if the Western Australian government does not live up to its responsibilities.

PARA.TAB: In terms of the guidelines mentioned in the second part of your question, I suppose it is best to say that we have made a contingent decision with respect to that. With respect to the guidelines, as I have said to you, Senator—and you had better go back to my first answer because I do not have enough time to give you a comprehensive one now—the guidelines when we look at them go very much to a minister defending himself or herself against civil or criminal proceedings. They go only to cases where a person is a defendant. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —On a point of order—
—I will table the guidelines.

—My question is directed to the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories. I am aware that the Australian government recently signed an agreement with the International Olympic Committee and the Sydney Olympic Games Organising Committee to pursue a drug free Sydney 2000 Olympics. Can the minister please explain the significance of this agreement and tell the Senate how this fits within the government's broader strategy to combat drugs in sport?

—I appreciate the question from Senator Childs. On 13 July I did sign, on behalf of the government, an historic anti-doping agreement with the International Olympic Committee and SOCOG, the Sydney Organising Committee for the Olympic Games. This agreement commits all parties to actively pursue a drug free Sydney 2000 Olympiad. No previous agreement has ever formalised the intentions of the IOC, the host national government and the organising committee in this way. Sydney 2000 must not be contaminated by cheats using drugs. I will be doing everything possible, as I have been already, to beat the cheats.

PARA.TAB: As sports minister, I am determined that this government will do everything it can to ensure that the games will be a sporting and financial success. A drug free Sydney 2000 does have the potential to re-establish the credibility of international sport and provide a launching pad to take a drug free sporting ethos into the 21st century. The signing of the agreement follows a cabinet decision to implement a wide range of measures aimed at pursuing a drug free 2000 Games. These measures include the implementation of an effective drug testing program that targets international athletes competing and training in Australia, the implementation of effective drug testing programs at the 2000 Olympics and the test events leading up to the games, and the maintenance of an internationally accredited drug testing laboratory in Sydney.

Other measures include the implementation of education programs throughout the school and sporting communities, the reduction in the prescribing of performance enhancing drugs for non-medical reasons and the implementation of effective out of competition drug testing programs by international sports federations that target top athletes around the world.

At the time of the signing of the anti-doping agreement, I also met with the presidents of the international sports of swimming, cycling and rowing. The three sports indicated their strong support for our anti-doping goals. I am very pleased to note that they are already moving on appropriate drug testing programs. The comprehensive package of anti-doping measures, together with the signing of the tripartite agreement, sends the clearest and strongest possible signals to Australia's top athletes and the international sporting community.

The success of Sydney in winning the right to host the 2000 Games has provided us with a unique opportunity to further the fight against doping. We are recognised throughout the world as the leader in the fight against drugs in sport. With the spotlight on Sydney, we are well placed to demonstrate the effectiveness of our domestic anti-doping programs and, in so doing, advocate to the international sports community the need for a similar stringent and effective effort.

I should make one thing very clear: when I talk about Australia's sporting success, I am talking about the pursuit of excellence, not about a win at all costs attitude. This government is not about pursuing medals for the sake of it. We will not support cheating in any form in order to stand on the dais. The Australian government and community expect us to ensure that Australia fulfils these obligations. (Time expired)

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: Minister for Human Services and Health

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Attorney-General. What steps were taken to protect taxpayers' funds when cabinet agreed to fund Dr Lawrence's private legal action to scuttle the Easton royal commission? Were any limits placed on the nature and extent of her legal costs, or does she have a blank cheque to launch as many challenges as she likes, employing the most expensive silks money can buy? What on earth has any obligation to `defend herself by reason of her ministerial function' got to do with taking pre-emptive restraining action in respect of her behaviour when she was clearly not a federal minister?

—This case has been highlighted by the opposition's utmost hypocrisy. Senator Alston asked the question while claiming that this has nothing to do with Dr Lawrence's position of being a federal minister. Senator Vanstone was on radio yesterday publicly stating very loudly that there would not have been a royal commission if Carmen Lawrence had not been a federal minister. `Well that may be', she said. She let the cat out of the bag. They go public, claiming that the person is not fit to hold office. Senator Alston then has the gall to come in here and argue that it has nothing to do with her job as a Commonwealth minister.

PARA.TAB: The reality is that Carmen Lawrence has to defend herself as a Commonwealth minister of the Crown. In doing so, some fairly important principles of law and institutions relating to her position not only as a minister but also as a member of parliament are involved here. There are fundamental principles going to parliamentary privilege and cabinet confidentiality. That is why the federal government is concerned to involve itself in this matter.

Let us not have hypocrisy. Let us acknowledge that this goes very much to the continued operation of a federal minister of the Crown. Let us acknowledge that, outside this place, more often than not that is what the other side claims. That is what they also claim in here. So there is footing and, as I said, there is precedent on the state and federal levels for governments to be involved in funding in this way. There is legal authority to do so. In pursuance of that legal authority, we have decided to do so.

In terms of the first part of the question, we have in here an established practice. If payments have been made and a decision is taken—a contingent decision having been taken—those payments will be in accordance with a longstanding established practice that no payment will be made unless it has been certified by the Australian Government Solicitor as fair and reasonable, having regard to reasonable commercial practice. There is also an imperative on the solicitor to look at the relevance of the expenditure in terms of its merit.

We have not made any payments so far. But there will be proper scrutiny and overview by the Commonwealth's own solicitors. That sort of overview from very experienced people will be put in place here. With authority and due care, the expenditure will be in accordance with those principles of relevance, will be fair and reasonable in terms of its limit and will be reasonable in accordance with commercial practice. That is what we are talking about.

In giving that full answer, it would really do the public debate in this place a lot of good if those on that side did not show the shamefaced hypocrisy that they are showing on this matter. They should acknowledge, as Senator Vanstone did yesterday when she let the cat out of the bag, that this goes very much to Carmen Lawrence being a federal minister. There would not have been a royal commission, as she said yesterday—

TALK.START.PARA: —On a point of order: I would take your advice, Mr President, as to whether you want me to wait until he has finished or whether I should do it on a point of order now.
—If it is a personal explanation, there is a proper time to do that.
—You are entitled to take a point of order.
—Why don't you be quiet; I am taking some advice.
—Order! If it is a personal explanation, this is not the proper time to do it. The proper time to do it is after question time.
—Okay, I will do it then.

—Let me put it clearly on the record. When Flynn put to Senator Vanstone on 4BC yesterday, `If she was just an ordinary member of the community there would be no royal commission,' Senator Vanstone said, `Well that may be.' You cannot have it both ways. What we are doing here is consistent with precedent and in accordance with fairness. If you are concerned about the taxpayers here, why don't you get Noel Crichton-Browne to ring his mate Richard Court to call the whole thing off? That will save the taxpayers a bit of money.

—Can I be quite clear on this: is the minister saying that Carmen Lawrence has an open-ended entitlement to take as many actions as she likes in every jurisdiction that she thinks is reasonable and to incur unlimited legal expenses as long as one of your flunkeys at some later point in time says it is all fair and reasonable? Is that the extent of the limitation that you have placed on her legal bills to protect taxpayers' funds?

—The answer is no, you cannot take that, Senator Alston. But can I say to you that calling the Australian Government Solicitor a `flunkey' is a reflection on you and on the way that your side have been pursuing this matter. Maybe the media ought to just pause and reflect on the disinformation and on the public attacks on reputation you have been involved in. You cannot call an independent senior officer of the Crown a `flunkey'. You ought to be made to withdraw in shame over it.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs. I refer to the bill currently before the Papua New Guinea parliament which, while providing for some level of compensation for the environmental damage caused by the BHP mining operations on the Ok Tedi River, prohibits further legal action for compensation and also prohibits any challenge to the validity of these laws. I ask: first, has the federal government had any contact with BHP over its agreement with the Papua New Guinea government and the subsequent legislation; secondly, what did the minister mean when he stated that some of the measures in the legislation were `a bit unusual'; and, thirdly, has the government considered prohibiting Australian companies from being involved in such gross abuses of the environment and human rights as are taking place at Ok Tedi and, if not, why not?

—I am not aware of any contact between the Australian government and BHP in recent times about either the compensation settlement or the terms of the legislation. I am not saying there has not been any; I am certainly not aware of it. I know there have been a lot of attempts by Slater and Gordon to make contact with the government, but I am not aware of any in relation to BHP. It has been regarded, by and large, by the government as a matter to be resolved between BHP, the Papua New Guinea government and its own citizens, the Papua New Guinea government being a mature, independent and responsible nation state perfectly capable of determining its own future in these particular matters.

PARA.TAB: We do have an interest, of course, in relation to possible environmental pollution of Australian waters from the Ok Tedi exercise. That has been the subject of many hours of discussion over the years between the governments with BHP. With monitoring programs being put in place and so on, there has been no cause for alarm so far as we are concerned.

What did I mean when I referred to some aspects of the legislation being unusual? I was referring to reports at that stage that not only was there an exclusion of double-dipping in the sense that there was a proposed legislative requirement, as I understood it, that people were not to be able to sue; there were also some fairly extraordinary provisions referred to in the press reports suggesting that there be criminal penalties attached to anyone who did have the effrontery to issue a writ or initiate proceedings. They were certainly unusual provisions.

The difficulty, however, for those who want to get excited about that is that we are advised by the Papua New Guinea government that there is no intention to proceed with those; that was just an early draft that Slater and Gordon somehow got hold of. It was an idea that was thought by Papua New Guinea's own advisers not to have much to commend it—a judgment which I in turn commend—and they have not proceeded with it.

But what is involved here is an exercise of legislative exclusion of a compensation payout which would otherwise be damaging to the Papua New Guinea economy in the judgment of the Papua New Guinea government. They have made the judgment that the compensation package is sufficiently large to be fair for the landowners concerned and that there is no particular justification for allowing a foreign firm of lawyers to enrich themselves with some sort of contingent fee exercise with the prospect of protracted legislation at the end of the day which, if it were successful, would be very damaging indeed. I am not saying that these are the Australian government's judgments; these are unquestionably, however, the judgments that have been made by the Papua New Guinea government. Essentially, the Australian government's position is that that is a matter for them.

As to the question of whether there should be some kind of code of conduct or restraints on what mining companies do in Papua New Guinea, I note that there has been an application by the Australian Conservation Foundation for a project in Papua New Guinea to draw up such a code. Because that project is highly controversial, extensive consultation has proven necessary with relevant organisations in PNG, including government, community and industry groups. I expect a decision to be made by the government soon on that. There are obviously a lot of questions of principle involved here and one needs to tread pretty warily, again paying very close regard to the responses of the Papua New Guinea government, which is, after all—and I keep saying this—the government which has responsibility for in the first instance its own environment and its own people's welfare.

TALK.START.PARA: —What, Minister, of the federal government's responsibility to ensure that Australian companies abide by the environmental and civil rights provisions outside Australia which we demand of them within Australia?

—There are no present obligations of that kind upon any companies which are the responsibility of any particular minister to enforce. It is an ongoing question as to whether there should be obligations of that kind imposed upon companies dealing overseas. It is an issue that arose, for example, a few years ago in the context of apartheid practices in South Africa by Australian companies there.

PARA.TAB: It is a legitimate question to ask, but it does involve a lot of difficult questions that need to be balanced and, at the end of the day, that is in the first instance a responsibility of the Papua New Guinea government. If they sought some such exercise by the Australian government, that would obviously add a degree of sharpness to our consideration of this. If they do not or if they seek the contrary because they are worried about the implications for other investment and so on, that is something we would have to take seriously into account in contemplating the worth or otherwise of such a policy exercise.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: Minister for Human Services and Health

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Human Services and Health, Senator Crowley. Given that Carmen Lawrence's legal defence will cost the Australian taxpayer at least $10,000 per day, could the minister confirm that, if those tax dollars were applied to reduce the long waiting lists in Australia's public hospitals, they would buy on each day four total hip replacements or one kidney transplant or 20 hernia repair operations or 10 cataract operations or 10 gall bladder operations or 10 operations for bowel cancer or almost two heart bypass operations or 10 neonatal intensive care beds? (Time expired)
—I draw your attention, Mr President, to standing order 73 in terms of the rules for questions and, clearly, that question was out of order.

—There are many questions that would be out of order based on a rigid interpretation of any of the standing orders, but I do take your point and I hope that you, Senator Tierney, have taken the point too. I will allow the general thrust of the question in this case, although I must say you did not really get to it.

—The first point that I think needs to be made is that this question is quite out of order. For a start, trying to trawl across a hypothetical amount of what might be the costs in the royal commission is quite out of order. Secondly, the question is quite inappropriately addressed to me. If Senator Tierney wants to talk about whether or not this government is doing anything to reduce waiting lists in hospitals, if that is the point of his question—
—He is asking you what $10,000 a day would buy.

—This is really an outrageous question. The question is what $10,000 buys; the answer is just about anything you care to postulate, Senator. The other important thing is that there is now a figure being bandied about, a figure that we cannot possibly—

PARA.TAB: Honourable senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —This part of the question is quite out of order.
—Order! The minister is entitled to be heard in silence.

—I reiterate that the first part of this question is out of order. It is hypothetical and it is inappropriate to address it to me. If Senator Tierney wants to talk about what we are doing in terms of hospital waiting lists, which is really the important point of the question, this government has done a huge amount to reduce waiting lists. It increased money through the Medicare grants to the states while the states were cutting their funding.

PARA.TAB: We have seen a continuing concern by the very minister that the opposition wants to attack to make sure that the health services of this country are delivered in the very best way. At a time when she has had this terrible distraction, she has been concerned to see that negotiations with the states continue to make sure that special funding and extra funding, particularly in the light of the review of funding from the Commonwealth to the states, might be able to provide even further assistance from the Commonwealth to assist with whatever numbers of procedures surgeons and doctors in various states determine patients might need. The question of what we could buy for X amount of dollars is irrelevant and stupid.

TALK.START.PARA: —Oh!

—It is so open-ended as to be daft, Senator. We are very serious about reducing waiting lists. Minister Lawrence is in the business right now of negotiating further moneys to the states to assist in reducing those waiting lists. Any number of those services are available through the hospital system in this country. Even more will be available as more and more states become efficient, with the extra money provided by the Commonwealth, to do more of those procedures.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Defence, Senator Ray, and continues the Western Australian theme. The minister would be aware of the recent ill-founded and inflammatory comments by the Premier of Western Australia, Richard Court, to the effect that Western Australia has a lower defence priority than the eastern states. Can the minister reassure Western Australians of the government's commitment to the defence of Australia's most important and western third?

—I noticed that on VP Day the Premier of Western Australia took some time off from internal brawling in the Liberal Party and from launching star chambers to actually become a defence expert. On that whole day this was the only tacky exercise run.

PARA.TAB: The allegation by Mr Court is that we do not spend enough on defence in Western Australia, basically that we leave it undefended. I think the first point I should make is that at no stage in defence do we ever allocate resources on the basis of a state—that you can get 20 per cent and that is your percentage. That obviously is what Mr Court wanted. If we did that on a per capita basis, I am sure that Senator Tambling and Senator Bob Collins would be very upset at the massive reduction we would have to make in defence expenditure in the Northern Territory.

I remind Mr Court that Western Australia now is the recipient of a naval base at Stirling at which half the fleet will be based. When this mob opposite left office, they had two patrol boats in Western Australia. Now, under our administration and our guidance, they will have half the fleet, including six submarines.

Obviously Mr Court has never visited 13th Brigade in Western Australia. Obviously he has not visited the SAS at Swanbourne. Obviously he has not visited the air force training school at Pearce. Obviously he does not know about North West Cape; he does not know about the base at Geraldton. He does not know about the two bases at Learmonth and Curtin. Of course, 25 per cent of the expenditure on K95 was in planning and exercising in Western Australia in the last few weeks. Obviously he does not know that 3rd Brigade, the mechanised brigade, is in Darwin to defend the north of Western Australia.

What this was about was a tacky political exercise by Mr Court on VP Day to get some cheap publicity. We will not, and I am sure no federal government will, allocate defence resources to meet the desires of petty parochial politicians.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Defence, Senator Robert Ray. I refer to this letter in the Hobart Mercury from former—
—We can't see it.
—I will table it, if you like.
—Is leave granted to table it?
—Yes.
—Leave is granted.

—The letter is from former federal Labor Senate leader, Ken Wriedt, in response to your comments, Minister, on the Batman preselection when you said that `politics is not about fairness, it's about getting results'. Would you agree with Mr Wriedt that if those elected to parliament cannot put the objective of fairness at the top of their priorities they should not be in parliament? Would you also agree that your attitude will appal the majority of decent Labor Party members and supporters, and that it is just another example of how out of touch and arrogant this Labor ministry has become?

—I am sure neither Mr Wriedt nor Senator Newman listened to the radio interview and heard the context of that remark. It was not and should never be taken as a remark about government policy. What we were talking about when I made that statement was the management of the affairs of a political party. Mr Wriedt has taken it as a general attitude to politics, which it is not. Fairness and equity in government and the treatment of Australian citizens is an absolute principle I endorse.

PARA.TAB: I will give you an example, Mr President, of what I was talking about. I thought, in the context of the Batman preselection, that one candidate quite clearly was better than another—the same as, I am sure, most people would have taken the attitude in the Boothby preselection that it would have been better to have Senator Hill as the candidate but that it was fairer to have the processes he went through. I am sure those opposite would think it was better to have a joint Senate ticket in Queensland, but they cannot get it through because they were absolutely fair about it. They cannot get a joint ticket.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about WA?

—In terms of WA, I am sure they think it is a lot fairer to dump Mr Filing and Mr Rocher and to replace them with nonentities. I am sure that is the attitude they take. My remark was only in the context of internal party affairs, not government policy. Go back and read the transcript of the Aitken interview and you will see that clearly. Once again you have come in here with a fragment of an interview and totally distorted what was said. The difference between the Labor Party and the Liberal Party at the moment is that, even though we go through convoluted procedures, we can manage our own affairs. But you cannot. You have had to strip preselection from three candidates in New South Wales; you have had to chuck out two candidates, two sitting members, in Western Australia, and you cannot even agree on a joint Senate ticket in Queensland. That is how friendly you are with your ugly cousins sitting over there. So you cannot manage your affairs.
—On a point of order—

—I was pointing to Queensland. I was only referring to the Queensland Nationals, Senator. I know you have jumped to your feet to dissociate yourself from the Queensland Nationals, and I will give you an opportunity to do so—
—On a point of order: I suggest the Minister should occasionally look in the mirror at himself.
—I stress again I was referring to the Queensland Nationals, Senator Brownhill; not to yourself.
—On a point of order—
—Speak of the devil!
—Mr President, on a point of order: I am absolutely forced to defend the Queensland Nationals as being non-ugly. Would you ask the minister to withdraw that reflection?
—I did think it was inappropriate language.

—I did refer to Senator Boswell once as pineapple head and I will withdraw that as well. What you have done, Senator Newman, which is typical of your style, is you have taken a quote out of context and then extrapolated it to the whole political spectrum. Today you have been found out on that because you did not listen to the interview, you did not see the context in which the remark was made and you are going through your normal distorting political process.

—Mr President, on a point of order: you have heard enough, surely, to understand by now that Senator Ray knows full well that it is not a matter of Senator Newman interpreting some interview with Doug Aiton. It is a matter of Ken Wreidt, your former Labor leader in the Senate, saying that he thinks it is just not on to say there should not be fairness in the Labor Party. If Senator Ray wants to respond to that allegation by Ken Wreidt let him, but don't allow him the opportunity to criticism Senator Newman.

—Mr President, on the point of order: I was putting the remark in context, as that I'm entitled to, because it was left hanging according to the interpretation—and it is only a misinterpretation by Mr Wriedt because he would only have seen part of a quote in a newspaper or whatever else—
—Order! Are you still on the point of order?
—I'll let you rule on it.
—There is no point of order. Senator Ray, complete your answer.

—As I was saying, Mr President, internal politics is never particularly fair. I have quoted many examples of it in the Liberal Party today. The important thing is the outcome in how successful politicians and political parties have been in this country—and it is essential that they manage their political resources and maximise their efforts. We have done so. You opposite have proved incapable of doing so.
—Mr President, I ask that further questions be placed on the Notice Paper.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tierney Sen J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Senator Bob Collins), to a question without notice asked by Senator Burns this day, relating to the government's drought policy.

SPEECH.PARA: I refer the minister to an article in the Australian last week headed, `Drought approach fails, inquiry finds', which states:
A two-year investigation into the national drought policies has labelled the Federal Government's approach to the nation's 85,000 farmers as "ineffective, misguided and counterproductive".

It goes on to say that the approach is based on false assumptions that farmers can battle long-term drought as part of the farming business environment. The report attacks the government's advice to store feed and to keep cash reserves. It uses tax incentives instead of direct fodder help and uses the exceptional circumstances criteria for drought ravaged farmers applying for assistance. It goes on to conclude, very damningly I think, that the whole focus of the national drought policy—including the assumption that farmers are self-reliant and can become drought proof in cyclical downturns—is misguided.

PARA.TAB: This finally nails the minister's approach to drought. We believe that when he received the response to this report in his office he went off the deep end, because when they set up this inquiry into drought policy he was expecting a pat on the back for the great things this government has done for the farmers over the last several years.

Let me remind the Senate that this drought has been going on now for four years. It was a little over a year ago in about July last year that the government really started to get involved with coming to grips with the drought and to give up its previous policy of hoping it would just rain. They did institute a number of measures, including their extreme drought relief policy, and time after time in the Senate we have condemned the way in which that policy is administered, we have condemned the guidelines in that policy and we have condemned the criteria that is used to select drought areas. If Minister Collins managed to actually go up there and look at what was happening in areas like the Upper Hunter he would see—

TALK.START.PARA: —I've just been there, as a matter of fact.

—You went to the Hunter, Minister, you didn't go to the Upper Hunter. They didn't see you up in Scone, they didn't see you in Merriwa, they didn't see you out in Singleton where the real drought country is.
—I didn't see you in Perth last week; I didn't see you in Kununurra the week before.
—The minister—
—I did not see you in Maitland.

—Didn't you? Well, we heard from you in Maitland, didn't we, minister? The minister got up and explained what he had done under the exceptional circumstances drought relief and the question was asked of the minister, `Well, finally, you have included some of the people in the Upper Hunter after several years. If you allowed them exceptional drought relief money two months ago, why has it taken two months for the money to come through?' The minister was totally surprised by this.
—And it turned out to be wrong, Senator Tierney. We checked that out.
—Yes, the week before, was it? Seven weeks instead of eight weeks, was it?
—Your stupid press statement was a lie.
—The thing is, minister, that the most damning thing is that you did not know. You had given this money out but you did not know whether it was through or not. That was basically the point.
—Because it was wrong.
—When he went to the Hunter Valley the minister could not even be bothered to check whether the money had come through.
—So you are conceding that your statement was rubbish.

—Well, minister, it was seven weeks rather than eight. I do not think it makes a great deal of difference to people who have been waiting years for any sort of assistance from your government. This report from the University of New England—an academic, independent report into this government's drought policy—proves comprehensively that the policy has failed. I challenge the minister to table the report and release it—
—Happy to.

—Thank you very much. There is a rumour going around that you are going to release it in two or three months or after the election. If you want to release the full report we will be very happy to see it. We will be able to read in full detail what this report is saying about your policy. I defy the minister to quote from the report to disprove that it is saying, in summary, that the government's policy is ineffective, misguided and counter-productive.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOB COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am more than happy to provide Senator Tierney and anyone else with a copy of this working paper. It is not in fact a report. I regret to say that the front page story in the Australian was a beat-up of the first order. That is a comment that I do not think I have ever made about the Australian in 17 years because it is a newspaper that I hold in extremely high regard for accurate reporting on most occasions. It astonished me that this beat-up by Mr Stapleton was run on the front page.

PARA.TAB: What astonished me even more, in terms of what I thought was a unique lack of professional ethics on the part of the Australian newspaper—it is the first time it has ever happened to me in respect of the Australian—was that Mr Stapleton was quite happy to write a front page screamer in the Australian and quite happy to attack the federal government, knowing full well that I am the architect, rightly or wrongly, of the drought policy that we are now talking about, but made not the slightest attempt to solicit any response to this attack from the federal government. He did not come near me and he did not come near my office. I have to say, Senator Crane, that you must have shares in the Australian—

TALK.START.PARA: —Ha, ha.

—You know what I am talking about. That afternoon, despite the fact that Mr Stapleton made no attempt to get any response from the federal government to the story, we provided him with one. We chased him down on Friday afternoon. The president of the grain growers, who assisted the Australian newspaper to set up the photograph that was carried with the story, provided a four paragraph rebuttal of the story. I refer to a headline in The Land newspaper last week which said, `Farm leaders back drought policy'. That story was a direct response to the beat-up in the Australian. Last week all the major farm organisations in Australia and all the state ministers solidly supported the policy.

PARA.TAB: On top of that, one of the organisations that funded this report actually put out a printed press release rebutting the story that afternoon. The newspaper did not solicit a response from me to the story. There was a response given directly to the journalist concerned by the president of the grain growers, and his organisation represents 40,000 grain growers in Australia.

There was also a printed response from one of the funding organisations. What was the result of all that? The newspaper ran a second story the following day—another screamer—simply re-running the story of the day before. It carried not one word of what I had provided to the paper in terms of a response that the president of the grain growers had provided or the organisation that funded the report. Not a single word of rebuttal was carried by the paper on the following day—and I have to say that that is the first letter I have ever written to the editor of the Australian over something like this. But what did the story carry—and I was pleased to see it? It carried a quote from Senator Winston Crane of Western Australia—

TALK.START.PARA: —A very good senator.

—He must, as I said, own shares in the Australian. It would not carry anything I told them as the federal minister who was being attacked; would not carry anything from the president of the grain growers; would not carry anything from the organisation that funded the report rebutting the story, but perpetuated the story and added to it the next day a quote condemning the government from Senator Winston Crane of Western Australia.

PARA.TAB: In fact, I am happy to provide you, Senator Tierney, as I provided the editor of the Australian, with a copy of the report because I would describe most of that working paper as drawing some unexceptional conclusions. It came to the conclusion that drought is not the only risk faced by primary producers. I do not think we needed to pay 300,000 bucks to find that out. It also came to the brilliant conclusion that preparing for drought—that is, drought proofing a property—is effective with moderate drought but is not so effective with long-term drought. You would not disagree with that.

The working paper is based on the study of seven farming systems. It is not directed to government policy and it did not, as the story in the Australian said, provide one single recommendation to government—that was not its purpose—nor did it advocate fodder subsidies, which was the other piece of nonsense that the front-page story of the Australian perpetuated.

Senator Tierney, I will give you one thing. I believe you are entitled to rely on a front-page story in the Australian for accuracy in terms of dropping a bucket on me. Regrettably, on this occasion you cannot. The bucket is not justified because the front page story of the Australian was grossly inaccurate and a beat-up of the first order.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is rather sad that some people, on the backs of people in primary industry who are in dire trouble, take an opportunity to take a shot at the minister, not about the drought policy but about the operations of a small part of it. It is well known—and it is on the record—that there was an expert inquiry that was conducted some four years or so ago. People who were a part of that inquiry body had personal and long experience on the land—and other people also had expertise. They made certain recommendations. One of those was that natural disasters such as drought should no longer be considered as part of that system. There has been a lot of argument about whether that should be so or not. I believe it should not, but I believe that the circumstances are dire and have to be dealt with.

PARA.TAB: I am chairman of the rural and regional affairs committee—a committee that has representation from all political parties, including the Australian Democrats—and we did a short inquiry to look at the way in which the recommendations from that previous inquiry were handled and whether they were making some gains in relation to those beneficial views that were expressed and should have been put into place.

The people we talked to clearly indicated that it was important that they be self-reliant and that assistance in regard to tax benefits would only be worth while for those people who were making money. After all, if you are in a loss situation, tax benefits are not available to you. So we considered the question of assistance from the government and the question of people having access to certain family payments and other payments when they are in dire circumstances.

But I cannot recall anybody—and our committee had some very close discussions from time to time with the minister; certainly I, as chairman, and Senator Brownhill, as deputy chairman, had access to the minister—at any time ever suggesting that people on the land could provide for themselves in long drought situations. Never at any time did anyone say anything other than, `We cannot afford to lose the families that are on the land. We need to keep them there. To the extent that the community is capable, through the taxation base, we should support them and see that they stay there.'

There is no doubt that that is still the attitude of the minister and still the attitude of the government in terms of drought policy. They did not develop a drought policy in a vacuum. They developed a drought policy as a result of recommendations of the expert committee and some of the views expressed to the rural and regional affairs committee. We also looked at the rural adjustment scheme.

I must say that members of the opposition on that committee very clearly suggested to witnesses on a number of occasions that they should get their minds around the importance of tax benefits and that they should understand that it is important that the money that was generated as a result of their activities in rural areas should be used to make provisions for bad times. They suggested that they should put money into funds which they could take out when needed, and store water, money and fodder so they become self-reliant. That view was accepted and expressed by people during those hearings.

I think it is unfair, unjust and sad to hear the criticism that the government's drought policy is a total failure. After all, the minister provided $160 million in that area. I will certainly be arguing the position that more has to be done if those people in real need are to be kept on their properties. They are an important part of the Australian community. They provide our food. We need them and they need us. I think we should be cooperating in a better fashion to get a better outcome for the whole nation.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: Minister for Human Services and Health

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vanstone Sen A.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Senator Gareth Evans), to a question without notice asked by Senator Vanstone this day, relating to the Minister for Human Services and Health.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Gareth Evans did not answer the question that he was asked. He simply chose to avoid the question clearly put to him. He was asked: when his government agreed to fund a private legal action to scuttle the Easton royal commission were the cabinet ministers who made that decision aware that Dr Lawrence, in her own right, probably did not have the standing to issue such proceedings? Did the federal government agree to fund proceedings or contingently fund proceedings—it does not matter which; in the end there is a commitment to pay if it is required—which Dr Lawrence, in her own right, probably would not have been able to initiate?

PARA.TAB: That has not been answered. It is a very simple question: did the government know that at the time that they agreed to pay the money? Did they know that it would be necessary to join someone else? It follows that they would have known. Did they consider that Mr John Halden may be the person who would have to be joined or did they know that he had already agreed to be joined in those proceedings—in other words, to lend his name to proceedings to get them on foot provided he did not have pay a cent? Did the Commonwealth know that? Did the cabinet ministers sitting around the table thrashing this out understand that that was the case? Were they aware that Mr Halden was simply unable to fund such an action?

If they were aware that Dr Lawrence had limited, if any, standing to initiate proceedings on her behalf, why in heavens name was Commonwealth taxpayers' money used to fund such proceedings? Why were steps not taken to ensure that Mr Halden would not be able to simply piggyback on Dr Lawrence's legal counsel—namely, at the taxpayers' expense. All Senator Gareth Evans has chosen to say is that he is quite sure that Mr Halden's solicitors will be keeping a clear record and there will be separate bills, but there has been no comment from the minister with respect to the payment to barristers, in particular Roger Gyles QC who is appearing for both.

TALK.START.PARA: —Barristers are only paid through solicitors.

—The minister now interjects that that will all be sorted out because the bill will come through the solicitors—well and good. The question still remains: did the government take steps to ensure that Mr Halden would not be able to piggyback on Dr Lawrence's legal counsel whose fees are being paid by the Commonwealth? It is reasonably clear that they did not take any such steps. They cannot get away with the ruse that they are not paying for anything that Mr Halden is getting, but if Roger Gyles chooses to do his work for nothing and then gets paid top dollar for Carmen Lawrence's work they will nod and turn the other way. That ruse is not an adequate explanation.

PARA.TAB: He was further asked why the Sydney based law firm of Dunhill Madden Butler was chosen to act for Dr Lawrence. These are Western Australian proceedings; it is a New South Wales firm. There are necessarily added expenses in operating out of New South Wales and—surprise, surprise—former Senator Stephen `let me at the money' Loosley is a consultant to that firm. Senator Evans was asked whether Senator Loosley had anything to do with that firm being appointed; whether the government had anything to do with that firm being appointed. There are no answers.

The minister has chosen to say—I will come to the gross misrepresentation by Senator Evans and Senator Bolkus in a personal explanation at a later point—that this commission in Western Australia would not have come about unless Dr Lawrence was a federal minister. I have made it abundantly clear that the commission in Western Australia has come about not because Dr Lawrence is now a Commonwealth minister but because she was then the key minister in a Western Australian government. It relates to Western Australian activities well before she ever got here. It goes to the heart of whether the parliamentary system in Western Australia can be relied on, whether electors can believe what their ministers tell them. There could be no greater purpose for a royal commission than that.

But the bottom line is it has nothing to do with her duties as a federal minister, and the Commonwealth has no business spending hard earned taxpayers' money to fund such an action. Sadly, we find Dr Lawrence hiding behind her gender in the last couple of days doing the `poor me, I am a victim' only because she does not want to be seen as the perpetrator. (Time expired)

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: Minister for Human Services and Health

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALKER.NAME: Senator GARETH EVANS
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Government in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —Let me state again for the record that when this particular matter was raised there was no secret about the fact that it was likely Mr Halden would be a co-plaintiff with Dr Lawrence in the court actions challenging the legality of the commission. There is always an issue of that standing when you do not have formal litigation initiated but are mounting something in the nature of a collateral challenge to a royal commission which does not explicitly name people.
—Does that mean yes, you did know?
—We knew. Everyone knew. There was no secret that Mr Halden was a co-plaintiff.
—Did you know she could not run it on her own? That was the question.

—It is up to her legal advisers and her to make their own judgments about what was likely to maximise the chances of her particular matter getting before the court. It is no secret that sometimes there are questions about standing which you need some belt and braces in order to make yourself absolutely sure about to put the matter beyond doubt. There is no trouble about that.

PARA.TAB: The only matter in issue is whether the Commonwealth is paying for Mr Halden's legal fees or Dr Lawrence's. We are not paying for anybody's at the moment, we have only made at best a contingent decision, because we regard all these things as the responsibility of the Western Australian government, including collateral challenges to the validity of the commission itself. Just as the New South Wales government funded Mr Greiner's collateral challenge to the ICAC commission once he got caught up in it, and just as the Tasmanian government funded Mr Gray's collateral challenge to the Rouse royal commission once he got caught up in it, so too it would be appropriate for the Western Australian government, we believe, to fund not only those people appearing before it in terms of the cross-examination of the witnesses and so on, but also those who challenge with every interest in the world to do so the nature of those proceedings as being inappropriate and a misapplication of public funds.

There is no doubt about Dr Lawrence's interest in this matter. There is not a single person in this country who does not think that the Western Australian royal commission is about Dr Lawrence to the exclusion of just about every other consideration. There is not a person in this country who does not believe that, if Carmen Lawrence was not now a high profile cabinet minister in this government, that particular royal commission would not proceed. Not only is there not a person in the country who does not believe that, Senator Vanstone does not believe it herself. I repeat again, but this time the full text of the question that was put to her by Julie Flynn:

SPEECH.PARA: But the government argues that she would not be the subject of this royal commission if she was not the cabinet minister that she is today. If she was just an ordinary member of the community there'd be no royal commission.
Vanstone: Well that may be . . .

`If she was not the cabinet minister that she is today'—not the cabinet minister that she was yesterday in the Western Australian government but the cabinet minister that she is today. You are on the public record as conceding that particular point. Of course you concede it because every person with half a brain in the country knows that that is what the nature of this particular exercise is about.

TALK.START.PARA: —Rubbish! Read the bit before and after. Don't be so deceitful.

—You can read it to your heart's content when you make a personal explanation. It does not alter the nub of that particular exchange. I am not misrepresenting your position. Your position is absolutely clear. I am happy to seek leave to incorporate in Hansard the full text, including whatever else Senator Vanstone would like of that interview. I ask for an incorporation of that page.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

SPEECH.PARA: Vanstone continued:

whatsoever. But what we would like to achieve this week is some explanation to the community as to why Dr Lawrence's private legal fees to try and scuttle the West Australian royal commission, when that action relates in no way whatsoever to her task as a federal minister, why those fees are being paid by hard earned (sic) taxpayers.
FLYNN:

But the government argues that she would not be the subject of this royal commission if she was not the cabinet minister that she is today. If she was just an ordinary member of the community there'd be no royal commission.
VANSTONE:

Well that may be, but the simple facts are these, the Commonwealth government has to spend its money in accordance with the constitution and under the acts of Parliament under which each of the ministers operate. It's not entitled to say, `oh look I'm sorry, one of our people's being attacked and we think they're being attacked wrongly, so we're just going to spend the money.'
There has to be some Commonwealth interest in doing so. Not a Labor Party interest, a Commonwealth taxpayer interest in doing so. And frankly I can't see that there is one.

Doc . . . Dr Lawrence would be quite open . . . would have been quite open to go to the commission in the first instance and to argue her claim of parliamentary privilege in the commission. Now that's what happened in the royal commission into the Brisbane line some time ago during the war. It's not that she's not entitled to raise that point, it's that the Commonwealth should not be paying her legal fees to do so.

TALK.START.PARA: —Dr Lawrence has an interest by virtue of the fact that her capacity to continue as a minister in this particular federal government is very much under challenge and under assault as a result of this particular proceeding brought two years or more after the events. If Senator Vanstone had such a passion for untangling the mysteries of Western Australian politics, one would have thought that passion would have articulated itself a little earlier. Moreover, there is a larger Commonwealth interest here in the way in which parliamentary privilege law applies at the Commonwealth level as well as the state parliaments, and the way in which, in particular, cabinet confidentiality applies. To the extent that these matters are also caught up in existing attacks that have already been mounted collaterally or which may be mounted in the future, the Commonwealth has a manifest interest in this. There is a sound legal foundation for this in terms of section 4(4)(b)—
—Why don't you release your legal advice?

—That is a matter for Mr Lavarch. If he wants to do so, there is plenty of legal advice—we have armloads of legal advice on this particular subject, oral and otherwise. We are perfectly confident of our legal ground. Under section 4(4)(b) of the Parliamentary Entitlements Act, which is a specific provision enacted after the case of Brown v. West to cover the problems that might be thought to exist with section 48 of the Constitution, which provides a specific statutory head of power, we believe we are perfectly well covered. That is a matter which we are perfectly happy to debate with you at any time and any place. (Time expired)

The fact that the decision to fund Lawrence does not meet the Government's own guidelines for the provision of assistance to ministers in relation to the defence of legal proceedings.

PARA.TAB: So it seems that if it is a Labor mate, it's all okay. The principles all of a sudden seem to change; the morality changes. It is a bit like what Senator Ray said, isn't it? That is the way Carmen Lawrence embarked, to try to destroy Richard Court. She is now getting her comeuppance—and she deserves it. QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: Minister for Human Services and Health

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to take whatever time there is left. It is a not a court, as Senator Abetz would agree; it is an exercise of executive power by one government against a minister of another government. What is at issue in this matter is the credibility—

TALK.START.PARA: —I just want to take a few minutes to make a personal explanation.
