TALK.START.PARA: —I want to speak about the misrepresentation that both Senator Gareth Evans and Senator Bolkus have chosen to make in desperation—clutching at straws—with respect to the interview that I did with Julie Flynn yesterday. Senator Evans quotes from a portion of the interview, and he very kindly has included in Hansard the whole page. This makes the picture a bit clearer, because prior to the proposition being put to me by Julie Flynn that this government says this thing would not be happening unless Carmen Lawrence was in fact a minister, I made it quite clear that the action of the Western Australian royal commission relates in no way to her task as a federal minister and, therefore, why are these fees being paid for with hard-earned taxpayers' money? My position is abundantly clear.

PARA.TAB: Following the proposition put by Julie Flynn—just before you chuckle with that overconfidence that you seem to have oozing out of your body every minute of the day, Senator Evans—I said, `Well that may be, but the simple facts are these,' and went on to explain the point which I think is the most relevant with respect to this funding. That point is, `the Commonwealth has to spend its money'—and Senator Evans I do not think would disagree—`in accordance with the constitution and under the acts of Parliament under which each of the ministers operate.'

Senator Evans and Senator Bolkus are trying to assert that the remark `Well that may be' means `Yes, that is right.' I do not think there is any way you can twist the English language, try as you may, desperate as you may be, to turn the remark `Well that may be' into `Yes, that is the case.'

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not criticising that point. Let me just move back to the one you make.

—Mr President, I am not trying to hold up the Senate any longer than necessary. If Senator Evans wants to have 53 bites of the cherry, I am happy to take as long as is required. It would not seem to be helpful if I were pushed to do that.
—Let the record speak for itself.
—What does the word `may' mean, or don't you understand it?
—I hope that you are winding up.
—I would like to, but I am having a bit of difficulty. If you cannot keep Senator Evans in order, it makes it harder.
—I am sure that you can manage. Senator Evans, it would help if you did not interject.

—The senator may remember his law school classes on the `may-shall' distinction. He understands what `may' means. How do I know what would be the case if we wound back the clock and things were different. I cannot say whether that would be the case or not. PARA.TAB: If we were able to wind back the clock and Dr Lawrence had not shifted to federal parliament, I would hope that it would still go ahead. The reason I would hope that—
Senator Gareth Evans interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —You have been asked to be quiet, you selfish thing. You take all the space all the time. You are a selfish, self-indulgent, over-opinionated thing. I would hope that the commission would go ahead in any event. The commission's purpose is to ascertain whether the Western Australian electorate can rely on what its minister has said.

PARA.TAB: Senator Evans seeks to say that there is no purpose in this other than to get Dr Lawrence. He does not think there is any—
Senator Gareth Evans interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I am happy to be pleasant about these things, but you have been asked to keep him quiet. You have failed to do so. Are you chicken or what?
—Order! This is really a question of the pot calling the kettle black. Just give your answer. Senator Evans, I ask you to desist. Senator Vanstone, please complete your explanation.
—Mr President, are you implying that there is some time limit?
—I am not implying anything. I would like you to get on with it.

—I will try. As I was saying before I was so rudely interrupted, Senator Evans tries to make the point that the commission would not be going ahead but for Dr Lawrence being in federal parliament. Ascertaining whether that is the case is a very valuable purpose of any royal commission. I can think of probably no higher purpose. The protection of the parliamentary system is very important. It is a very important matter. For that reason, I would hope that the commission would go ahead in any event.

Can I say that it would or would not? No. The obvious answer is `Well that may be.' TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It is with deep regret that I inform the Senate of the death on 2 August 1995 of the Hon. Frederick Michael Daly AO, member of the House of Representatives for the division of Martin from 1943 to 1949, member for the division of Grayndler from 1949 to 1975, and Minister for Services and Property and Leader of the House of Representatives from 1972 to 1975. He was a very good friend of this parliament all round. I acknowledge in the gallery the members of Fred's family.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALKER.NAME: Senator GARETH EVANS
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Government in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate expresses its deep regret at the death, on Wednesday, 2 August 1995, of the Honourable Frederick Michael Daly, AO, member of the House of Representatives for the division of Martin from 1943 to 1949, member for the division of Grayndler from 1949 to 1975 and Minister for Services and Property and Leader of the House of Representatives from 1972 to 1975, places on record its appreciation of his long and meritorious public service and tenders its profound sympathy to his family in their bereavement.

SPEECH.PARA: Fred Daly was born in Currabubula, near Tamworth, New South Wales, on 13 June 1912. He was one of 11 children of an Irish pioneer farming family. His father, Michael Joseph Daly, migrated from County Clare, Ireland, to Australia in the mid-1860s. At the tender age of 11, Fred lost his father. Later in his book From Curtin to Kerr, Fred noted that this tragic event was to change his family's whole way of life and eventually turn his steps towards Canberra and the Commonwealth parliament.

PARA.TAB: The family had to move to Sydney and struggled through the worsening depression that followed. Fred left school at 14 to assist the family. His first job was with a bicycle firm as a messenger, and he soon became an active member of the Federated Clerks Union with which he was to maintain a lifelong association. It was during these early years of hardship that Fred started to develop his passion for politics and his unswerving dedication for the Labor Party cause. He joined the local branch of the ALP and resolved that he would try to enter parliament. Fred achieved his ambition in 1943 when Australia was at war.

In his maiden speech on 7 October 1943, Fred was able to look beyond the war to postwar reconstruction, to a better social and economic order. Having come through the Depression, his concern was for fundamental issues affecting the ordinary people: employment, housing, health and social services. He declared that his goal as a member of parliament was to see the people of Australia:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . live as free men and women in every sense of the word, and . . . . enjoy social and economic security which is their right.

Fred's passionate commitment to ordinary working men and women and their families was very eloquently testified to by the turnout at his funeral in his own home suburb, at which there were just so many people present giving silent witness and testimony to their enormous affection for Fred and the role that he played in their lives—coming as they did from so many different backgrounds—during his years of service to, and residence in, the electorate.

PARA.TAB: Throughout his political career Fred remained true to his commitment to a better social order, most notably through his achievements in electoral reforms when he served as Minister for Services and Property in the Whitlam government. In his three decades of illustrious and memorable career in the House of Representatives—and it was both of those things—Fred was Opposition Whip from 1950 to 1956, and Minister for Services and Property and Leader of the House from 1972 to 1975. He also served as a member of the Joint Committee on Social Security from 1943 to 1946, a member of the Rationing Commission from 1946 to 1950, a member and later Deputy Chairman of the Joint Committee on the ACT from 1967 to 1972 and a member of the Commonwealth Immigration Advisory Council from 1970 to 1973.

Fred made a huge contribution to Australian public life. But perhaps most significantly of all, he humanised the parliamentary process and brought it closer to people through his understanding of the forms and practices of the parliament and the way he handled the place and, above all, through his brilliant wit and his enduring sense of humour. In the introduction of his book The Politician Who Laughed, Fred offered the following account of his personal philosophy, which I think is worth putting on the record:

SPEECH.PARA: I was privileged to serve in Parliament with some of the great political performers, masters of the arts of scorn, ridicule, satire, and humour, who used them devastatingly to win their point. Humour as practised by the masters of these skills—in Parliament or in the public forum—was not for amusement; it was to win an argument, cheerfully yet effectively. Humour to be good should be without malice. It should be good natured, pertinent, and effective in its application—and you must be able to laugh at yourself.

I think we would all acknowledge these days that that is very good advice. Fred Daly, above all, was a great Australian character and it is worth saying that there are not too many of those left in the Australian parliament these days. Maybe it is just nostalgia talking with all the error which we are prone to with nostalgia, but the political process does seem to dry up the juices of the current generations of politicians in a way that never seemed to be the case in earlier years.

PARA.TAB: When Fred retired from politics in 1975 he was the Father of the House and had the distinction of having served with 10 prime ministers, spanning the terms of nine governor-generals. He will be remembered very fondly indeed and missed greatly by both sides of politics. He was truly a unique and outstanding parliamentarian. In 1978, recognising all that, he was appointed an Officer of the Order of Australia, AO, for his services to politics.

He lived life to the full—as, I guess, his family present among us today will readily testify. In the 20 years of his retirement, he became a much loved writer and public speaker about Australian politics. His fund of memories and anecdotes—even if we heard them all about 53 times; and they were never any less funny on each subsequent occasion—did serve to keep younger generations informed and interested in the political history of the 1940s, 1950s and 1960s where so much of his political life had been lived.

He spent his retirement years in Canberra and became really something of an institution, I guess, in the national capital's political, social and, certainly, sporting life. He will be very deeply missed by all of us who knew him. On behalf of the government, I do extend to his daughter, Margaret; his son, Lawrence; daughter-in-law, Anne; and grandchildren, Kate, Clare and Michael, our most sincere sympathy in their bereavement.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of opposition senators, I wish to support the condolence motion moved by the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Gareth Evans) on the death of Fred Daly, a former minister in the Whitlam government and, at his retirement, the Father of the House of Representatives; and certainly one of the most popular members of that house. Opposition senators were saddened by his death and we offer his family—his surviving sisters, daughter, son, daughter-in-law and three grandchildren—our sympathy and condolences.

PARA.TAB: Fred Daly died at his daughter's home in Sydney on 2 August at the age of 83. In his own words, his allegiances were to his God, his family, his party and his football teams—and, as was said of him, he kept the faith. It is a bit difficult to imagine a simpler, more modest description of the man and his aspirations than his description of himself. Equally, it would be difficult to imagine a more honest statement about the man and his values. He had no special advantages in life—born of Irish immigrant parents with an elementary education—yet he became a minister in our national government, a formidable tactician, Leader of the House, and a professional and dedicated parliamentarian.

During his long and ultimately distinguished parliamentary career he initiated electoral reforms, extended the vote to 18-year-olds, greatly improved the lot of the parliamentary backbencher and the ability of that backbencher to represent his electorate, and represented the national parliament and its parliamentarians in a number of important national fora.

As was said by Senator Gareth Evans, although Fred Daly retired from the House in 1975, he certainly remained a national figure. Indeed, as a result of his conducted tours of Canberra and the precincts of Parliament House, Fred probably became better known than he was as a minister. Through Fred thousands of Australians gained a better appreciation of their national capital and their national parliament and a more tolerant view of us, their representatives. As parliamentarians, we could not have asked for a better emissary.

At a time when Australians were becoming more uncertain about their parliaments and cynical towards their politicians, Fred reminded them that politicians have the same foibles, strengths and weaknesses as are found throughout the community. He joined them in laughing at foibles, just as he had laughed at foibles and poked fun at humbug and pomposity during his time as a parliamentarian.

Many of his obituaries dwelt on his sense of humour, his wit in the House and his ability to make friendships across the parties. Of course, his friendship with our own Jim Killen has been publicly acknowledged and valued. In fact, he invited Jim to write the introductions to his books.

It would be a mistake and a denial of the man's achievements to think of him only as a humorist who took that talent with him into the parliament. His political biography From Curtin to Kerr leaves no doubt of the difficulties he faced and overcame during his years in the parliament, which included the split. Nor does his political biography leave any doubt about his ability to marshal relevant facts and make sound judgments.

Fred Daly spent 32 years in the parliament, his first two terms as the member for Martin and the remainder as the member for Grayndler. He entered the parliament and made his maiden speech during the war. He was the embodiment of Labor traditions; he provided a continuity. He served under 10 prime ministers and four former prime ministers and, interestingly, in his own superministry laid out in his political memoirs excluded most of them. Perhaps that was his way of having the last laugh. We on the opposition side acknowledge Fred Daly's contribution and his achievements and offer sincere condolences to his family.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Australian Democrats, I rise to support the condolence motion. I think it is fair to say that, irrespective of where we sit in the political spectrum, Fred Daly was a great Australian. He was an Australian who served his country with distinction, with integrity and, perhaps most amazingly of all, without losing his sense of humour.

PARA.TAB: He was a parliamentarian for more than 30 years, something which I think would quite surely try one's sense of humour, and a minister in the Whitlam government from 1972 to 1975. In his retirement he became well known as a humorist and as a witty and well loved commentator on Australian politics. He was a man of generous spirit and great wit. For me and for my colleagues he symbolises that larger than life type of Labor politician that came out of the 1940s and 1950s—a type which has unfortunately become all too rare in Australian politics today.

But it is important that Fred Daly be remembered for more than his ability to entertain and amuse. As former Prime Minister Gough Whitlam pointed out, Fred Daly made a significant contribution to government in Australia. He was largely responsible for the voting age being lowered to 18, for major electoral reform, for people in the territories obtaining Senate representation, and for the first legislation requiring parliamentarians to declare their financial interests. I found it interesting, too, that Mr Whitlam observed that nothing Fred Daly ever said in the House could not be said in public or in private. That, I think, says much about the integrity of Fred Daly, both the man and the politician.

In this year, when we celebrate the 50th anniversary of the Second World War, Fred Daly's death takes on a particularly poignant significance, and that is because he was the last survivor of the wartime government of John Curtin, a government which served Australians well in one of the most difficult and darkest periods of our history. The very fact that I can stand here and say that Fred Daly was a member of that wartime government and, some 30 years later, a member of the Whitlam government, says not just that his political career was a long one but that he was there right in the thick of things at some of the most crucial and dramatic moments in this country's history. It says that, despite his regret at spending so many years in opposition, he lived a fine, full and vigorous life.

Fred Daly was true to his roots and true to his background. He was down to earth and irreverent. I must say that I got a bit of a laugh finding out that his old English sheepdog was called Sir John. He never forget where he came from. He made no secret of the fact that, although he was a Labor man through and through, he personally had little time for the privatisation agenda of the Hawke and Keating governments.

As I said earlier, I think he was the sort of old fashioned Labor politician which Australian politics in general is all the poorer for being without. He will be missed. On behalf of the Democrats, I offer my condolences to Mr Daly's children and other members of his family.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOSWELL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to associate the National Party in the Senate with the condolence motion moved by the government. I know many senators would like to speak today on this condolence motion.

PARA.TAB: Fred Daly was a unique personality who greatly enriched Australia's political life. His death a couple of weeks ago at the age of 83 was mourned by countless numbers of Australians from all walks of life and across the entire political spectrum. As a federal member of the House of Representatives for 33 years, from 1943 during the wartime governments of John Curtin until the end of the Whitlam era in 1975, Fred Daly's contribution and commitment to his party and his electorate was unquestioned.

During his 33 years of parliamentary career, he served as Minister for Services and Property in the Whitlam government. He also served as opposition whip, Leader of the House, and Father of the House. He was well known for his humorous turn of phrase and his quick witted rejoinders to interjections could always be relied upon to enliven the debate in the House. He was a very popular member within his own party and he extended the arm of friendship and esprit de corps across the political divide—such was his enduring friendship with Sir James Killen.

After over three decades in federal politics Fred Daly embarked on his second career as author, public speaker and Canberra tour guide and spokesman. He will continue to be remembered through his political works, The A to Z of politics and The politician who laughed. Drawing on his vast political experience, his books provide a contemporary account of Australia's political life and will continue to be a source of great interest, information and amusement to many Australians.

Fred Daly's wit and generosity of spirit ensured he had many friends both in and out of politics and on both sides of the political fence. He made a great contribution to Australian political life, one which will never be forgotten. I am sure all honourable senators will join with me in extending sympathy to Mr Daly's children and grandchildren.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Forshaw Sen M.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I had the privilege and the great pleasure of knowing Fred Daly for a number of years. To people of my generation in the Labor Party and the labour movement, Fred Daly was our continuing link with the Curtin and Chifley governments. Through Fred's speeches and stories he brought to life the personalities and the political events of the 1940s, the 1950s and the 1960s. Of course, Fred's great heroes—John Curtin and Ben Chifley, Prime Ministers of Australia during the war and postwar years—have been noted by other speakers.

PARA.TAB: It is somewhat ironic that in this year, which commemorates the 50th anniversary of the end of World War II, we remember that John Curtin passed away just a few short weeks before the end of the war in the Pacific and we note that Fred Daly passed away only a matter of days before that 50th anniversary commemoration. As has been noted so often in the obituaries and speeches about Fred, he was our last link with the Curtin government.

Many of those years, particularly during the 1950s and the 1960s, were turbulent years for the Australian Labor Party. Fred was a very active participant in all the struggles and internal battles which, dare I say it, somewhat approached civil war at times. Fred Daly was always able to convey to those of us who were not around then both the seriousness and the drama of those occasions, and he was able to do it with genuine humility, with good humour and without rancour. Fred truly played it tough, but he always played it fair.

Unfortunately, whilst Fred Daly spent over 30 years in this parliament, he spent only a short three years in government and in the ministry. That was too short a time for a person who had made such a great contribution and who so richly deserved the honour and distinction of being a minister in government. Fred's contributions during those three years of the Whitlam government have been well documented, particularly his efforts in regard to electoral reform and the granting of the vote to 18-year-olds. Fred's contribution to the Labor Party was honoured with life membership in not one but two branches, the New South Wales branch and the ACT branch.

Recently I was reading the biographical notes put out by the Parliamentary Library about Fred Daly, and I was interested to note a couple of things that have not been as widely publicised about him as have many of his other great attributes. For instance, Fred Daly was a great battler for backbenchers and took steps when he first got into government—in the ministry—to improve the lot of backbenchers. He had spent such a long time in opposition that he knew what the requirements were going to be of future members of parliament on the back bench and he did something about them.

But Fred also was campaigning as far back as 1953 on the impact of aircraft noise on the residents of Sydney—something that a few of us are going through at the moment on the Senate committee. As far back as 1953, Fred campaigned hard and campaigned long on behalf of those residents in his electorate and in surrounding electorates—an issue ignored at the time by the then Liberal government but belatedly discovered by some of the opposition members today.
I noticed in a speech that Fred gave in 1971 on this issue he commenced with a few comments in his usual humorous fashion. I quote from the Hansard of September 1971 when he said:

I listened to the remarks of supporters of the Government who took part in the debate tonight. What a weird and wonderful collection they were. First we had the honourable member for Cowper (Mr Robinson), who lives on the north coast of New South Wales. He is one of the people whom the aeroplanes carry over my electorate at midnight and keep half the population awake. Having to look at him in the day time is bad enough, but fancy being woken up for him in the evening!

SPEECH.PARA: Fred then went on to make a very powerful speech in support of the rights of residents affected by aircraft noise—a speech that I am sure will be referred to during the current Senate inquiry.

PARA.TAB: Fred of course, as we all remember, was dismissed along with the Whitlam government in 1975, and anybody who was around in those times will never forget that experience. As a person who believed in fairness, in democracy and in the right of governments to govern, Fred Daly was naturally offended by the dismissal of the Whitlam government. Yet he could still bring humour to even that grave crisis. One of his most famous and wittiest speeches ever delivered in the parliament was at the time of the Khemlani affair when he described in humorous terms the cloak and dagger comings and goings of Tirath Khemlani around Canberra, and at one stage actually referred to Khemlani as somebody who was probably a half-brother to Leilani, the then Melbourne Cup racehorse.

I have particularly had the great pleasure of knowing Fred Daly through his family, Lawrie, Margaret, Anne, Kate, Clare and Michael who are in the gallery today. The Dalys moved into the area in which I lived some years ago and joined my local branch. Fred was always available for fund-raisers and we came to know and love him like anybody in the Labor Party and in general who knew Fred. I am pleased to be able to acknowledge today the presence of the Daly family, great friends of mine and my wife, Jan, and to record that Fred's son, Lawrie, and his daughter, Margaret, and the family carry on Fred's great tradition. They are great workers for the party, for the local schools, for the parish community and for the sporting organisations. I cannot help but think that what was so touching at Fred Daly's funeral in Sydney was the long lines of local people who took communion that day at the church. It was a real symbol of how loved Fred was in his local community by the ordinary folk.

It has been said that Fred had three loves: his family; his faith; and his party. He also, of course, loved his football. But he also had another love and that was for the institution of parliament itself. He had great respect for it and he was always willing to encourage others, whether they were younger members of parliament or political aspirants like myself or people who were visiting Canberra. He was always interested in bringing them to the parliament to pass on his great store of knowledge and good humour to them.I am sure that we have all seen Fred in the gallery up there on many occasions with a group of people in tow as he took them around the parliament and enlightened them on the importance of this building, of this parliament, of our democratic heritage and how we should cherish it.

I used to run into Fred quite often and he would always say to the people who were with him, `Here we have an example of life after death—this is a senator!' But Fred could always say things like that to us and we knew he only half meant it. And we are going to miss him around this place, I am sure. Certainly parliament, the Labor Party and the nation are the poorer for his passing. So to Lawrie, to Margaret, to Anne, to Kate, to Clare and to Michael I extend my sympathy. We have been privileged to know Fred, to love him as you do and to know his family. We won't forget him. In our books, Fred Daly will always have the numbers.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I rise to speak briefly on this condolence motion because Fred Daly became an important part of this community not only during the time that he was a member of parliament and came to Canberra but particularly after his retirement when he spent a lot of time here and mixed and mingled in the community, as Senator McMullan, I am sure, will also speak about.

PARA.TAB: He was at one stage—I can't remember the year—the King of Canberra, which was the time when I think many Canberrans got to know him in a way that they had not known him previously. As has been said, he has since been involved in tours of Canberra and added a great deal in that capacity. He lives on through the books that he has written and his humour and the character of him will survive in those books.

It is perhaps though as co-patron of the Raiders that I want to make some mention this afternoon. He not only was an active co-patron for the club, he became a very significant father figure to many of the players who looked up to him and saw him for the really good man that he was and, I think, gained a great deal in their own lives and careers, from their association with him, as an active player of the club. He was at the match at the Bruce Stadium on the Saturday before he died.

He was indeed loved in this community. He was, as has been mentioned, involved in the territory getting representation in the Senate. Of course, a measure of his humour and the way he dealt with people was his comment to Senator Forshaw, and to me, about life after death—`She's a senator. Ha, ha, ha!' But Fred Daly was the person who, in fact, made sure that the territory got representation in the Senate. However, that sort of comment was never hurtful or malicious. There could frequently be a cutting edge to the things that he said, but they were not personal comments to the person to whom they were directed. And it was always a good day if you ran into Fred and could exchange the time of day with him.

He will be missed by the Raiders. He will be missed in this community. He was generous with his time and talents to Canberra. The people here will miss him and I will miss him. I want to convey my condolences today to Margaret, whom I know, and to the family I have not met.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McMullan Sen The Hon R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —If time permitted there would be a lot of things I would wish to say about Fred Daly and his great contributions to Australia, to the Labor Party and to the Marrickville community he served in parliament. But so many things have been said in the House of Representatives and the Senate, and were said so eloquently at the state funeral which I had the honour to attend, that all I really need do is endorse those views and express my great appreciation for having had the opportunity to know Fred.

PARA.TAB: I think I first met him when I was in Western Australia and he was a minister in the Whitlam government. I knew him for a long time after that. I admired and respected his consistency of purpose and the contribution that he made. I always enjoyed his company. I am pleased that in people's assessment of him they have consistently made two points that would otherwise have led him, I think, to be underestimated. The first point is that, whilst he was a great humorist, he was more than a humorist; he was a person of substance. Secondly, whilst he was a popular person and a person of goodwill and many good deeds, he would never have wanted people to have thought that he was some sort of soft touch. He was a pretty tough old politician because he did the things that he thought were important to achieve the outcomes to which he was committed. He would not have wanted people to describe him as some sort of saintly milksop. That would not be the view that he had of himself.

He has been fairly accurately, appropriately and positively described by others. I simply want to join in those remarks and say something about Fred Daly and Canberra. I join with Senator Reid in doing so. The list of things that one could say about Fred's contribution to Canberra is too long to even attempt. It is hard to remember that it is 20 years since he ceased being a member of parliament in 1975. In all those years he continued to be an active and effective participant in the social and public life of Canberra and made a great contribution as an advocate for and an activist within Canberra.

As Senator Reid has said, he was the King of Canberra in 1981 and 1982, and I think everyone—even the republicans—thought of him as that for the next 13 years. When he was not officially the King of Canberra, he was still king to everybody who met him in an around Ainslie and Braddon and the inner north suburbs where he and I both lived.

The last time I saw him—and it summed up several of the elements of his life—was on the day when he was made a life member of the ACT branch of the Labor Party. I was overseas when I heard, to my great shock, that he had died. That he was made a life member of the Labor Party and that it was in Canberra, in addition to the recognition he received in his home state of New South Wales, was appropriate in relation to both his political commitment and his contribution to the ACT. He made a very effective speech that day. It was short, to the point, and witty, but with a substantial political thread running right through it.
In an article in the Sydney Morning Herald Richard Farmer wrote:
Daly was a believer in Australia being one nation. He had little time for State rivalries.

SPEECH.PARA: This is the point I wish to emphasise from a Canberra point of view. Mr Farmer went on:
. . . and saw the national capital as a symbol of what was good about the country, not what was bad.
I think we need more people like Fred to speak up for the national interest and for Canberra as the national capital. He was valued for that because of the clear genuineness with which he did it.

PARA.TAB: I had the pleasure of not only knowing Fred but of knowing and continuing to have friendship with Lawrie and Margaret and I wish to join with others in conveying my condolences to them. I have a mixture of great regret and yet pleasure at the opportunity to associate myself with this motion of condolence for Fred Daly.

TALK.START.PARA: —One of the pleasures one gets in life can be in knowing people and I think everybody has to say that it was a pleasure knowing Fred. I first got to hear Fred, not to know him, when as someone leaving the country and coming to the city I discovered one could listen to the broadcast of parliament. This is about the time when my interest in politics was being awoken. Listening to Fred as Leader of the House in the Whitlam years was to me, sitting at home on my days off from nursing, an opportunity to spend the whole time hearing what was happening and how Fred was leading the House: his humour, his barb, his political nous and his ability.

PARA.TAB: It was a great honour to meet the gentleman, to know him, and to know his family. I joined the Labor Party the year when Fred ceased to be the member for Grayndler, but he never left parliament. He was often to be seen in the corridors of parliament and whilst, yes, we were told that there was life after death when we met him, he was still interested to know what we were doing, how we were going and what was happening. He never lost that interest.

I saw him just a couple of weeks before this place adjourned for the last recess. At that time I had an opportunity to have a short and quick but delightful discussion with Fred about what was happening. He could tell you what the opposition was doing wrong and how they were going to make fools of themselves—all those wonderful things. As everyone has said, his sense of humour was wonderful and his wit will never be forgotten.

Another thing that should never be forgotten about Fred is that he also never forgot. He never forgot his party loyalty. He never forgot all his loves. He also never forgot what his colleagues and his opponents had done. In 1983, as a change of career, I started work for David Simmons. I came to know Tony Luchetti, a contemporary of Fred's, very well. I had been at a function with Fred and he had asked me what I was doing, where I was working, and just generally catching up. I told him I had seen Tony. The first thing he said was, `Ah, but Tony voted such and such a way at such and such a time on such and such an issue.' A couple of weeks later I met Tony Luchetti and I said, `Fred asked me to pass on his regards.' Tony said, `Yes. Fred voted such and such a way at such and such a time on such and such an issue.' They had been on opposite sides of the debate in the caucus room and 30 years later they still remembered.

That, of course, was the great value that Fred brought to the Labor Party: that he never forgot Labor Party history and he made sure that it had been well documented. He never forgot parliamentary history. He ensured with his writings and his stories that that history will never be forgotten.

He was always happy to attend ALP fundraising functions. I know he travelled long distances to do so. I have fond memories of attending a fundraising function one night at Temora. I think two former state ministers who attended the function were Harry Jensen and Syd Einfeld. It was billed as a retirement farewell for them by Terry Sheahan. Whilst they were the guests, Fred was the MC for the evening. For 40 minutes Fred had his audience almost rolling on the floor. Temora is not a Labor town and it is not in the middle of a Labor area. But the number of people of all political persuasions who came to hear this legendary figure was wonderful. It was a great tribute to him. Today I wish to be associated with all of the tributes. To Lawrie, Margaret, Anne and the children can I say that my sympathy and thoughts are with you.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to join in the condolence motion in honour of Fred Daly. It is a symbol of how important Fred Daly was to the ALP and to Australian history generally that when I entered parliament some 50 years after he entered parliament he was a very familiar and reassuring figure to me.

PARA.TAB: A lot of people have talked about Fred's contribution while he was in parliament, and I acknowledge that. However, I do not really want to speak about that. What I really want to speak about is Fred's contribution outside the parliament and the contribution he made after he retired from parliament. It is extraordinarily unusual for people to continue to make a contribution after they have been in parliament, particularly after 30 years. Many former parliamentarians go away and pursue their personal interests and that part of their life is over. That was not so with Fred.

When I joined the Labor Party in 1980 and then when I entered parliament in 1994 the person who was hanging around attending party functions and fund-raisers—the inevitable rubber chicken dinners, the inevitable sausage sizzles, the inevitable soggy chip drink nights raising money slavishly for the Labor Party—was Fred. The great thing about Fred was that you could bring on a parliamentarian and a minister at a dinner and you might get a few people interested—those who were really committed to the Labor Party—but if you had Fred along he would attract a whole group of people, Labor supporters, Labor Party members and a lot of people who just came along because they were interested in the witty things that Fred could say. That was always a great bonus.

I have to emphasise that in saying all these things I do not want to put forward the view that Fred was in some way all froth and bubble. Fred was a person of extremely strong opinions and very strong principles. He did not ever believe things in a half-hearted way. He did not half believe this; he was never cynical. He believed things absolutely and he believed in things absolutely. I have to say that Lawrie, Anne, Kate, Clare and Michael, whom I have had the pleasure of knowing, have carried on that tradition of believing in things very strongly. I want very much on my behalf, and on behalf of my family, to express my very strong condolences to them. I also pass my condolences to Margaret, whom I do not know as well. Thank you for sharing your father and your grandfather with us. He was very much appreciated.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to say something in relation to Fred Daly—my old mate. Let me endorse all the remarks that everyone has passed in outlining the history of Fred Daly. In doing so, could I extend my sympathy to the family—Lawrie, Margaret, his daughter-in-law, and his grandchildren.

PARA.TAB: Fred Daly was a character that comes only once in a lifetime, particularly in this place. I think the measure of the man was not only in the funny jokes that he could tell but also in the way in which he performed in this place as a member of parliament in the Whitlam government, the way he performed after he retired from parliament and the way in which he set an example for a large number of people within the Labor Party. I am sure that he was also admired by a lot of people on the opposite side of this chamber.

Fred Daly was the type of person, no matter where you were, particularly in this parliament, to spend some time having a long discussion about not only politics but also, as someone mentioned before, the Raiders and football. I must say that that was one area that Fred and I never agreed on because of my support for the Broncos and his support for the Raiders. But we had a lot of discussions that we could agree on, and those discussions were in relation to what was happening politically in Canberra and what was happening on the political scene in other states. He would always ask what was happening in Queensland and I would give him a run-down. He would then say to me that he thought they ought to do this, this or this, in no uncertain terms. The way in which Fred Daly used to become a part of a discussion and take an interest in not only the political situation here but in other states is something that we will not see again for a long time.

If one were to say something about Fred Daly, from a Labor Party point of view one could say a lot—and I think a lot has been said. But the one thing that shows the type of person he was, was his friendship with Jim Killen. Jim Killen was a Queenslander. I think Fred might have had some sort of liking for Queenslanders. I can remember Fred and Jim on many occasions having a quiet discussion—more than a quiet discussion on some occasions—but always remaining strong friends. For anyone as strong politically as Killen and as strong politically as Daly to remain friends shows very clearly the measure of the person that I speak about—Fred Daly.

The only regret I have is the fact that I was overseas and was not able to attend Fred's funeral, or his day out as they call it. I had a phone call very early in the morning from my son when I was in San Francisco. I said, `What's wrong?' He said, `Something terrible's happened.' I thought something had happened to one of the members of my family. He said, `Fred Daly died and his funeral will be on before you get back, dad.' I said, `Well, that has probably knocked the gloss off the few days I still have to spend in San Francisco.' That is the one regret I have—that I was not there to say goodbye to Fred Daly. Could I take this opportunity to again extend my sympathies to his family—Margaret, Lawrie, his daughter-in-law and grandchildren. Could I also say on the record here today goodbye to a good mate.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will end the debate by sharing a brief vignette with you. Senator Forshaw mentioned that Fred Daly was a regular visitor to the gallery. So it was. You would often see him up here with 20 or 30 people around him. Those people were generally public servants taking part in the parliamentary familiarisation seminars that Fred Daly was conducting.

PARA.TAB: But he did not want to give them any ordinary tour. Anybody can go and see the Great Hall, the public areas and come in to see the chambers—the ordinary public can do that. Fred wanted to give them something extra. I do not know how many others he used this way, but he used to burst into my office with 30 or 40 people in tow behind him and simply take over the office. It did not matter what I was doing or where I was. He managed to get past all those officers who normally guard my privacy so well and burst in.

His comment was not the usual comment about life after death as a senator and so on. It was, `Here is obviously a man who has no worries,' as I looked furrowed and tense before question time, because he would usually observe question time just after his visit to my office. Nobody dared knock him back. Who knocks back an icon or a national treasure? That is the way he was seen in the office. He was always a welcome visitor to the office and welcome wherever I met him.

I hope that somebody else takes up those tours. I am not sure that they will have as ready access to the office as Fred did. I also hope that somebody else takes up the political tours of Canberra, because it would be a great loss indeed if they were not to continue, based on the knowledge that Fred has given us but building on it as we go along. I would like to join in what everybody has said and add my condolences to the family who are present with us in the gallery. I ask honourable senators to stand in silence to signify their assent to the motion.

TAB.EMPHASIS: Question resolved in the affirmative, honourable senators standing in their places.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Mr Samuel James Benson CBE, RD

TALK.START.PARA: —It is with deep regret that I inform the Senate of the death on Wednesday, 26 July 1995 of Samuel James Benson CBE, RD, member of the House of Representatives for the division of Batman from 1962 to 1969.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Beahan Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator O'Chee, by letter dated 11 July 1995, has raised with me matters of privilege under standing order 81, and asked that I give precedence to a motion to refer the matter to the Privileges Committee. I have determined that a motion to refer the matter to the Privileges Committee should have precedence. Because of the significance of the issue arising from those matters, it is important that I set out in some detail the reasons for my determination. With the concurrence of the Senate, I will incorporate a statement of reasons into Hansard. I table the letter from Senator O'Chee and other documents provided by him.

PARA.TAB: The statement read as follows—

The essence of the first matter raised by Senator O'Chee is that certain persons have been threatened with legal action and that the basis of the threatened action is, at least in part, the provision by those persons of information to Senator O'Chee concerning matters which he has raised in the Senate. Senator O'Chee suggests that the purpose of the threatened actions is to intimidate those persons in relation to the provision of information to members of Parliament.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator O'Chee's letter raises the very significant question of whether actions taken against persons in respect of their provision of information to members of Parliament may constitute a contempt, in the words of section 4 of the Parliamentary Privileges Act 1987, as conduct which

"amounts, or is intended or likely to amount, to an improper interference with the free exercise by a House or a committee of its authority or functions, or with the free performance by a member of the member's duties as a member".
This question has not been determined, either by parliamentary cases or by judgments of the courts.

It is well established that a threat to take legal action against a person may constitute a contempt where the threat is intended or likely to influence a person in respect of the provision of evidence to a court, a House or a committee. The courts have made this principle clear in relation to contempt of court, and the Senate Privileges Committee, and other parliamentary privileges committees, have accepted the principle in the course of their work.

The question is whether such a threat constitutes a contempt when directed at the provision of information to a member of Parliament for the purpose of having a matter raised in Parliament. A strong case can be made out that the contempt jurisdiction extends to that area. Obviously the provision of information to members for the purposes of raising matters in Parliament is highly significant to the performance by members of their parliamentary functions and an important means by which matters may be raised in Parliament. Members would be significantly affected in their work if such provision of information were to be regularly subjected to threats of legal action.

Senator O'Chee also raises the question of whether the provision of information to a member for the purposes of raising a matter in Parliament may be protected by parliamentary privilege in so far as it may fall within matters "for purposes of or incidental to, the transaction of the business of a House or a committee" within the meaning of subsection 16(2) of the Parliamentary Privileges Act 1987. The answer to this question, however, does not determine the answer to the question concerning the contempt jurisdiction, although, if it were held that such provision of information is covered by parliamentary privilege, this would be persuasive in any consideration of the question of the contempt jurisdiction. It is not necessary for me to consider the question.

I am required by Resolution 4 of the Senate's Privilege Resolutions to determine whether a motion to refer the matter to the Privileges Committee should have precedence, having regard to the following criteria:

(a)the principle that the Senate's power to adjudge and deal with contempts should be used only where it is necessary to provide reasonable protection for the Senate and its committees and for Senators against improper acts tending substantially to obstruct them in the performance of their functions, and should not be used in respect of matters which appear to be of a trivial nature or unworthy of the attention of the Senate; and
(b)the existence of any remedy other than that power for any act which may be held to be a contempt.

In relation to criterion (a), it is clear that interference with the ability of citizens to provide information to members of Parliament could substantially obstruct members in the performance of their functions; the question of whether the contempt jurisdiction is necessary to provide reasonable protection probably depends on the open question of extent of the contempt power. In relation to criterion (b), the only other remedy is for the persons concerned to defend any legal action against them, but, as has been indicated, the legal question involved does not determine the question of the extent of the contempt jurisdiction, and, as Senator O'Chee points out, threatened actions may have a chilling effect on persons who might otherwise provide information to members, and a threatened action which is not proceeded with can put a potential defendant to a great deal of trouble and expense.

I therefore think that the matter raised by Senator O'Chee substantially meets the criteria I am required to consider, and I think that I should allow the matter to be referred to the Privileges Committee so that that committee can determine the very significant question which arises in relation to the Senate's contempt power.

The Committee, of course, will also determine the questions of fact in respect of the particular cases raised by Senator O'Chee; I am not required to determine those questions of fact for the purposes of determining whether a motion for a reference to the Privileges Committee should have precedence.

Senator O'Chee also states that legal action has been threatened against him in relation to his intention to raise this matter as a matter of privilege, and he indicates that this threat was made in order to deter him from so raising the matter. It is well established that threatening members of Parliament with legal action in order to influence them in the conduct of their parliamentary duties may constitute a contempt. This matter therefore clearly meets the criteria I am required to consider.
I therefore determine that a motion in respect of the matters raised by Senator O'Chee may have precedence.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOSWELL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

PARA.TAB: That the following matters be referred to the Committee of Privileges:
(a)whether threats of legal proceedings were made against persons in respect of their provision of information to Senator O'Chee in relation to matters raised in the Senate by Senator O'Chee;
(b)whether a threat of legal proceedings was made against Senator O'Chee in respect of his activities as a Senator; and
(c)whether contempts were committed in respect of those matters.

TALK.START.PARA: —Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows:

PETITION.TITLE: Building Materials
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:
The Petition of the undersigned shows:

PARA.TAB: We the undersigned citizens respectfully submit our opposition to the announced imposition of Sales Tax of 12% on basic hardware and building products by the Federal Government from July 1 1995. The petitioners note particularly that:

1. This new tax will directly affect ordinary Australians in the form of rising prices of building, maintaining and improving their home and by consequential job losses and company closures in an industry which has faced many economic pressures over recent years.
2. The new tax offers no net benefit to Australia and should be abandoned.
Your petitioners request that the Senate should not pass this legislation when it is presented and/or work to prevent this taxation measure from being implemented by the current Federal Government.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senator Abetz (from 33 citizens), Senator Gibson (from 72 citizens) and Senator MacGibbon (from 158 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: French Nuclear Testing
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:

PARA.TAB: The petition of the undersigned expresses the widespread community outrate throughout Australia at the decision of the French Government to resume nuclear testing in the South Pacific.
Your petitioners ask that the Senate note and endorse the concerns expressed in this petition and convey to the French Parliament in the strongest terms Australia's opposition to this decision.

PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senator Beahan (from 21,678 citizens), Senator Childs (from 106 citizens) and Senator West (from 648 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Sex Guide
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:

PARA.TAB: The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that:

PETITION.PARA: 1.We are opposed to the sex guide endorsed by Ms Lawrence, Minister for Health in the Keating Government, and published in the December issue of Cleo.
2.We believe that the sex guide encourages dangerous sexual practices which could have serious medical and moral effects.

PARA.TAB: We call on Ms Lawrence to withdraw her endorsement of this sex guide and for the Prime Minister, Mr Keating, to indicate his disapproval.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senator Herron (from 3,668 citizens) and Senator Patterson (from 54 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Family Law
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:

PARA.TAB: The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia draws to the attention of the Senate the need for changes to the Family Law Act of Australia and to the child support scheme.
Your petitioners therefore request that the Senate support the following changes.

PETITION.PARA: (1)That the existing Family Law Act be scrapped and replaced by a more simplified version together with the minimum of rules and regulations necessary.

(2)That the Family Court be replaced by a Tribunal and that all matters resulting from divorce and family breakdown be heard before, and determined by a panel; the panel to be made up of persons qualified in matters arising from family breakdown.
(3)That legal professionals be barred from appearing before the Tribunal resulting in vast savings to the disputing parties.
(4)That a modified fault clause be re-introduced to Family Law primarily designed to discourage adultery and to stop rewarding adulterers at the expense of deserted and innocent parties.
(5)That the Child Support Agency be scrapped and replaced by an appropriate administrative procedure within the Tribunal.
(6)That apart from cases of exceptional circumstances parental-child access become the inalienable right of all parents.

(7)That alternative counselling, (Government funded) be made available through the Churches and that much more emphasis be placed on mediation in resolving disputes prior to the commencement of legal proceedings.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senator Kemp (from 416 citizens) and Senator Patterson (from 800 citizens).

PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President Members of the Senate in the Parliament assembled.
The Petition of the undersigned draws to the attention of the Senate Indonesia's continued denial of human rights to the people of East Timor.

PARA.TAB: Your Petitioners ask the Senate to call on the Australian Government to:
1. actively support all United Nations resolutions and initiatives on East Timor;
2. actively support the right to self-determination of the people of East Timor;
3. work for the immediate release of all Timorese political prisoners;
4. repeal the Timor Gap Treaty; and
5. stop all military cooperation and commercial military activity with Indonesia.

PETITION.TITLE: Asylum Seekers
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled the petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth:
the Australian Government's policy of detaining people seeking asylum has caused enormous hardship and misery for those detained;
the policy has contravened international obligations undertaken by Australia;
as a result of the detention of asylum seekers the Australian community has borne a considerable financial burden;

PARA.TAB: Your petitioners therefore most humbly pray that the Senate in Parliament assembled should request the Government:

to release those asylum seekers still being held in Department of Immigration Processing Centres.

PARA.TAB: And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Logging and Woodchipping
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.

PARA.TAB: We are dismayed at the continuing destruction of old growth and wilderness forests around Australia, despite the National Forest Policy Statement jointly signed by the Commonwealth and all States except Tasmania.

Intensive logging, most often to feed a voracious woodchip industry is underway or planned for many high conservation value forests. These forests should be protected by the commitments of the Commonwealth and State Governments under the NFPS.
These forests include:

PETITION.PARA: Coolangubra Wilderness and other areas of the S.E. Forests of NSW along with rainforest and other N.E. areas of NSW including Wingham, Mistake, Richmond Range, Chaelundi, North Washpool, Barrington and Dorrigo.
The Southern Highlands, Great Western Tiers and Tarkine Wilderness of Tasmania.
The Karri and Jarrah forests of S.W. Western Australia.
The Errinundra Plateau and other areas of the East Gippsland forests of Victoria.
The rainforests of the Proserpine region of Queensland.

PARA.TAB: We request that the Government act urgently to protect our precious forests by utilising the Commonwealth's legal and constitutional powers, including:

PETITION.PARA: Refusal of export woodchip licences
Powers to control corporations
Protection of areas listed on the register of the National Estate
Protection and effective funding of areas identified for their World Heritage values.

PARA.TAB: Genuine and effective action by the Government to protect these and other old growth and wilderness forests is critical. A comprehensive plantation strategy rather than exploiting native forests is the way forward for a truly environmentally responsible timber industry. We further request that the Government take effective action without further delay.

PETITION.TITLE: Sex Guide
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:

PARA.TAB: We the undersigned citizens deplore the action of the Minister for Health, the Hon. Carmen Lawrence MP and the Federal Labor Government in spending over $250,000 on the Cleo magazine supplement featuring a section entitled the Agony and the Ecstacy, that promotes anal sex as a normal and safe activity, under the guise of sex education.
We call on the Senate to fully debate the need for a Senate inquiry into this misuse of the health budget at a time when basic health services are being starved of funds.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Sex Guide
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:

PARA.TAB: We the undersigned citizens condemn the Minister for Health, the Hon. Carmen Lawrence MP and the federal Labor Government for spending a quarter of a million dollars on the Cleo magazine supplement featuring a section entitled the Agony and the Ecstacy, that promotes anal sex as a normal and safe activity, under the guise of sex education.

We call on the Federal Government to address the real needs of young Australians by providing resources for health education programs that do not glorify potentially dangerous sexual practices, but promote sound medical advice and support in areas of HIV AIDS and sexually transmitted diseases and youth suicide.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: National Flag
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:

PARA.TAB: The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that:

PETITION.PARA: 1.The majority of Australians are completely satisfied with the existing Australian national flag and condemns the attack on the Australian flag by the Prime Minister Mr Keating while he was overseas.

2.We therefore request that the Senate ensures that the Australian national flag, as provided in Section (3) of the Flags Act, is not changed or replaced without first being voted upon and approved by the people of Australia in a referendum.

PARA.TAB: And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Constitutional Monarchy
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.
The petition of the undersigned shows:

We the undersigned citizens respectfully submit that Australia, under its constitutional system based on the Monarchy, is one of the world's most successful democracies. The petitioners note particularly that:

PARA.TAB: Australia is one of the world's oldest democracies
Australia has led the world in many democratic reforms

PETITION.PARA: Our constitution, based on the Monarchy, has:

PARA.TAB: ensured national independence
maintained national unity in a federation
provided constitutional stability
protected our liberties and freedoms

PETITION.PARA: Your petitioners therefore request that:
Australia should remain a constitutional Monarchy with Her Majesty The Queen of Australia as our head of State.

PETITION.TITLE: Widow Allowance
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in the Parliament assembled:

PARA.TAB: The Petition of the undersigned requests that the Widow Allowance be made available to women over 50 who were widowed, separated or divorced after they turned 40 years of age; that the allowance be paid at the Age Pension rate; and that the allowance attract the same concessions and benefits as the Age Pension.

PETITION.TITLE: French Nuclear Testing
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.

PARA.TAB: We, the undersigned, wish to lodge our protest in the strongest possible terms against the resumption of Nuclear Testing. Therefore we request:
1. the immediate and permanent cessation of mining and the export of Uranium as a signal to all nations that we will not accept nuclear weapons in any form,
2. the use of all means possible to dissuade France and any other nation from Nuclear Weapons Testing,
3. that the Minister for Foreign Affairs make a submission arguing the illegality of Nuclear Weapons to the International Court of Justice.

PETITION.TITLE: Salmon
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:

PARA.TAB: The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia opposes the lifting of a ban on the import to Australia of Canadian Pacific Salmon, which the Australian Bureau of Agriculture and Research Economics acknowledges has the potential to destroy the Tasmanian industry and also pose the threat of serious and irrecoverable damage to fresh water species and other forms of Marine life should exotic diseases known to be carried by these fish become established here.
Your petitioners request that the Senate uphold Australia's right to protect local industry and livelihoods of thousand of workers—from the threat of destruction.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will pray.

PETITION.TITLE: French Nuclear Testing
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:

PARA.TAB: The Petition of the undersigned:
1. Condemns the President of France, Jacques Chirac, and the French Government for deciding to resume nuclear testing at Mururoa Atoll;
2. Joins in the world-wide anger over France's decision, which calls into question France's commitment to the Nuclear Non-Proliferation Treaty;
3. Urges the Federal Government to urgently inform France in the strongest possible terms of the anger felt by the people of Australia at the decision;
4. Calls on the Federal Government to consider all available diplomatic; economic and cultural measures which may force the French Government to cancel nuclear testing.

PETITION.PARA: And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Child Care
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Senators in Parliament assembled:

PARA.TAB: The petition of the undersigned shows: the injust and inequitable nature of the Government's policy to restrict Childcare Assistance where a parent is outside the workforce to 12 hours per week. This policy will cause hardship to lower income families, to the children of those families, and child care workers. The Government should be condemned for breaking its promise to ensure access and affordability in child care.

Under the Government's policy parents will have to pay full cost fees after 12 hours of childcare per week if one parent is outside the workforce. This will widen the gap between rich and poor, and many child care workers may lose their jobs.
Your petitioners therefore ask that the Senate should oppose the passage of this Bill into law.

PETITION.TITLE: Children: Slave Labour
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:

PARA.TAB: The Petition of the undersigned shows concern regarding the appalling conditions under which some children in so-called third world nations must work in order to produce goods for export. This concern was fuelled by a recent documentary featuring child labour in Pakistan. These children are chained to looms 24 hours a day in order to produce carpets for export.

PETITION.PARA: Your Petitioners ask that the Senate monitor imports into this country and ban from import those whose production employs children in degrading and inhuman conditions.
