INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —I inform the Senate that the President has received the following letter, dated 22 August 1995, from Senator Kernot:

INTERJECT.PARA: Pursuant to standing order 75, I give notice that today I propose to move:

PARA.TAB: That in the opinion of the Senate the following is a matter of urgency:

INTERJECT.PARA: The necessity for the government to address the growing impact on the current account deficit of the growth of consumption imports largely funded by the increase in household debt, and the need for the government to review its inadequate industry, trade and banking policies to prevent recurring balance of payments crises.

PARA.TAB: More than the number of senators required by the standing orders having risen in their places—

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kernot Sen C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That in the opinion of the Senate the following is a matter of urgency:

SPEECH.PARA: The necessity for the government to address the growing impact on the current account deficit of the growth of consumption imports largely funded by the increase in household debt, and the need for the government to review its inadequate industry, trade and banking policies to prevent recurring balance of payments crises.

We have been debating a lot of important matters here so far today, but none more important, I think, than the current account deficit. The current account deficit for 1994-95 was over $26 billion—the highest ever. This represents a $10 billion deterioration on last year. It means that for every $100 we as a nation earn we are spending almost $106—overspending we could only finance by increasing foreign debt or selling off more and more of our national assets to foreign investors.

PARA.TAB: Our current account deficit is now the largest of any OECD country, even higher than Mexico. It is true that we are probably close to the peak of this particular economic cycle and, perhaps, the deficit will start to fall. We certainly hope so. But the fact remains that the current account has been in deficit for 24 years running. How much longer can we, as a nation, continue borrowing and selling off our assets to fund a way of life which we want and have become accustomed to but which we cannot afford?

Jacking up interest rates to the highest level in the world, then waiting and hoping for the cycle to turn, is an extraordinarily blunt, short-term and, ultimately, destructive policy answer. But that so far is all this government has offered. My colleague Senator Spindler will concentrate on our export and import performance and the inadequacy of this government's trade and industry policies, but I want to concentrate on the government's financial market policies and the impact that these are having on the current account.

It was no surprise to the Democrats that in the last quarter imports of consumption goods in July rose by nine per cent, while imports of capital goods fell by 15 per cent. This reflects the slowdown in business investment going on because of interest rates, in our view, and also the build-up of consumer spending, much of it financed by debt. In the same week as those figures were released, the Reserve Bank revealed that personal loans jumped $1.6 billion in the three months to June—the largest quarterly rise since figures have been kept, that is, since 1989. That increase comes on top of the massive 16.5 per cent increase in housing lending over the past year to a new total of $158 billion. Household debt is twice the level it was just five years ago. Despite the rhetoric, incomes have not risen all that much in recent years. Not surprisingly, households are saving much less. In fact, our national savings rate is just one third of the rate of a decade ago.

In the 1980s when the current account went through the roof it was because of a massive debt-financed speculative boom by business. But this time business has been more restrained, funding growth mostly by savings. It is households which are spending, spending and spending—spending money they do not have but which the banks, with the benefit of enjoying fat profits on home and personal loans, are more than happy to give them. With higher interest rates and low income growth, an increasing number of households have been caught in this vice.

What the Democrats believe is needed is a stronger commitment to national savings, and it is needed now—not in three years or 10 years or when the government sees fit to respond to the FitzGerald report in detail. It means a few things. It means attacking the debt culture in this country, it means making it more attractive to save, it means reducing the taxation on medium-term interest bearing savings, promoting employee share plans and better targeting superannuation tax concessions. Yet the government sits on its hands and the opposition criticises.

TALK.START.PARA: —We don't.

—You do sit on your hands, Senator. You keep saying, `We are going to have another statement, and eventually we'll do something.' The opposition has criticised but so far has failed to release its proposals on how it would address the urgent need for action on the current account.
—What would you do?

—I just told you. I just gave you five good ideas to start with, Senator Schacht. After 24 years, both Labor governments and coalition governments have failed to address the urgency. We need integrated solutions now. (Time expired)

TALKER.NAME: Senator SCHACHT
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Small Business, Customs and Construction)

TALK.START.PARA: —You caught me a bit short, Senator Kernot, speaking for only five minutes, but I noticed that you kept five minutes to round up at the end. That is a very smart move. I must remember that tactic.
—Don't you know how this place works? Haven't you heard about proportionality?

—No, it is using the five minutes at the end. The government rejects this urgency motion moved by the Democrats. We have heard most of this comment before from the Democrats. We know the prescription that Senator Spindler has, which is to turn Australia into a cloistered, closed economy which all through the `50s, the `60s and the `70s made Australian industry uncompetitive. It meant Australian consumers paid far too much for goods that were not of international standard or quality. It also meant that our manufacturing industries were going backwards.

PARA.TAB: In the 15 minutes that I have available, I want to put on the record some of the facts and figures that deal with the issues raised in Senator Kernot's motion. The 1995-96 current account deficit is expected to be $27 billion. That has been stated in the budget clearly and unambiguously by the government. It is similar in nominal terms to the preliminary outcome of the 1994-95 budget of $26.1 billion. However, as a proportion of GDP, the current account deficit is forecast to improve from the budget forecast of around six per cent of GDP in 1994-95 to 5 1/2 per cent of GDP in 1995-96.

An improvement in net export volumes in the terms of trade is expected to be offset by a rise in the net income deficit, resulting in the small increase in the current account deficit. Imports of goods and services in volume terms are expected to rise by eight per cent in 1995-96 compared with the expected increase of 17 per cent in 1994-95. The forecast slowing in import volume growth largely reflects the anticipated slowing in the domestic demand growth in 1995-96 as relative to 1994-95, which is clearly the government's stated policy in the budget of this year.

Exports of goods and services in volume terms are forecast to increase by nine per cent compared with four per cent in 1994-95. The pick-up in export volume growth will reflect a growth in rural exports, given the assumed return to more normal weather conditions in grain growing areas. Though New South Wales is still suffering, in southern Australia, particularly in South Australia at the moment, we may well have one of the best crops ever in cereals and grains. Strong growth is expected to continue for elaborately transformed manufactures and service exports, reflecting the ongoing strength of international demand and competitiveness of Australian industry.

The improvements in the terms of trade reflect strengthening in commodity prices in 1995-96, as world industrial production increases and fundamentals such as falling stockpiles improve in many commodity markets. In particular, higher coal and iron ore contract prices negotiated with the Japanese for the period April 1995 to March 1996 are expected to boost aggregate export prices. The net income deficit is expected to rise in 1995-96. This reflects higher interest payments flowing from increases in world interest rates since early 1994.

As you can see, we do not run away from the fact that we still have a problem with the current account deficit. We want to put those figures on the record, as we did in the budget. Even today in the parliament Senator Cook acknowledged that this is a major problem that has to be dealt with. In dealing with it, there are a number of issues which the government has taken on. First of all, it is to improve the savings pool in Australia by the establishment and expansion of superannuation to allow Australians to improve their ability to fund their retirement from their own superannuation. This is a long-term program. I have seen criticism in the media by some commentators saying that the full benefit of this will only be received by people who are now 18 years of age and who will get it after 40 years of work in the Australian work force. This has been criticised as not being able to provide the full benefit.

TALK.START.PARA: —No, just overstated.

—No, Senator Kernot, some commentators have said this and have accused the government of taking this long-term view. I have to say that Australia has culturally suffered in many ways by the fact that we have not taken the long-term view in planning, the long-term view in structuring our economy and the long-term view, particularly in this case, of the savings pool. We say with some pride that we are thinking about 18-year-old kids going out to get a job in the next year or so. When they retire in 40-odd years time, they will be able to retire with very close to average weekly earnings for the rest of their retirement period. We think that is a long-term goal worth working for.

PARA.TAB: We believe that the savings pool is being addressed, as are other micro-economic reform measures, of which there are too many to mention now. We have taken many measures through the 1980s and the 1990s to make Australia more competitive. It means that, over the longer term, particularly as we move to a higher expansion of exports from elaborately transformed manufactures, this is where the best growth will be in our economy.

Often we hear criticism that our Australian economy and industry is being affected by the import of cheap manufactured goods from low wage countries. If you look at the figures for all of the countries with a substantial trade with Australia in the north Asia and east Asia area—most of them with wages a lot less than Australia—only one at the moment, I think it is China, has a balance of trade which sometimes is a bit negative for us and which sometimes is in surplus. Other than China, we have a substantial trade surplus with the countries with the very lowest wage levels. Whether it is Thailand, Singapore, Hong Kong, Indonesia, Malaysia or Korea, we have a substantial trade surplus. The countries with which we have a substantial trade deficit are the countries with the highest labour wages in the world. They are North America, Canada, the US, eastern Europe, Germany, France, Great Britain and Scandinavian countries. They are the countries with the highest labour wages because we import from them the high value added products that our mature economy needs.

It is not until we get a high level of elaborately transformed manufactures into our export mixture that we will be able to effectively address the current account deficit. Certainly in the Working Nation statement and in a number of statements over the last decade, the government in industry policy, in my own portfolio area, has consistently aimed to make Australian industry in the manufacturing area and in the value added area internationally competitive. For example, we have seen car exports in a decade grow from barely $100 million or more to $1 1/2 billion. Not only the major car manufacturers but also many car component manufacturers, particularly in my own state, are now exporting successfully.

Foreign debt is also mentioned in the motion. Australia's net foreign debt at the end of March 1995 was $166.9 billion or 37 per cent of GDP. Although the peak was reached at the end of September 1993—$174 billion, or 42 per cent of GDP—we admit the level is significantly higher than the level of net foreign debt in the early 1980s. A build-up in foreign debt as a result of the current account deficit is not necessarily an undesirable development, so long as the deficits are geared towards exploiting investment opportunities which are capable of generating sufficient returns to cover servicing costs. It must be remembered that 61 per cent of Australia's net foreign debt is owed by private sector borrowers. Unfortunately, every time the community hears about Australia's debt, they believe it is all Commonwealth debt, government debt, but it is overwhelmingly private sector borrowers. It is they, rather than the economy as a whole, that accept the risk associated with holding this debt and, so far, they have been able to service that debt.

TALK.START.PARA: —Who encourages people to borrow?

—I point out to Senator Kernot that it is overwhelmingly this private sector debt that ordinary Australians have accumulated by borrowing to buy consumer goods and by building houses, along with the corporations, borrowing large amounts of money, certainly in the binge of the 1980s, with corporate takeovers and so on. But no-one has suggested—and we have to be careful about this, Senator Kernot—that this debt is not serviceable in the private sector. People are adequately servicing it; and that is the point that ought to be made.

PARA.TAB: The remaining 39 per cent of the debt, which is in the public sector, is overwhelmingly accounted for by state governments and public trading enterprises. Currently, the Commonwealth government is a small net borrower. I hear—not you so much, Senator Kernot, I admit—the opposition giving misleading rhetoric about the state of Australia's debt. It does not mention that 61 per cent of it is in the private sector and, overwhelmingly, in the corporate sector.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is irrelevant; absolutely irrelevant.
—Are you saying that the debt overall is now irrelevant? This is a new line from the opposition.

—I take a point of order. The minister knows full well that that is not what I said. What I said was that the distinction between the private and public debt split is irrelevant. That is what I said—and you know perfectly well that that is what I said.

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Teague)—Senator Short, you will have an opportunity at the end of Senator Schacht's speech to say whatever you wish. There is no point of order.

TALK.START.PARA: —I also want to point out to the Senate that service costs as a proportion of total exports for servicing our debt have fallen from 20.6 per cent in June 1990 to 11.4 per cent in March 1995. Over a five-year period we have halved the service costs as a proportion of exports. This is a significant improvement. The main reason is that our policy of encouraging our manufacturing and service industries to grow their exports has meant that we are in a better position to service the debt. That has not been acknowledged often enough by senators opposite. Government and industry policy, through the Working Nation statement in particular, is to encourage our SMEs—our small- to medium-sized enterprises with between 15 and 25,000 employees and which are not exporting at the moment—to get into exports to further grow the real value-added exports that help our Australian economy.

PARA.TAB: Senator Kernot in her remarks mentioned household debt. Certainly household debt has increased since 1983 but, again, this fact has to be kept in balance. People should not get carried away by a fear campaign that the country is going broke. While we acknowledge that household indebtedness has increased in Australia, we realise it has been at a much more moderate pace than that in other countries. Household debt in Australia is much lower than in countries such as the United States, the United Kingdom, Japan and Canada. They are a reasonably good cross-section of OECD economies that people often like to compare us with. When we compare ourselves with them, we find our household debt level is lower. So before people start on fear campaigns, saying that this country is overwhelmingly swimming in debt, let us do a comparison with most of our OECD partners and see we are doing quite well. We do not run away from the current account deficit problem. We have addressed it in the long term by improving the savings pool through superannuation structural changes.

TALK.START.PARA: —Forty years! What are we going to do now?
—We are doing it now. Since we have been in office the superannuation pool has increased from something like $30 billion to nearly $200 billion.(Time expired)
—Good speech, Schachtie.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —You've got to be joking! The coalition will be supporting the Australian Democrats urgency motion but, as it will probably be clear from the debate, for many reasons different from those stated by the Democrats in terms of their presentation of the matter of urgency, namely:

SPEECH.PARA: The necessity for the Government to address the growing impact on the current account deficit of the growth of consumption imports largely funded by the increase in household debt, and the need for the Government to review its inadequate industry, trade and banking policies to prevent recurring balance of payments crises.

We agree with much of the wording, but for reasons different from those proposed by the Democrats policy spokesman. The whole policy of the Democrats is a policy of protecting or cotton woolling the Australian economy from international competition, from higher and higher taxes and higher and higher spending. Indeed, it is compounding the very problems with which they profess to be concerned.

PARA.TAB: We certainly fully endorse the calls for the government to take action on the horrific state of the current account deficit in our external accounts. For a long time now we have been calling on the government to address this problem. It is a problem which is getting worse and which has been chronic throughout the periods of the Hawke and Keating governments and which is due, essentially, to the policy mismanagement of the government. We have been calling on the government to address both the macro- and micro-economic deficiencies in their policies that have led to the situation we find ourselves in today, where Australia's current account deficit is the highest in the developed world.

To repeat, our debt is worse than Mexico's. We used to joke about the state of affairs of the external accounts of the Mexicos of this world. This year, Mexico's current account deficit is forecast to fall to less than two per cent of GDP; and probably to move into surplus in the next two years. By comparison, our current account deficit is six per cent of GDP. Even on the government's own figures for 1995-96, it is going to fall by a minuscule one half of one per cent, to about 5 1/2 per cent of GDP.

I remind the Senate that it was that six per cent of GDP figure that prompted Paul Keating, the then Treasurer who, by his own admission, was pulling all the levers of economic policy in 1986, to say that a country with a current account deficit of that magnitude was well down the so-called Argentinean road. The Argentinas and the Mexicos of this world have absolutely put us to shame in that respect. The tragedy is that, despite all the hardship that the Australian people have gone through over the last decade to attempt ostensibly to correct our balance of payments problem, we have a bigger problem today. I believe that it is a more intractable problem and that it is more difficult to solve than it was at the time Treasurer Keating made those remarks almost a decade ago.

This is the third year—1994-95—in 12 years of Labor that we have had a current account deficit of six per cent or thereabouts of GDP. We had it in 1985-86 and 1989-90. You might also recall, Mr Acting Deputy President, that it was that current account deficit in 1989-90, particularly with the huge growth in expenditure relative to the growth of production in our economy, that caused the government to engineer the recession which started towards the middle or end of 1990.

Despite all those mismeasures that have been taken, we now find ourselves in exactly the same position in terms of the arithmetic of the balance of payments deficit that we were in then. As I say, it is now a more intractable problem in terms of the resolution of those difficulties. The reason for that is the failure of the government to take the policies that are necessary to release the potential in the Australian economy through its people, resources, skills and talents, and its place in this region of the world, which is the highest growth region of the world, to allow us to capitalise and realise our tremendous potential.

Instead of a healthy balance of payments situation, which we certainly should have, we have now just racked up in the last 12 months the 11th current account deficit of more than $2 billion. That is an obscene figure. If people suggested five years ago that we would have deficits of that order, they would have been laughed out of court. Yet we now have the situation where the media in Australia, some of the financial markets and certainly the government are saying, `Isn't it great if the deficit falls from $2.9 billion, the greatest level ever recorded in Australia'—as was the case in May—`to about $2.5 billion', which is the second largest figure ever recorded.' We went from the greatest figure ever recorded to the second greatest figure ever recorded, yet the government, through the Treasurer, the Prime Minister and others, has said that things are on the improve. Nothing could be further from the truth.

All these current account deficits have left us, as the Minister for Small Business, Customs and Construction (Senator Schacht) acknowledged, with a net foreign debt of almost $170,000 million. That is almost $10,000 for every man, woman and child in this country. That compares with a figure of $23,000 million when this government took office in 1983—in other words, the present figure is seven times higher. The greatest loss that Australia incurs as a result of that increase in foreign debt is a loss of its economic independence and sovereignty.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about your mate Elliott? Why don't you tell us about him? The former President of the Liberal Party.

—Senator Murphy will have a chance in a minute. Why doesn't he just shut up and listen. Senator Murphy can have his go in a minute. The fact is that we now have a level of foreign debt that is seven times higher than it was 12 years ago.

PARA.TAB: The Democrat motion does not go far enough. It should call on the government to address some of the more obvious and overdue areas of reform which are essential to addressing the current account deficit problem, such as industrial relations reform and continued micro-economic reform. In his speech today Senator Schacht talked about the car industry and its potential. That industry has great potential.

The head of Toyota said on the Business Sunday program last weekend that the industry itself will continue to languish unless the federal government can deliver micro-economic reform in the areas of labour, electricity costs and freight costs. The necessary micro-economic reforms could boost the local industry to about 700,000 units per year and create thousands and thousands of additional jobs. What the government has done by its failure to address these basic issues is to increase unemployment to a staggeringly high continuing level, to restrain growth in Australia, to smash savings, to inhibit investment and, through that, to impose long-term structural problems which this country will have the greatest of difficulty in solving unless urgent, immediate changes are made to the whole stance of policy making in this country.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Greens (WA) support the motion before us. Economic or capital transfers remain a huge problem because of the flow of money offshore as interest payments, the repatriation of profits and assets and investment subsequently reinvested overseas. But we are seeing a growing imbalance between imports and exports. This is driven by the increase in consumer imports. These are two sides to the same coin.

PARA.TAB: The consumer issue results from a failure to address the need for a viable domestic economy. There is almost exclusive concentration on the export economy, but we import what we do not make ourselves. The impetus for developing a diverse and higher value export sector often comes from the development of industries for the domestic market.

The problem has been exacerbated by the pre-emptive reduction of tariffs and trade barriers and a willingness to sacrifice industries at the altar of free trade. Our industries are now competing in an international arena in which many of their competitors are heavily subsidised and can depend on other governments to use non-financial power to secure deals, and where other nations rigidly protect their own domestic economic interests. Japan and the United States are both notorious for such practices, while most developing nations retain high tariff barriers and actively support the development of their domestic industry.

Economic fundamentalists believe that the only way we can advance is to encourage transnational corporations to invest here through tax minimisation, facilitation and sometimes direct subsidies to get or keep them here. We had the massive Kodak payout a few years ago to encourage them to stay and we have the continuing obscenity of subsidised power to Alcoa, an aluminium company of America, yet we are very virtuous about making sure that we do not support our own businesses.

I do not suggest that we should be subsidising domestic industry. However, subsiding foreign industry while letting the domestic industry die is surely stupid. I also realise that, under the World Trade Organisation rules, our actions may be irreversible. But we should reconsider reducing them any further until we see other nations bring them down to equivalent levels. There are many options for industry development and the support of industries other than subsidy or tariff barriers.

One impact of this failure is that we are increasingly dependent on imports for all our normal consumer goods: clothes, appliances, hardware and tools, as well as most of our high-tech electronic goods, manufacturing equipment and many of our secondary materials, including steel. With the takeover of most of the remaining Australian brands in the food industry by Nestle, we can now expect that the profits of this industry will almost totally flow overseas. Investment and sourcing decisions in this global company will not take Australian interests into account. The push for an export food industry to Asia may see goods labelled `Birdseye' or `Edgell' sourced in Canada, the Philippines, New Zealand or other nations where Nestle has a hold.

As the drive for competitive advantage in attracting transnational capital rises, the pressure to increase productivity will rise. This is often a euphemism for wage reduction, work intensification or massive retrenchments. We are seeing this pressure now in wage restraint, the push for enterprise bargaining and the general erosion of union power.

The gulf between rich and poor increases. The government claims the welfare net is better, but a means-tested handout to compensate for lack of real wages is not real equity. More and more people are belonging to the working poor. As price becomes more important, people are pushed more and more to buy the cheapest option, usually an import. They are more dependent on loans to cover wage shortfalls. Historically, the evidence shows that savings does not lead to a good balance of payments figure. It is actually the other way around. When the economy is doing well, when people have money, they save. When people are hard-pressed, they do not save—they borrow.

Government has devastated the Australian domestic economy, and it will become much worse as the competition reforms begin to bite. We can see in Victoria that it is simply a formula for allowing the takeover of government utilities by foreign companies, even if those foreign companies are foreign government utilities. We also see the continued support of free trade which leads to further destruction of our ability to control or affect our economy.

The most recent assault is the United States attack on the Foreign Investment Review Board, an ironic attack given the record of the Foreign Investment Review Board. The Greens have been calling for some time for an abandonment of the export market transnational corporation orientation of government. We have been calling for a refocus on the domestic economy and the development of industry, trade and investment policy. It is time we realised that the purpose of national government is to look after the real wellbeing of the people in our nation, not to serve an ideology that says the only way we can get ahead is to sacrifice ordinary people in the interests of corporate profits. What is good for General Motors is not necessarily what is good for Australia.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Murphy Sen S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I find this a very interesting urgency motion. I will read it out again. It states:

SPEECH.PARA: The necessity for the government to address the growing impact on the current account deficit of the growth of consumption imports largely funded by the increase in household debt, and the need for the government to review its inadequate industry, trade and banking policies to prevent recurring balance of payments crises.
When Senator Kernot started out, I did not hear her deal with anything in respect of industry—

PARA.TAB: Senator Kernot interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Good, I will listen with great interest to Senator Spindler. Senator Kernot said that we ought to somehow invent a stronger commitment to national savings to make it more attractive to save and, if I understood her correctly, that tax concessions in terms of superannuation ought to be better directed. They were Senator Kernot's ideas on behalf of the Australian Democrats.
—There are more.

—I am pleased. I hope that you do identify some more because there was not much in that lot. The reality is, Senator Kernot, that you are saying to the Australian people that they can have a job but they cannot spend any money.
—No, I did not say that.

—If you are not saying that, I do not know what you are saying. I am at a loss to understand where you are coming from. If you say that you want people to save, I think you would acknowledge that we are not a nation of compulsive savers. You should stand up and tell the government how you will make people save their money because, right now, people like to spend their money.

PARA.TAB: This government has created a significant number of jobs. It has restructured this economy like it has never been restructured before and brought in a number of changes. Of course, what we get from the opposition is the usual stuff. They never tell us anything about what they are going to do. They criticise, criticise, criticise. So I thought, `Okay, if we are on about criticism, we ought to be doing a bit of comparison.' When Mr Howard, the now leader of the Liberal Party, was Treasurer when the conservatives were in government—

TALK.START.PARA: —Oh, look out!

—This is very important, Senator Panizza. Let us look at economic growth. During the Howard years as Treasurer, economic growth was 2.6 per cent; under Labor, 3.4 per cent. Inflation under Howard was 9.8 per cent; under Labor, 5.3 per cent, and down to 2.3 per cent since June. When Howard left, the rate of inflation was 11.4 per cent—

—Mr Acting Deputy President, I take a point of order: the senator has continually referred to the Leader of the Opposition by his surname. He has done so on about five occasions in 10 seconds. I would like you to call him to order to observe proper parliamentary procedure.

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Teague)—Senator Troeth, that is a correct point of order. Senator Murphy on one occasion referred to the Leader of the Opposition as Mr Howard. I ask him to refer to Mr Howard in all of his references.

TALK.START.PARA: —I apologise, Mr Acting Deputy President. Under Mr Howard as Treasurer in the conservative government the average number of jobs created during his term was 51,300; we have created 164,600 jobs.

PARA.TAB: Senator Kernot, that is the problem when you are talking about the development of the current account deficit. We have got 670,000 people who now have a job. We have got the highest participation rate that we have ever had in this country. You cannot deny the people the right to go and buy a home. But how do they go and buy that home? They go and borrow money. That is the reality—you probably do the same. But if you are going to expect a government to come down and say, `Bang, here's your pay packet but don't spend any of it,' that is a ridiculous suggestion.

TALK.START.PARA: —Nobody is saying that.

—I do not know what you are suggesting if you are not suggesting that. I would just like to read very quickly from a speech made by the Treasurer (Mr Willis). He said, `The opening up of the economy to competitive pressures, both internationally and externally, has compelled our businesses to become much more competitive.' That is true. We have introduced an economy that has become competitive and that has looked out to the world. We are now in a different world in terms of trade, and we have an economy that is sound. In terms of servicing our current account deficit, it is important to note that our capacity to service the debt has much improved. (Time expired)

—At this stage I think it might be just as well to remind Senator Murphy, and others in the chamber, just how bad the current account crisis is. We are now going into the eighth month where the deficit is going to be in excess of $2 billion. But that is not all: what is actually happening is that we are proportionately importing more and exporting less. Some six months ago, the gap between imports and exports was at an annual level of about $35 billion; it is now over $40 billion. So we are actually going backwards.

PARA.TAB: All your industry policies—which are non-existent, Senator Murphy—have not done a thing. It is very convenient for the government and for the opposition to say that we are a high protection party. That may be fine if it were true, but it is not. What we are saying is that the protective measures that have protected our industry—the quotas and the tariffs—have been reduced too far and too quickly. We have taken no account of what our trading partners are doing but have simply said to the world, `We'll open ourselves up, please come in and sell us cheap socks and cheap jumpers.' Never mind if our TCF industries go down the drain; never mind if our car industry is now endangered by the Proton from Korea. Korea still has car tariffs of 37 per cent. We have got them down to 27 per cent and they will be going down to 25 per cent. Another country that is going to import cars to us is India that has got car tariffs ranging up to 300 per cent. We are being the good guys. We are saying, `Bring in the cars. Never mind that we still have 850,000 unemployed Australian workers.' Senator Murphy, have you considered that?

TALK.START.PARA: —Why don't you tell us how you will pay for it?

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Teague)—Order! Senator Spindler, I ask that you direct your remarks through the chair and not to individual senators. That will lead to fewer interjections.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will be happy to do so, Mr Acting Deputy President. The fact that some little time ago the industry spokesperson for the coalition, Mr John Moore, called for a slowing down of tariff cuts—in fact, even a temporary freeze of tariff cuts—indicates that even the opposition is becoming a bit uncomfortable about the free trade policies that so far they have supported. But let us face the facts. Mr Moore was very quickly pulled back, and the opposition is back again supporting the government in its free trade policies. So Senator Murphy can rest assured he is well supported in how the government treats our workers and jeopardises our jobs—the fact that we have still got 850,000 unemployed shows that. He can rest assured that he has got the full support of the opposition in what the government is doing.

PARA.TAB: Now let me offer him some solutions. We are suggesting that in the trade area we should freeze tariff cuts temporarily until the others catch up. We should have a quid pro quo—reciprocity—with our trading partners. We should have bilateral agreements. We should say to them, `We will not reduce our protection any further, unless you follow suit and unless you allow us to export into your countries.'

We should have tougher import quality controls. Not so very long ago we had five inspectors for all Australian ports inspecting food imports. I understand that has now risen to about double. Big deal! How much quality control can they have? Have a look at our dumping measures. Have a look at how long it takes and how much it costs for an Australian enterprise and for an Australian industry to get some protection against the cheap dumping they are faced with.

What about your better labelling legislation that should show Australians whether a particular product has been made of Australian product by Australians and by Australian owned companies? Where is that legislation? The government has not provided it. In industry development, we are suggesting—(Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macdonald Sen S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to start by making three fundamental points. Firstly, Australia's current account deficit is fundamentally and structurally too high and, as a percentage of GDP, I understand, it is currently the highest in the Western world. No economist or commentator sees that as sustainable. It is caused by a lack of savings, both public savings, despite the shonky 1995-96 federal budget balance, and private savings, which basically revolve around a lack of after-tax savings to provide an environment for investment. In addition to that, there are these road blocks on our productivity which make import replacement unattainable and real pie-in-the-sky objectives. We wait in vain to see the J-curve working and we have heard a lot about it for a number of years.

PARA.TAB: The second fundamental point is that, because the current account deficit is too high, when we have a real crisis like the continuing drought where we have seen wheat exports halved, grain imported, wool exports substantially reduced, and beef and lamb exports under pressure, the only avenue for escape is to go further into hock because we cannot pay our way. I want to make the point that at the moment about 60 per cent of New South Wales and 40 per cent of Queensland—an area at least twice as big as the state of Victoria—remain critically drought declared, with many farmers facing their fifth consecutive year of drought and crop failure.

Despite this, we had the Minister for Trade, Senator McMullan, last week predicting an extra $2 billion in wheat export earnings between November and February, basing his confidence largely on what he described as `the breaking of the drought' on ABC radio on 16 August. It is glaringly obvious to me that this government has no concept at all of the grave outlook facing Australian farmers, farming families and farming enterprises. In every sense we are looking down the barrel of a national disaster of which this government—or any government ever in Australia's history—is totally unaware.

The third fundamental point is that our economy has not been structurally reformed to be able to cope with the five minutes of economic sunlight experienced after the recession. We have had a number of quarters of economic growth, but meeting demand for consumer goods has meant that the current account deficit has been increased by these imports. So the present current account crisis is based on the underlying structural problems of the economy, on a consumer debt push which is continuing and on our inability to export through particularly difficult seasonal conditions. I think that those points need to be made.

This Labor government has had 13 years to get the economy right. It keeps telling us, `Everything is fine. Don't worry about the current account deficit. Don't worry about our past performance of high interest rates and unemployment; just continue to trust us.' I want to take a brief look at past budgets and at comments made by the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) with respect to economic management, the current account and the level of our foreign debt.

If we go back to 1983, in the budget of that year Mr Keating said, `1983-84 holds the promise of a considerable improvement in economic performance.' At that stage our foreign debt stood at $23 billion. In the 1984 budget, he said:

SPEECH.PARA: Tonight I am proud to be able to tell the Australian people that we now have strong economic growth, many more jobs, a substantial fall in inflation and declining interest rates. The government's policies are on track.

Foreign debt stood at $28 billion. In the 1986 budget, he said, `The 1986-87 budget, which I have presented tonight, rings the changes on a more robust, aggressive Australian economy.' He was entitled to his view but the foreign debt spiralled to $75 billion. In the 1990 budget, he said:

This year, inflation will fall further, the current account deficit will markedly improve and employment will pick up . . . (all) delivered without the misery and despair of high unemployment and a savage recession.
Foreign debt rose to $124 billion, and so it goes on.

PARA.TAB: Then we have the Prime Minister's specific comments on the current account deficit. In 1986 he said—and this is the famous banana republic quote:

SPEECH.PARA: Australia is so undisciplined, so disinterested in its salvation, in its economic well being, that it doesn't deal with this fundamental problem . . . The only thing to do is to slow down growth to a canter . . . Then you are gone—you are a Banana Republic.
Later, in March 1991, he said:
The current account deficit . . . remains Australia's most pressing pressure. I think you have to be quite clear about that.
Later in the same month in 1991, he said:
The worst is now behind us. The government established the strategy to deal with the current account deficit and inflation and has stuck to it and is succeeding.

The foreign debt at that stage was $130 billion. In February 1992, he was quoted as saying, `Labor's plan for the next four years will create 800,000 new jobs without increasing the current account deficit.' Foreign debt at that stage was $140 billion. Recently, in July of this year, Mr Keating said:
. . . as the economy gets back to a sustainable rate of growth, so too will we see a subside in the current account deficit. In other words, we have got the position covered.
Again he is entitled to his view, but foreign debt now is at $170 billion-plus.

PARA.TAB: The Australian people are not so stupid as to continue to believe this diatribe of rhetoric and slick phrases. They know that Labor's strategy has faltered. They know that Labor has run out of ideas. They know that Labor has failed to control the foreign debt. They know that Labor has failed on every count and debased Australia's economic debate. Make no bones about it, Senator Murphy, you have debased the economic debate and, unfortunately, all politicians suffer as a result of what the Prime Minister has said.

We are now recording the worst current account deficit in our nation's history. Australia's accrued deficit of $2.9 billion in May works out at about $4 million per hour. In June the current account was $2.3 billion, which was seasonally adjusted. So we had a current account deficit in 1994-95 of $26 billion and we have a projected forecast in the budget for 1995-96 at $27 billion.
Australia's current account is currently running at between five and six per cent of GDP. Bernie Fraser has indicated that a current account of this magnitude is not sustainable. I quote him:

SPEECH.PARA: I believe there is a case for accepting an on-going deficit of modest proportions, but it is more likely to be 3 per cent of GDP, rather than 4 or 5 per cent.

He said that on 29 November last year. The government has sought to restore national savings through a longer term superannuation strategy and increased public savings. The strategy is a longer term one which will leave the current account very high in the next few years, and hence the economy vulnerable to adverse overseas developments and adverse domestic developments like the present drought.

PARA.TAB: The budget strategy is partly smoke and mirrors, as I have mentioned, because asset sales and promises of keeping to the forward estimates of spending has been something that this Labor government has consistently failed to project accurately. Vince FitzGerald, in his national savings report, has identified the lack of public saving as the main cause of our structural decline in national savings. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: While both public and private saving have fallen, the major structural decline is in public sector saving.

The Prime Minister, as one of his major diversions from high unemployment and economic disintegration, has concentrated on our need to change our constitutional make-up. His preoccupation has been couched in the language of national pride and independence and how to cut off our shackles of the past. Simply put, Mr Keating, we have a much greater threat to our independence from the crisis in our current account and the similar and connected foreign debt than from our constitutional make-up. If Australia were a company, the receivers would have the cheque book. There is a much greater threat to Australia from the potential intervention of the head of the International Monetary Fund than who is our head of state.

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply—The gist of Senator Schacht's argument was that the current account deficit is self-managing. We say to that: at what economic cost? At the cost of the loss of economic independence and the selling off what is left of the farm. It will probably get up to the army, ultimately. His second argument was, `We are doing something about savings. We have the got superannuation guarantee charge.' Yes, we have and yes, the Democrats voted for it, but it will not realise any addition to savings that is worth mentioning until the year 2035. In the meantime, it will cost in terms of disposable income for low income earners and it will cost in the way in which it is regressively subsidised, and the government is regressively subsidising superannuation tax concessions which flow through to high income earners. So, savings for whom, Senator Murphy?

PARA.TAB: Another point Senator Schacht made is that debt is overwhelmingly private sector debt. We agree. He says it is serviceable. Why, then, has the number of people who have fallen behind on their mortgage payments jumped by nearly 40 per cent in the last four months? As a measure of serviceability, through you, Mr Acting Deputy President, I draw that to Senator Schacht's attention.
Senator Murphy pointed with some pride to the creation of, I think he said, 146,000 jobs.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are delighted to see 164,000 jobs created, but let us not forget that this restructuring cost one million Australians their jobs on the way through. Let us not crow too much about 164,000 and conveniently ignore the immediate past. The fact is that government policy encourages a debt culture. Government policy has led to lax taxation treatment of debt finance. The Government's failure to influence the banking industry in this country has led to the spend now, pay later mentality encouraged by bank advertising and easy—very easy, ridiculously easy—access to home equity loans.

PARA.TAB: The opposition's arguments, such as they were, were that the government has failed to release the potential of this economy—

TALK.START.PARA: —But what would you do about that?

—I am coming to that—through people and resources. When pressed, Senator Schacht added, `We need greater industrial relations reform and more micro-economic reform.' The same old thing we have heard before!

PARA.TAB: The opposition voted against the introduction of the superannuation guarantee charge but they have, as yet, failed to tell us what they would do to introduce a short, medium and long-term national savings plan for this country. Yes, they are on about smaller and smaller government, but what would they do about private sector debt? Their attitude to the banking industry comes down to supporting a reduction in competition by an increased number of mergers. Senator Murphy says, `Well, what are your answers?' Senator Spindler did not get a chance to finish some of his, so I will do that.

In the area of industry development, try this for size, Senator Murphy, through you, Mr Acting Deputy President. Tax incentives for productive investment but to be granted only if agreed performance targets are met; a higher priority on research and development, including increased funding for the CSIRO, increased funding for university research and discretionary R&D grants; increased funding for all levels of education as Australia now ranks 13 out of 16 OECD countries in education spending as a percentage of GDP; more effective foreign investment rules to ensure that any foreign investment is of real development benefit to Australia and to discourage the sale of mature Australian companies; tax penalties for superannuation funds which invest offshore rather than meeting the capital demand which will be created by the investment allowance which we proposed above; and the establishment of a venture and development capital finance corporation aimed at supporting small and medium businesses.

Current account deficits are not intrinsically bad except when they get too high. Forty years ago our current account deficit averaged about 2.5 per cent of GDP; last financial year it was six per cent of GDP. If we add to that the fact that a much higher proportion of the current account deficit is being financed by borrowings from foreigners and that they become more anxious about lending to us as our debt rises, therefore they charge us higher interest rates, we know we have an urgent problem. We have to produce more and consume less. We have to save more so that we can finance from our own savings a higher proportion of own economic development.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The time for the debate has expired.

PARA.TAB: Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bell Sen R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the document.

SPEECH.PARA: This is an extremely important report consisting of 390-odd pages. Enterprise Bargaining in Australia—Annual Report 1994 is the report which the government was required to compile as a result of section 170RC of the Industrial Relations Act as drafted by the Australian Democrats. That section obliged the government to prepare this particular report. The merit of that particular section of the Industrial Relations Act is demonstrated by the comprehensiveness of the report. I must congratulate the government on its methodology and comprehensiveness.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think we also deserve some acknowledgment, as Senator Kernot says. While I congratulate the government, the report itself reveals the sorts of concerns that were expressed, particularly by women who were representing other women in the work force who were not particularly advantaged by the concept of enterprise bargaining. In fact, we can see from the report that, although not exclusively, particularly women were not advantaged.

PARA.TAB: For example, I refer honourable senators to page 233 of the report. Table 5.19 shows the estimated wage increases in Part VIB wage agreements, by gender industry classification. When we look at the number of agreements in the gender industry classification, which in this chart are listed as female dominated—in other words, where 60 per cent or more of the work force is female—we see there were 22 agreements over the period that were surveyed and that there were 35,700 employees covered by such agreements.

When we look further down in the chart we see, in those industries which were classified as male dominated—where there were less than 40 per cent female employees—there were not 22 agreements reached but, rather, 625. There were 225,300 people covered compared with 35,700. I think that information speaks for itself. These agreements are more readily reached in male-dominated employment areas rather than female-dominated employment areas. I commend the report.

Those sorts of charts, diagrams and graphs are an extremely useful set of information, again demonstrating the value of monitoring the effects of government legislation after it has been passed. Far too often we are told by the Prime Minister and his ministers that some new reform will deliver the earth, the moon and the stars but, in the past, we really have not initiated or established monitoring practices to show whether in fact those things are delivered. Here we have the proof of what actually happens. We should perhaps see more of this type of report as we can use this sort of report to check on the initial hyperbole that is promoted by the government when it introduces things.

That is not to condemn this legislation. I do not want to be misunderstood and for it to be thought that that is what I am doing here. I am saying that the basis for any criticism can more easily be established when we have monitoring such as we have here. Instead of hyperbole, I wish more often we had the actual factual bases upon which we could make our criticisms. I want to be constructive in my criticisms. I appreciate the fact that, in the area of industrial relations and enterprise bargaining as it affects women in the workplace, I now have something upon which I can establish that constructive criticism. Without it we only have the assertion that some people will be better off than others under this new system.

Of course, this report enables us to make the judgment that enterprise bargaining is an imperfect vehicle for achieving a better economic and social balance between work and family responsibility because the report shows that fewer than half of the registered agreements have included family leave. That is a very poor take-up rate of the 1994 test case that Senator Kernot initiated.

We are able to see in objective, factual material that is presented here the rate at which those recommendations are taken up. So we see that it is far from perfect, that it does need more consideration by the employees and their representatives in unions, and also a greater effort by employers to understand that not all employees have the capacity to bargain, to negotiate on their own behalf; especially those employees who are in part-time work or are part of a greater proportion of people who do not have English as their first language, or who do not have the training-education in the areas of negotiation. Of course, we do have those industries and it is wrong to assume that all people have equal capacity to negotiate. The negotiation can be taken up and represented by trade union organisations or even other representatives. But in this report we have a demonstration that that is not necessarily taking place and that we should consider whether it is necessary to institute other protective measures.

The report also gives us the opportunity to see whether the people themselves are affected. I understand that 1,000-odd workplaces were surveyed and that that covered several thousand employees—I cannot remember the figure exactly, but it was something like 10,000. As part of that survey the employees themselves were asked whether they thought they were better off or not and whether they were satisfied with the system. That is the sort of monitoring that is probably even appropriate in other legislation—whether it had the effect that it was designed for or that the government led us to believe that it would have.

I again congratulate those responsible for undertaking the report itself. Of course I have not read the entire 390 pages yet, but I intend to use this as a piece of valuable reference to establish a basis upon which, as I said before, we can all make constructive criticism. I again say that it may yet give us an example of what we can use as a future monitoring tool on other legislation.

PROCTEXT.PARA: PRESIDENT'S REPORT TO THE SENATE ON GOVERNMENT RESPONSES OUTSTANDING TO PARLIAMENTARY COMMITTEE REPORTS AS AT 30 JUNE 1995

This document continues the practice of presenting to the Senate twice each year a schedule listing Government responses to Senate and joint committee reports as well as responses which remain outstanding.

The practice of presenting this schedule to the Senate follows the undertaking by successive governments to respond to parliamentary committee reports in timely fashion. On 26 May 1978 the Minister for Administrative Services (Senator Withers) informed the Senate that within six months of the tabling of a committee report, the responsible Minister would make a statement in the Parliament outlining the action the Government proposed to take in relation to the report. The period for responses was reduced from six months to three months in 1983 by the incoming government. The Leader of the Government in the Senate announced this change on 24 August 1983. The method of response continued to be by way of statement. Subsequently the Government has

advised that responses to committee reports will be made by letter to a committee chairman, with the letter being tabled in the Senate at the earliest opportunity. The date of the presentation of the Government's response to the Senate has been taken as the date that the response is presented, not the date of any correspondence with the committee.

Senate legislation committees are often required to report on the provisions of bills. Only those reports in this category that make recommendations and therefore require a response are listed in the schedule.

The schedule does not usually include reports of the Parliamentary Standing Committee on Public Works or the Senate Standing Committees on Appropriations and Staffing, Selection of Bills, Procedure, Publications, Regulations and Ordinances and Scrutiny of Bills, though such reports will be included if they require a response. Government responses to reports of the Public Works Committee are normally reflected in motions for the approval of works after the relevant report has been presented and considered. Responses to reports of the Joint Committee of Public Accounts are usually made in the form of Finance Minutes which are tabled by the committee. Where a response has been made by way of Finance Minute, the date of presentation has been appropriately annotated.

The Government has put in place a range of measures to implement the Committee's recommendation concerning training for senior officials in relation to the principles governing the operation of the Parliament, including issues of accountability and protection of witnesses before parliamentary committees.

The Public Service Commission (PSC) invites a representative of the Department of the Senate to address all Senior Executive Service (SES) orientation courses, which are conducted for newly appointed and promoted SES officers. Information about SES officers' responsibilities in relation to committees is also provided to new SES officers in the form of the Government Guidelines for Official Witnesses before Parliamentary Committees and the Department of the Senate publication, Protection of Witnesses before Senate Committees.

In addition, to inform all SES officers of the Committee's recommendation, the PSC published in one of its SES Newsletters an article, The Senior Executive Service and Parliament, prepared by Ms Anne Lynch, Deputy Clerk of the Senate and Secretary of the Committee of Privileges.

The recently revised Guidelines on Official Conduct of Commonwealth Public Servants, 8000 copies of which were distributed to departments and agencies, include information on the responsibility public servants have in providing information to the Parliament, and advises public servants appearing before parliamentary committees to prepare by reading the Government Guidelines for Official Witnesses referred to above. Those guidelines contain sections on parliamentary privilege and contempt of parliament, and deal explicitly with the protection afforded witnesses and potential witnesses.

All SES officers receive as well copies of PSC and Management Advisory Board/ Management Improvement Advisory Committee publications on the accountability of public servants for their actions. Finally, the PSC is organising a seminar for SES officers in late 1995 on issues related to accountability in the public service. The Department of the Senate will be invited to contribute to the seminar.
