That this bill be now read a second time.

TALK.START.PARA: —By agreement with the government I seek leave to continue my speech. I understand I made a three-minute speech on the last Thursday of the previous session. I was not present on the Friday and I was therefore overtaken. The government has kindly agreed that I can complete my speech—other senators may have a different view—and that Senator Ellison can then complete his speech. If Senator Ellison spoke now I would be interrupting his speech. It is a messy business for which I apologise, but it was unavoidable.

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Childs)—I believe Senator Ellison might require leave to continue his speech.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am seeking leave to continue my speech and Senator Ellison can follow me. That will get the mess out of the way.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate for granting leave. It was unfortunate that I was able to speak for only three minutes on this bill on the final Thursday of the last session. It was equally unfortunate to find that on the Friday, the last day of the session, the Attorney-General (Mr Lavarch) chose to issue a press release saying that the coalition and others here—by definition including the Australian Democrats and the Greens—were seeking to hold up the First Corporate Law Simplification Bill and had cost small businesses around Australia thousands of dollars and we were the demons to be hated because we had done this dreadful thing to small business.

PARA.TAB: There are two reasons why I was offended by that press release. Firstly, I do not believe that the bill ever got to the top of the list of bills that the government wanted dealt with during the last session. It was on the red, as so many things often are, and was expected to be dealt with at some stage. There would not be a senator in this chamber who has not come in here hour after hour, day after day, waiting for one matter or another to get on. I thought it was a bit rich for the Attorney-General to be complaining that one of the bills in his portfolio had not got through when the situation was that he did not have the capacity to convince his colleagues to put it higher in the agenda. Either the Attorney-General has such a low standing with his colleagues or this bill has such a low standing with them that they were not prepared to make the effort required to have the bill dealt with prior to the close of the last session.

It was a cheap shot when it was really the Attorney-General's fault that the matter was not put sufficiently high on the agenda. In the ordinary course of events on that Friday we would have only had about 17 or 18 minutes for debate on the bill. That is not sufficient time to allow the parliament to express its views on such an important bill. This bill has had wide consideration in the community. Representatives of the business community with whom I have had contact have nothing but praise for the process of the simplification task force and the efforts that have been made. By and large they have no complaints with the first draft.

I want to make it perfectly clear that there is no criticism of the simplification task force and the process that it has undertaken; save to say that parliamentary committees might have been included earlier in the discussion. The task force came up with what it thought was the perfect product and expected a quick tick from the parliament, but it might have been smarter for the task force to have included parliamentary committees earlier. The task force and those associated with it might see the situation as parliament holding things up—which I see as parliament doing its job—but the differences could have been thrashed out and the arguments aired before the bill came to the parliament. There are no other criticisms of the process. We are supportive of this first bill. We made that clear at the very beginning. The bill had a thorough airing at the Joint Standing Committee on Corporations and Securities.

A number of proposals were put before that committee. One particular proposal related to the small-large distinction. I will come back to that matter. I wanted to put into context that the Attorney-General's criticism of the bill not passing had nothing to do with us. At that point we were happy with the bill and it would have passed had it been higher on the agenda.

The second thing that was offensive about the Attorney-General's press release was this: at the time when the Attorney-General issued the press release—and at this day—he and the minister representing him in this chamber are in contempt of the Senate for failing to comply with a return to order. The Attorney-General is meant to have some understanding of the parliamentary system and some respect for it, but he has a cheek issuing a press release blaming other parties for bills not passing and expressing the view that the parliamentary process had been diminished when he, by his cavalier response to a return to order, was diminishing parliamentary process himself. He was seeking to place himself and the minister representing him here above the parliament. For those reasons I believe that the Attorney-General's press release was a cheap shot.

As is often the case, when you throw the first stone you find it comes to land in your own backyard. That is what has happened to the Attorney-General. In his press release he sought to make himself a champion of small business. What shockers were we for holding this up! Small business was going to be beating our doors down. We were going to be condemned around Australia. I believe he wrote to thousands of representatives of small business to promote himself, no doubt, and putting the view that I have just put to this chamber.

Since that press release the Attorney-General has been silent on this matter and has not publicly raised the fact that subsequent to the ending of the last parliamentary session he was contacted by the Motor Trades Association of Australia, the Australian Chamber of Commerce and Industry and the Victorian Employers Chamber of Commerce and Industry representing small businesses. Those associations were putting the view that there was a problem—an unintended consequence—which centred upon the small-large distinction. It was not an argument that we should move to a reporting entity concept; that argument had been thrashed out in the Joint Standing Committee on Corporations and Securities and I do not seek to rehash that argument here.

What was raised with the Attorney-General was the three criteria by which we establish whether a company is small or large, remembering the consequences that flow in relation to external auditors. As you may know, Mr Acting Deputy President, if you are covered by two of those three requirements you are deemed to be a large company. The associations suspect that it is an inadvertent and unintended consequence of the pitching of the levels of those three criteria and that a significant number of companies previously not thought to be affected by this legislation would be affected and that something should be done.

We can all raise our hands in the air and say, `Where have all these people been? Why didn't they come up earlier? Why didn't we understand this earlier?' I know we get carried away in this place and think that out there in Bob and Mary Stringbag land, where the electors are, they are focusing on every word in this place. Of course, they are not. It is the last thing they are remotely interested in. It does take time for people to come to realise how a bill under consideration will affect them.

The Attorney, who wanted to place himself as the champion of small business, went silent during the debate because small business was on his back telling him that something was wrong and that it needed to be fixed. The sad part of this story is that it has been put to me that the groups that approached the Attorney were led to believe that he was genuinely listening to the concerns they had and led to believe, by inference, that something was going to be done to fix their concerns.

That is why, at the bottom of the letter they sent to the Attorney, they said that they believed there should be bipartisan support for an amendment to the bill to fix this particular problem. I might add that they are not wanting to detract from the policy behind it or cause a significant delay. Those arguments have been held. They also said in the letter that because they think there should be bipartisan support for an amendment, they are going to send a copy of the submission they sent to the Attorney to us, to the Australian Democrats, to the Greens and to the Chairman of the Joint Committee on Corporations and Securities. I am told that they then received a rather heated call from a gentleman in the Attorney's office saying, `What the hell are you go doing that for? You do not have to notify these people. You just deal with us and we will listen to your concerns.' The inference that was created was that they will fix the problem.

I do not imagine that the Attorney wants to have companies classified as large companies that, in the ordinary course of events, people might agree ought not be. I do not attribute any bad faith to the Attorney about the pitching of the levels, but there has been a suggestion of some bad faith in dealing with these groups, in suggesting that their problem would be listened to and giving the impression that these levels would be looked at. For that reason, they say that they complied with the request or direction—phrase it as you will—not to send their submission to us because they thought in good faith they would deal with the government, only to find very recently that they have been told to go jump, that no change will be made.

They are not happy with that; they are not happy with that at all. I understand that the Attorney has done two things. In his own second reading speech he made the point—no-one could deny it; no-one seeks to deny it—that the pitching of these levels is somewhat arbitrary. It is necessary to exclude some people that others think should be included. If you are going to include people that others think should be excluded, you are always going to have an argument about it. Wherever you pitch those levels, someone is going to be unhappy. We understand that and he understands that. But he did make the point that the levels are arbitrary. He further made the point that the levels needed to be watched closely, because they are crucial to the impact this regulation has on the business community. The regulation is not designed—it should not be in its intention at all—to somehow drag the corporate community down. It is meant to be more efficient.

For that reason, the Attorney quite rightly acknowledged that he would look at these levels. That gave these people hope. When they wrote to him during the break and said that there was something wrong with the levels and they were told not to contact us but to deal with the Attorney's department, they thought they had an open ear and something was going to happen. They feel let down.

The second thing the Attorney has done—or his office, at least—is to indicate that these people might have some hope by virtue of exemptions from the ASC. They are not actually confident about that at all. They do not think that it is that easy to convince the commissioner to exercise that discretion. Circumstances might not be so exceptional. It might be just a plain matter of fact that we have pitched the levels wrong—and there is nothing exceptional about that; that people fall over the level is not in itself exceptional—and the ASC commissioner may not be able to offer the exemption. It is not that they are attributing, in that respect, bad faith to the Attorney or his office. It is just that what is being offered out might not be the appropriate solution. It may not be possible to make that work.

We now have the person who held himself out to be the champion of small business having the opportunity to, in a sense, display that that is true. If that is true, he will not mind, and the government will agree with, an amendment that we wish to move by way of a second reading amendment—that is, that the matter of the levels of those three criteria in the bill that distinguish small and large companies, and that matter alone, be referred to the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs for a short Friday hearing. That is the equivalent of what would have happened had this limited aspect of the bill been referred to that committee—a Friday committee. We would like this to happen so that these people get the opportunity to make their case that these levels are too high.

What we will seek to do is move a second reading amendment, which I will do now, that that is what happens. I notice that the Deputy Clerk is perhaps concerned about that proposal and may want to take some advice on the matter. There may be some other appropriate way to do this. We want to stress that we do not want to unnecessarily hold up the passage of this bill. We are supportive of the simplification process and supportive of the task force, and the arguments about small/large reporting entities have been held. We do not want to rehash those.

We share the Attorney's concern that the levels are pitched correctly, and we invite him to take this opportunity to ensure that they are set correctly now and to give these people an opportunity to be heard. As I understand it, that can be done relatively easily. If this is done, those people will have an opportunity to be heard.
The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Childs)—Senator Vanstone, I understand that at the end of the second reading debate the referral can then be moved.

TALK.START.PARA: —So I do not need to move that motion now?
—No. You do not want to hold the matter up.

—Yes, I want the second reading debate to be completed to give everybody an opportunity to speak in the second reading debate so that when we come back we can go straight into committee. I want to confirm for the government advisers that are here that the inquiry we are seeking we want restricted to just those points.

PARA.TAB: If the Attorney does not agree to this, if the government seeks to have a division and votes against this reference, then the small business community will know that the press release the Attorney was so quick to send out, the letters he was so quick to send out in support of small business, will show him to be something of a straw man in terms of standing up for small business.

We are not seeking a long delay, but we are seeking an opportunity for these people, who said that they were not aware of the consequences and did not have the opportunity before and that no-one sat down and worked out exactly which companies would and would not be included or excluded. We understand that the government has had advice about the 98 per cent and the two per cent. What we say is that that advice might now appear to be wrong and that perhaps there are some people who have inadvertently been dragged into this that the Attorney would not want to drag into it. They should have a chance to be heard.

On that note, I might conclude, although I might refer the Attorney's officers and others to the 31 July issue of the Business Review Weekly with the headline `The top 500 private companies'. It is in that edition of the Business Review Weekly that there is an article indicating just how harshly the bill, if it is passed in its present form with the levels set as they are, will affect car dealers. It is possible to have individual groups, for one reason or another, tossed into a pile that ordinarily we might not want them tossed into.

They go into that pile because of the very high value of their stocks and their turnover. But with the sort of people we are dealing with and the protections they might want, some people could make a case to say that not all of those companies that might fall into the large company grouping are the sorts of companies that we would want to fall into that grouping. That is the sort of matter that we want looked at. I thank the Senate again for giving me leave to complete my speech and giving Senator Ellison leave to follow me and complete his. I know that was messy. It was just an accident of timing at the end of the last session.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is debating the First Corporate Law Simplification Bill which deals with share buy-backs, proprietary companies and company registers. I welcome the fact that it has been drafted in plain English and also includes several features which are intended to assist the user of this bill dealing with the Corporations Law.

PARA.TAB: In the past, companies have been reluctant to use buy-back provisions because of their complexity. In fact, those provisions in the current law run to some 15,000 words in 89 sections. The bill will reduce this to 2,000 words in 11 sections. Therefore, it is substantially reduced and, I believe, a lot clearer and user friendly. The bill includes safeguards for shareholders and directors in the share buy-back. Directors become personally liable if a buy-back makes a company insolvent. A liquidator may also be able to recover damages from the selling shareholders if a buy-back causes the company to become insolvent.

In relation to proprietary companies, the bill makes several changes to the existing law. The distinction between exempt proprietary and non-exempt proprietary companies is removed. The practical effect of this change is to eliminate the current requirement on small companies to prepare financial reports for filing with the Australian Securities Commission, data which has been proved to be of very limited value.

The bill also contains a new distinction between small and large proprietary companies based on a company's gross operating revenue, assets and number of employees. Like Senator Vanstone, I have received some representations from various organisations, in particular the Motor Trades Association, claiming that the levels for the criteria in these areas have been struck in such a way as to disadvantage a particular range and type of company.

My attention has only just been drawn to these matters and I am not able to say whether we support the claims. However, we do support the idea that we take another look. So often we hurriedly pass legislation in this place only to find that amendments are necessary at a later stage. The Democrats will be supporting the motion to refer this limited aspect of the bill for a quick assessment by the Senate Legal and Constitutional Legislation Committee.

The bill also reduces the minimum number of members and directors of a proprietary company from two to one. Many people may see this as a somewhat revolutionary change. The change, it is said, overcomes the problem with directors who are, in reality, silent directors, who are recruited by the active director to fulfil the current technical requirements of the law, but who have no effective involvement in company management. The Democrats will not be opposing this provision, but I want to raise the concern that if the director is silent there is nevertheless a second person who is responsible for the affairs of the company who may be held liable in the event that creditors or shareholders are disadvantaged by the management of the company.

The second point I would like to make is that this sits somewhat oddly with the government's concern in the taxation area where single traders incorporate themselves to benefit from the considerably lower company tax rate. It seems to me that this provision will make it easier for people to take that route and thereby avoid tax. It may be advisable for the minister to address that particular point when responding to the issues raised in the second reading debate. It seems to me that this contravenes the concerns in this area that, from time to time, have been expressed by the taxation commissioner.

The other point worth mentioning is that the number of registers will be reduced. The Corporations Law currently requires companies to keep eight separate registers. They are registers of: members; option holders; debenture holders; directors, principal executive officers and secretaries; directors' shareholdings; substantial shareholders in listed companies; notices of beneficial ownership in listed companies; and share buy-backs. The bill changes that and reduces it to three registers containing information on members, option holders and debenture holders.

It is claimed by the government that the other information that has been contained in these various other registers can be obtained more readily from the Stock Exchange or from the Securities Commission. That may well be so. I would suggest that there is an implied obligation on the government to provide easy access to this information and to make information available to people in the commercial world—in particular to small businesses who cannot be expected to have at their finger tips all the provisions of the Corporations Law, where that information is available and what they need to do to access it.

Subject to these comments, the Democrats welcome this bill. It is an important step forward in simplifying the Corporations Law which is notoriously a very complicated area of the law and one that is still difficult to access. We, however, point out that we must ensure that the safeguards are not sacrificed for ease of operation and that the effects of this bill on shareholders and creditors be considered. The Democrats certainly intend to monitor how this bill governs our commercial dealings after its passage through this parliament.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ellison Sen C.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The First Corporate Law Simplification Bill represents the first stage of the government's approach to simplifying the laws as they deal with corporations. In particular, this bill seeks to simplify various provisions of the Corporations Law relating to share buy-backs, proprietary companies and company registers. It is useful to look at the report of the Joint Committee on Corporations and Securities which had this bill referred to it. A number of issues were raised during the course of the committee's inquiry, one of which being the new definitions of small and large companies. It is to that that I turn my attention in my speech tonight. Proposed section 45A(2) defines a small proprietary company as a small proprietary company:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . if it satisfies at least 2 of the following paragraphs:
(a) the consolidated gross operating revenue for the financial year of the company and the entities it controls (if any) is less than $10 million
(b) the value of the consolidated gross assets at the end of the financial year of the company and the entities it controls (if any) is less than $5 million
(c) the company and the entities it controls (if any) have fewer than 50 employees at the end of the financial year.

The definition of a large company is the reciprocal of that. So you look to see whether the company has in excess of $10 million operating revenue, whether it has gross assets at the end of the financial year of more than $5 million, and whether it controls more than 50 employees at the end of the financial year.

PARA.TAB: The differences between a small company and a large company are important. A small company, by virtue of the bill, has a less onerous obligation to provide financial details and accounting records. A large company does have that requirement. There is a provision whereby the ASC can exempt a large company from having to fulfil those obligations. It is an exemption I would submit with respect to the Senate that would only be exercised sparingly and where the public interest was involved. I do not think it is a situation where that exemption would be exercised merely to save a company money.

Comments have been made by both Senator Vanstone and Senator Spindler that, since this matter was last before the Senate on 30 June this year, there has been some community concern about this aspect of the bill. In particular, I refer to a media statement put out by the Australian Chamber of Commerce and Industry and the Motor Trades Association yesterday which expressed concern that there would be companies caught by the definition of a large company and that, as a result, those companies would be facing extra costs of $25,000 to $45,000 a year by way of auditing and legal fees. That was of great concern to those peak bodies. In fact, it was the Motor Trades Association which put it more simply by stating that some car dealers might have to sell 40 to 50 more cars a year in order to meet those extra costs.

Although those concerns were not squarely before the Joint Committee on Corporations and Securities when it considered this matter, there were submissions before that committee which did give rise to some of these matters but perhaps not as vividly as the ones I have just referred to. The committee in fact recommended that the bill be passed, but it did state that it was unable to reach an unqualified view on the test which draws a distinction between small and large proprietary companies. It suggested that the Attorney-General could consider two options: firstly, leave the criteria as is of 50 employees only; or, secondly, delete the criteria relating to employees and replace it with a test of only proposed assets and turnover.

More recently there has been mention of the possible problems this definition could give rise to, which was raised by Mr Penman in the Age. I refer to an article in the Age dated 7 August 1995 where he warned small business:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . it would be a sensible precaution for small businesses close to the threshold to keep reasonably accurate figures in case they unexpectedly exceeded two of the three criteria and needed to prepare audited statements.
At the moment you have to satisfy only two of the three criteria. It may be that a business is operating close to that threshold and could well qualify by the end of the financial year.

PARA.TAB: In that article, Mr Penman was reported as saying that this might not result in less bureaucratic red tape for small business. In any event, I would point out to the Senate that there is a common law duty cast upon directors of companies and that to facilitate and carry out those duties an adequate keeping of records and accounts is required.
I do believe that this bill does have some good aspects. I support the call for this particular aspect of the bill to go to the Senate Legal and Constitutional Affairs Legislation Committee.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Minister for Human Services and Health

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to address the Dr Lawrence saga and the duplicity of the Australian Labor Party in handling this matter. It should be remembered by all Australians that the genesis of the royal commission that is currently being conducted in Western Australia is as a result of Dr Lawrence's own personal activities in seeking to deliver a body blow to the then Leader of the Opposition in Western Australia, Mr Richard Court. That of course failed and history will tell us that Mr Court became Premier and Dr Lawrence was defeated. However, the tactic employed by Dr Lawrence has now gone full circle; it has come back to haunt her. I am sure that ultimately her activities in the Easton matter will deliver a body blow to her political career.

PARA.TAB: The matter I wish to address is the way that the Australian Labor Party, through the taxpayers, are funding all of Dr Lawrence's legal fees. At the outset let me say that I believe a very sustainable argument can be made out requiring governments establishing royal commissions to fund the legal representation for those whose activities will come under close scrutiny. However, the Dr Lawrence situation arises out of her activities as a state Premier not as the Minister for Human Services and Health in the federal government. Therefore, no Commonwealth funding ought be provided. If any funding ought be provided, it ought be provided through Western Australia.

The Labor Party argues that the royal commission was only set up because Dr Lawrence is a minister in a federal government. Clearly that is unsustainable. The situation is that the inquiry has been set up because of her activities as the former Premier of Western Australia. Even if we were to accept what the Labor Party are trying to peddle, it is not a case for justifying the funding.

In my own home state of Tasmania, the Australian Labor Party set up a royal commission to inquire into the activities of a former premier, Robin Gray. One could argue that the only reason he was pursued through a royal commission was that of his status as leader of the Liberal opposition. I note with some interest that the Australian Labor Party on the state basis did not want to fund Mr Gray's legal costs. Also of interest is the fact that the federal Labor Party did not come running with taxpayers' money from the Commonwealth taxpayer willing to fund Mr Gray because somehow he was a target of a royal commission which was as politically engineered as the Labor Party would now have us believe. Indeed, the exact opposite occurred. The then Minister for Justice, Senator Michael Tate, claimed it was an obscenity that the taxpayers of Tasmania were funding people's legal costs who were appearing before the royal commission, apart from the collateral representations that were made to the Supreme Court of Tasmania.

People such as Senator John Coates got up in this chamber to ask a dorothy dixer of Senator Michael Tate so that Senator Tate could make this obscenity claim. The now Minister for Justice, Duncan Kerr, made similar claims. The Leader of the Opposition in Tasmania, Michael Field, his deputy, Peter Patmore, and a whole host of trade unionists and other Australian Labor Party apparatchiks made the comment that it was an absolute obscenity that Mr Gray had his legal fees paid. There has been a strange silence from all of these people when it comes to Dr Lawrence. The reason is that there is even less justification for the funding of Dr Lawrence than there was for Mr Gray's legal costs.

I believe that there was a very strong argument for the payment of Mr Gray's fees after the royal commission concluded that there was no way that any charge could be proffered or laid against Mr Gray, and indeed no such recommendation was made. After the event the taxpayers of Tasmania, I think quite appropriately, picked up the tab—quite a modest tab compared with what Dr Lawrence is undoubtedly incurring at this very stage.

Of course, the Labor Party apparatchiks in Tasmania were very violent in their opposition. There were demonstrations. Senator Tate in his comments in the Senate on 23 June 1992 used very colourful language. He said, `In fact, Tasmania is in uproar this morning as it has been revealed that the state cabinet is prepared to pay those who were involved in appearing before the royal commission.' Tasmania was allegedly in uproar. If Tasmania was allegedly in uproar on 23 June 1992, the Australian Labor Party must be aware that all of Australia is in uproar in relation to the way that Dr Lawrence's fees are being paid for, not after the event but beforehand with an open cheque.

The Australian Labor Party has asserted that the alleged campaign by the Western Australian government is somehow a political witch-hunt. If that were true, and I do not concede that is the fact, surely it is up to the political party—namely the Labor Party—to fund Dr Lawrence from its own resources and not those of the taxpayer. Indeed, the Western Australian Labor Party has a history of having had sufficient resources to fund gambling debts incurred by its members of parliament—to pay them off so that there are not any adverse comments made by the public. If they can find money for that, one would have thought that they might also be able to find money to fund Dr Carmen Lawrence in her ill-fated attempts, first, to scuttle the Marks royal commission and, second, to try to defend herself before the commission.

The reason I wished to make some comment on this matter tonight is that there has been such gross double standards displayed, especially by the Australian Labor Party in my home state of Tasmania. People like the Leader of the Opposition, Michael Field, his deputy, Peter Patmore, the Secretary to the Tasmania Trades and Labor Council and a host of other people who basically assist the Australian Labor Party in its political operations called demonstrations and tried to get petitions going. Indeed, the Australian Democrats in Tasmania tried to get petitions going about the funding of people before a royal commission. I believe in principle there is nothing wrong with that, given that it is from the same governmental source that commenced the inquiry. If you allow one government to fund defendants or people before royal commissions in other states, I think very dangerous precedents are set.

As Laura Tingle has pointed out in the Australian of 17 August, the source of the funds may well be highly inappropriate given the standards that are required and applied to the administration of the funds that are being used. The duplicity of these people in so roundly condemning the Tasmanian Liberal government yet being so very silent on the issue of Dr Carmen Lawrence! I believe that duplicity and hypocrisy ought be exposed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tonight I wish to continue with some remarks that I began making in the last session in relation to the Commonwealth Serum Laboratories. Last night with great disappointment I learnt that the opposition will not at this time support the reference of several matters in relation to CSL to the Senate Consumer Affairs References Committee. That was why earlier today I sought to defer that matter for a further week. The matters that I wish to refer to are ones which affect the life and health of thousands of Australians who have been treated with products made by CSL.

PARA.TAB: I would have thought that the health of thousands of people who have been treated with contaminated products and so contracted diseases—some have died as a result of these treatments—would have been a consideration that outweighed all others. So it was with great disappointment that I learnt that one of the reasons the opposition was concerned about referring these matters to the committee was that it may affect the share price of CSL. I will not at this stage reveal who used that excuse to me, but I will have no compunction if the opposition continues in its obstruction of this important public interest inquiry.

Let us leave aside for the moment the morality of measuring the lives of Australians against the share price of a private company. The claim is silly for quite logical reasons. There is a great number of people who will be taking action against the CSL. So one way or another the information which needs to be revealed will be revealed. It is not a matter of whether the information will come out; it is simply a matter of the process by which it comes out. Stopping a Senate inquiry will not stop an effect on the CSL share price if the latter is going to be affected by adverse publicity.

Secondly, both the CSL and the government claim that the indemnities given to the CSL cover the CSL against any claim relating to events before the organisation was privatised. If that is the case, any effect on the share price is easily covered by the government assuring the shareholders that they are not at risk. If, on the other hand, the indemnities are not watertight—and I am quite sure that the revelations which will undoubtedly come out will cause the government to extend those indemnities, and that will cover the CSL for all its misdemeanours before it was privatised—this should convince even the most right-wing hoon, even if the already established facts do not, that the privatisation of CSL has been a disaster.

Tonight I shall place some more information on the record so that dispassionate observers can decide for themselves whether it is fair to subject the very many people who even now are preparing legal claims against CSL to the enormous expense of establishing through the law courts the information background which should already be in the public domain.

From the intense lobbying to which I am being subjected by CSL and by the minister's staff I am convinced that neither is going to make the task of the affected patients easy. Both will put every obstacle in the way of these people and their worried families. This is most shameful behaviour but it seems the opposition is also happy to impose this very heavy additional burden on their fellow suffering Australians.

Professor Allars was asked to carry out an investigation of CSL with respect to the disease CJD, Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease. CSL and others have tried to claim that this investigation covered all important matters and that there was nothing more to investigate. Nothing could be further from the truth, as I will now show. The Allars report was based on an inquiry whose terms of reference were inadequate to cover all the important matters. Moreover, there were some matters in which the investigation was misled; and this resulted in wrong conclusions. Specifically, the inquiry into CSL's manufacturing and quality control of hormone products was conspicuously lacking in depth.

The report failed to note serious problems CSL experienced in producing satisfactory products. It is surprising that it did not draw the conclusion that the products were quite unacceptable in terms of modern concepts of therapeutic goods quality. Professor Allars thus did not explore the circumstances that led to this deplorable situation and caused it to persist throughout the period of the use of human pituitary hormones, a period of some 20 years.

Professor Allars dealt in considerable detail with the government system of attempts at controlling the quality of therapeutic goods by testing of product samples and with the failure of the National Biological Standards Laboratory to test samples of the hormones and pursue the development of standards for them. By contrast, she dismissed in a few words the much more general and effective parallel government system of inspection and licensing of manufacturers on the basis of the code of good manufacturing practice for therapeutic goods. No amount of government sample testing can substitute for the failure of manufacturers to build into products the quality of purity, potency, consistency, reliability and safety. The measures which manufacturers must adopt to ensure such high quality products are laid down in the code. CSL distributed hormones which were neither pure, reliably potent, consistent in quality, nor safe.

Although the code was not introduced until 1971, it was in formation between 1966 and 1970 and it was being developed contemporaneously with the manufacture of human pituitary hormones by CSL. The NBSL was inspecting manufacturers and developing the code alongside other bodies. CSL was a conspicuous non-participant in the development of the code. CSL held itself aloof from the processes of government-industry cooperation and intra-industry discussion which surrounded the development and progressive implementation of the code. CSL made it known that it did not subscribe to the philosophy and many of the detailed provisions of the code; and had no intention of applying it.

The Allars report does say, quite correctly, that biological products were exempted from the code; but there were two reasons for this. It did not pretend to deal adequately with biological products because there were some special conditions applying to these products, conditions such as having master seed and production cultures for microbiological products, test and production animals, and microbial safety and containment. However, as far as it went, the code was in general completely applicable to biological products and, in particular, part 2 on sterile products was particularly appropriate in the case of sterile biological products.

It was only in the last year of CSL's manufacture of pituitary products that CSL commenced to systematically implement the code of good manufacturing practice and be inspected by the NBSL. The full adoption of the code has been achieved only very recently. Therefore, the statement in section 3.84 of the report, `CSL products including hPG and hGH were manufactured according to the code of GMP' is simply untrue.

The code requires that there be a set of complete and comprehensive master manufacturing instructions for every product formally authorised by management and that this be changed and updated only through formal authorisation. It must be strictly adhered to throughout the manufacture of every batch of the product. This is to ensure that before any product goes into production for distribution, or even for clinical trials, the manufacturer has developed and fully documented a process which will ensure that the product is consistent and reliable from batch to batch and, likewise, that the product clinically trialled will be reproduced after production before general distribution is begun.

It is abundantly clear from the report that CSL failed to develop satisfactory processes for manufacturing the hormone products before they went into production. They were not clinically trialled. For example, sections 3.71 and 7.159 and table 3.3 show that batches made by a variety of methods, including experimental methods, were distributed. The first four fractionation runs were experimental. Sections 3.88, 3.91, 3.93 and 3.97 and appendix 2 show that finished batches were not infrequently unsterile, pyrogenic, contained hepatitis B, could not be assayed for hormone content, contained uncontrolled amounts of extraneous hormones and caused stinging on injection, et cetera. Pyrexia often followed the injection of hormones.

There were persistent problems with freeze drying of the products, ampoules were sometimes not properly sealed and batches were often highly discoloured. In addition, labelling and packaging errors occurred from time to time. So much for the development of a standard protocol for the manufacture of these products and for CSL's adherence to anything

SPEECH.PARA: approaching a code of good manufacturing practice! As I said at the beginning, these processes should have been written down before distribution even began.(Time expired)

PARA.TAB: Question resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories, upon notice, on 15 December 1994:

PARA.TAB: (1) Does the Tasmanian Government plan to bulldoze a road through the Tarkine Wilderness.
(2) Is it a fact that there have been two resolutions at the International Union for the Conservation of Nature calling for immediate protection and assessment of World Heritage values.

(3) Does the document known as the Cook/ Groom Heads of Agreement 1988 oblige the Government of the Commonwealth to no longer nominate any additional areas for World Heritage assessment or nomination.

(4) How will the Government resolve the apparent conflict between this agreement and: (a) the promise made in the chamber on 31 August 1994 to honour Australia's world heritage obligations; and (b) our international commitments under the World Heritage Convention.
(5) Which agreement takes primacy, the Commonwealth's World Heritage Agreement or the 1988 agreement with the Tasmanian Government.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) Yes.
(2) Yes.

(3) The 1988 agreement states that the `Commonwealth undertakes not to initiate any further inquiries into forestry in Tasmania or to propose any other areas of Tasmania for World Heritage listing without the concurrence of the Tasmanian Government.'

(4)&(5) Commonwealth obligations arising from the World Heritage Convention will be met through the process of negotiation of a Regional Forest Agreement (RFA) under the National Forest Policy Statement (NFPS). Tasmania as a signatory to the NFPS is committed to an RFA, which would require an assessment of a wide range of values including World Heritage values. The Commonwealth and Tasmania have agreed that an RFA will replace the 1988 agreement.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Housing and Regional Development, upon notice, on 2 March 1995:

PARA.TAB: With reference to three pilot studies under the new homes for old program:
(1) When will the greater awareness program for housing options for older Australians in rural and remote communities and Aboriginal communities be instituted.
(2) Will funding for this awareness program be drawn from the $400,000 for 1995-96 under the new homes for old program.
(3) What studies have been commissioned or are proposed.

(4) What is the correlation between the $80,000 consultancy awarded for the third pilot study to the Municipal Association of Victoria (MAV) and the previous reports by MAV namely `Linking Housing and Support Services for Older People, 1990' and `Ageing in my Place 1994'.
(5) Were these 1990 and 1994 reports commissioned by the Commonwealth Government; if so, what were the associated costs.

(6) Was it necessary to implement a follow-up survey into the first of the three pilot studies awarded to the Queensland Council on Social Services ($80,000) under the housing choices for older Australians program.
(7) What was the rationale for the survey.
(8) Who was contracted to implement the survey.
(9) What were the associated costs and timetable.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Housing and Regional Development has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) Depending upon the results of research currently being conducted into housing options for older Aboriginals and Torres Strait Islanders, and research which is scheduled to be conducted into housing options for older Australians living in rural and remote areas, it is anticipated that housing choices awareness programs for these two groups will commence during the 1995-96 financial year.
(2) Yes.

(3) An Issues Paper on housing for older Aboriginals and Torres Strait Islanders has been commissioned, and it is proposed that an Issues Paper on housing for older Australians living in rural and remote areas also be commissioned.

(4) The Municipal Association of Victoria (MAV) was awarded $80,900 to conduct one of the three pilot projects. In 1993 the MAV produced a report titled `Linking Housing and Support Services for Older People', subtitled `1990's Action Strategy for Councils and their Communities'. The report was a summary of a 1992 conference organised by the MAV titled `Linking Housing and Home Care'. It was not directly related to the local area pilot project under the New Homes for Old Program.

`Ageing in my Place 1994' refers to the first quarterly report on the local area pilot project in Moreland, Victoria, being conducted under the New Homes for Old Program. The full title of the report is `Moreland City Council "Ageing in my Place" Project—First Quarterly Report to the State Advisory Committee—November 1994'. `Ageing in my Place' is the name given locally to the Victorian local area pilot project.

(5) The Commonwealth Government did not commission the `Linking Housing and Support Services for Older People' report, nor provide funding for the conference to which it refers. The cost of the `Moreland City Council "Ageing in my Place" Project First Quarterly Report' is included in the $80,900 with which the Commonwealth Government is funding the MAV to conduct the Victorian local area pilot project. The MAV is not required by the Commonwealth Government to report separately on the cost of the quarterly reports.
(6) Yes. Lessons learned from evaluation of pilot projects enable wider application. This was always a planned part of the project.

(7) The impact of the Queensland local area pilot project is assessed by means of surveys before and after the delivery of the pilot project's communications program. Benchmark surveys and follow-up surveys are the means of assessing the impact of all the local area pilot projects.
(8) Woolcott Research Pty Limited.

(9) Woolcott Research Pty Limited has been contracted to conduct the benchmark and follow-up surveys for the three local area pilot projects at a total cost of $48,400. These surveys began in November 1993 and are expected to be completed in mid-1995.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Foreign Investment Review Board: China Rainbow Constructions Pty Ltd

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Treasurer, upon notice, on 21 March 1995:

PARA.TAB: With reference to the investigations undertaken by the Foreign Investment Review Board (FIRB) into the request by China Rainbow Constructions Pty Ltd from the Peoples Republic of China to bring funds in excess of $2 million into Australia:
(1) When was this application heard by the FIRB.
(2) What amount of funds did China Rainbow Constructions Pty Ltd request to bring into Australia, and what was the stated purposes.
(3) What was the result of the FIRB's investigations.
(4) What are the names and addresses of the principals China Rainbow Constructions Pty Ltd.
(5) What association does the aforementioned company have with Ingabrook Pty Ltd.
(6) What action has the Australian Securities Commission taken against both companies.
(7) What contracts did China Rainbow Constructions Pty Ltd enter into for the purchase of land in New South Wales.

(8) If these contracts were not honoured by these foreign national in their dealings with Australian citizens, what can the Government do to protect the rights of Australians who appear to have been duped by this foreign company, China Rainbow Constructions Pty Ltd.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Treasurer has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1), (3) and (5) China Rainbow Constructions (Australia) Pty Ltd was, in effect, given foreign investment approval to acquire an interest in urban land in New South Wales on 1 July 1991 when Ingabrook Pty Limited was given approval for this acquisition. China Rainbow Constructions (Australia) Pty Ltd at that time had a 25 per cent interest in Ingabrook Pty Limited. An order prohibiting the acquisition was initially made on 27 March 1991 (Gazette S85 2 April 1991) and, following the consideration of additional information, the order was revoked on 1 July 1991 (Gazette S184 3 July 1991).

(2) Foreign investment approval is only required for acquisitions and investments that fall within the scope of foreign investment policy and the Foreign Acquisitions and Takeovers Act. Approval is not required to bring funds into Australia.
(4) China Rainbow Constructions (Australia) Pty Ltd is a wholly owned subsidiary of China Rainbow Development Corporation, which is located at 21 Nanlishilu, Beijing, China.
(6) This is a matter that should be directed to the Minister representing the Attorney-General.

(7) Contractual information is confidential to the parties involved. Foreign interests can enter into conditional contracts to acquire real estate in Australia, without having to submit those contracts to FIRB. The acquisitions could, for example, be conditional on FIRB approval, which would need to be obtained for the acquisition to proceed.

(8) The Australian legal system provides avenue for claims where parties believe there is a breach of contract. The Foreign Acquisitions and Takeovers Act also provides for substantial penalties, on conviction, for persons who do not comply with conditions imposed through approvals of acquisitions.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 3 May 1995:

PARA.TAB: (1)(a) Which grenades in the Australian Defence Industries (ADI) system can be activated by: (i) remote delivery, and (ii) rifle projector; and (b) can the Minister confirm that any grenade in the ADI system be activated by rifle projector.
(2) Could all grenades activated by rifle projector constitute remotely delivered land mines; if not, why not.

(3)(a) How many ADI produced rifle projectors were for use by the Australian Defence Force (ADF); and (b) how many or what percentage were exported commercially or under defence co-operation during the 1990-91, 1991-92, 1992-93, 1993-94 and 1994-95 financial years.
(4) To which countries were any rifle projectors exported: (a) commercially; or (b) under defence co-operation, during the 1990-91, 1991-92, 1992-93, 1993-94 and 1994-95 financial years.

(5)(a) How many ADI incendiary grenades (thermite) and ADI illuminating grenades/trip flares were for use by the ADF; and (b) how many or what percentage were exported commercially or under defence co-operation during the 1990-91, 1991-92, 1992-93, 1993-94 and 1994-95 financial years.

(6) To which countries were any ADI incendiary grenades (thermite) and ADI illuminating grenades/trip flares exported: (a) commercially; or (b) under defence co-operation, during the 1990-91, 1991-92, 1992-93, 1993-94 and 1994-95 financial years.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1)(a) (i) None. (ii) All types of grenades manufactured by ADI can be launched by rifle projector. (b) See (ii).

(2) No. Grenades launched by rifle projector automatically explode several seconds later. They are not mines as defined under Article 2 of Protocol II to the 1980 Inhumane Weapons Convention because they are not `designed to be detonated or exploded by the presence, proximity or contact of a person or vehicle' (that is, target actuated).

(3)(a) It is not appropriate to reveal Australian Defence Force (ADF) usage rates. To do so could give an indication of the combat sustainability of the ADF which would not be in our national security interests.

(b) Export statistics where individual companies or individual transactions can be identified are not released as this information is considered commercial-in-confidence. Australia's export control regime will only succeed if companies can trust the Government with sensitive details of their operations.

(4)(a) See (3). (b) I am unable at present to give details of exports of defence and related goods from Australia as the data received from Customs over the past few years has been found to be unreliable due to a computer software problem. Officers of my department are working with their colleagues in Customs to rectify the situation. Therefore, to advise with confidence what items may have been transferred under Defence Cooperation for the years 1990-91 onwards would require a great deal of administrative effort and I am not prepared to commit the resources necessary to retrieve the information.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 3 May 1995:

PARA.TAB: (1)(a) Can any trip wire accessory or firing device F1A1 be fitted to any grenades in the Australian Defence Industries (ADI) system; and (b) to which grenades in the ADI system can any trip wire accessory or firing device F1A1 be fitted.
(2) Could any of these grenades or devices constitute a land mine; if not, why not.

(3) Could any of the above devices or grenades sold with accessories such as trip wires for (a) pull; (b) tension release; (c) pressure activation; and (d) pressure release modes, constitute a land mine; if not, why not.
(4)(a) Are any of the ADI grenades fitted with any trip wire accessory or firing device F1A1 detectable; if not, why not; and (b) do they have self-destruct mechanisms; if not, why not.

(5)(a) How many ADI grenades with trip wire accessories were for use by the ADF; and (b) how many or what percentage were exported commercially or under defence co-operation during the 1990-91, 1991-92, 1992-93, 1993-94 and 1994-95 financial years.

(6) To which countries were any ADI grenades with any trip wire accessories and/or firing devices F1A1 exported: (a) commercially; or (b) under defence co-operation, during the 1990-91, 1991-92, 1992-93, 1993-94 and 1994-95 financial years.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) (a) Yes; (b) All.

(2) No. The definition of a landmine under Article 2 of Protocol II to the 1980 Inhumane Weapons Convention is `any munition placed under, on or near the ground or other surface area and designed to be detonated or exploded by the presence, proximity or contact of a person or vehicle'.

Grenades, including high explosive (HE) fragmentation grenades, incendiary grenades, and illuminating grenades, do not come within the above definition of a mine, because of their means of operation. Grenades are armed and thrown; they automatically explode several seconds later. They are not mines because they are not `designed to be detonated or exploded by the presence, proximity or contact of a person or vehicle' (that is, target actuated).

Similarly, rifle grenades do not come within the definition of a mine. Such grenades are launched from a rifle. Firing the rifle both launches the grenade and initiates the process of arming it. The grenade automatically detonates seconds later, either on impact with the target or after a set delay period. Like ordinary grenades, rifle grenades are not target actuated, and therefore are not mines or remotely delivered mines.
By itself, the firing device F1A1 does not come within the definition of a mine, because it is not a munition. It is intended for detonating munitions, often in conjunction with trip wires.
(4) (a) Yes. (b) No. A self destruct mechanism is not required.

(5) (a) It is not appropriate to reveal Australian Defence Force (ADF) usage rates. To do so could give an indication of the combat sustainability of the ADF which would not be in our national security interests.

(b) Export statistics where individual companies or individual transactions can be identified are not released as this information is considered commercial-in-confidence. Australia's export control regime will only succeed if companies can trust the Government with sensitive details of their operations.

(6) (a) See (5). (b) I am unable at present to give details of exports of defence and related goods from Australia as the data received from Customs over the past few years has been found to be unreliable due to a computer software problem. Officers of my department are working with their colleagues in Customs to rectify the situation. Therefore, to advise with confidence what items may have been transferred under Defence Cooperation for the years 1990-91 onwards would require a great deal of administrative effort and I am not prepared to commit the resources necessary to retrieve the information.

PARA.TAB: (1) No. The definition of a landmine under Article 2 of Protocol II to the 1980 Inhumane Weapons Convention is `any munition placed under, on or near the ground or other surface area and designed to be detonated or exploded by the presence, proximity or contact of a person or vehicle'.

Grenades, including high explosive (HE) fragmentation grenades, incendiary grenades, and illuminating grenades, do not come within the above definition of a mine, because of their means of operation. Australia's export control regime will only succeed if companies can trust the Government with sensitive details of their operations.

(6) (a) See (5). (b) I am unable at present to give details of exports of defence and related goods from Australia as the data received from Customs over the past few years has been found to be unreliable due to a computer software problem. Officers of my department are working with their colleagues in Customs to rectify the situation. Therefore, to advise with confidence what items may have been transferred under Defence Cooperation for the years 1990-91 onwards would require a great deal of administrative effort and I am not prepared to commit the resources necessary to retrieve the information.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 3 May 1995:

PARA.TAB: With reference to the 1981 United Nations (UN) Convention on `Prohibitions or Restrictions on the Use of Certain Conventional Weapons which may be deemed to be Excessively Injurious or to have Indiscriminate Effects' and its relevant protocol, Protocol II, on the `Prohibitions or Restrictions on the use of Mines, Booby-Traps and other Devices', and with reference to the definitions of `mine' in this Protocol, which defines a `mine' as `any munition placed under, on or near the ground or other surface area and designed to be detonated or exploded by the presence, proximity or contact of a person or vehicle', and `remotely delivered mine' means any mine so defined delivered by artillery, rocket, mortar or similar means or dropped from an aircraft:

(1) Could the Australian Defence Industries (ADI) HE fragmentation grenade fitted with any trip wire accessories and/or firing device F1A1 constitute a land mine under the above 1981 UN Convention and Protocol; if so, why; if not, why not.

(2) Could any grenade in the ADI system fitted with any trip wire accessories and/or firing device F1A1 constitute a land mine under the above 1981 UN Convention and Protocol; if so, why; if not, why not.
(3) Could any grenade in the ADI system which can be activated by rifle projector constitute a remotely delivered mine under the above 1981 UN Convention and Protocol; if so, why; if not, why not.
(4) Does the ADI incendiary grenade (thermite) and the ADI illuminating grenade/trip flare constitute a land mine under the above 1981 UN Convention and Protocol; if so, why; if not, why not.

(5) Once the Government signs the partial ban on land mines currently being negotiated at the UN: (a) will the Government review the grenades, accessories, projectors and land mines that ADI produces to ensure they comply; if not, why not; and (b) which grenades, accessories, land mines and projectors will either be banned or need to be modified to ensure they are detectable and have self-destruct mechanisms.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) No. Grenades, including high explosive (HE) fragmentation grenades, incendiary grenades, and illuminating grenades, do not come within the definition of a mine, because of their means of operation. Grenades are armed and thrown; they automatically explode several seconds later. They are not mines because they are not `designed to be detonated or exploded by the presence, proximity or contact of a person or vehicle' (that is, target actuated).

Similarly, rifle grenades do not come within the definition of a mine. Such grenades are launched from a rifle. Firing the rifle both launches the grenade and initiates the process of arming it. The grenade automatically detonates seconds later, either on impact with the target or after a set delay period. Like ordinary grenades, rifle grenades are not target actuated, and therefore are not mines or remotely delivered mines.
By itself, the firing device F1A1 does not come within the definition of a mine, because it is not a munition. It is intended for detonating munitions, often in conjunction with trip wires.

In addition, the opinion of the Group of Governmental Experts preparing for the review of the Inhumane Weapons Convention is that the definition of a mine is only intended to cover individual munitions manufactured as mines. Combinations of other forms of munitions with additional components (such as grenade and trip wire) are regarded as a `construct' and hence do not constitute a mine under the definitions contained in Article 2 of Protocol II of the Convention. Lethal `constructs' can be easily made from commonly available components such as batteries, wire, string, garden fertiliser and sugar. It is intended that `constructs' be dealt with in other articles to Protocol II of the Convention.

(5) (a) and (b) It is unfortunately by no means certain that there will be international consensus at the Review Conference on the Inhumane Weapons Convention, to be held in September and October, on the Australian Government's proposal to ban those landmines which are not detectable and which do not self-destruct and passively deactivate.

The Review Conference will conclude in mid October. At that time, the Government will review all items manufactured, sold, used or stockpiled in Australia which fall within the definitions contained in the revised Convention. Decisions on changes to export controls, and possible replacement of items used by the Australian Defence Force, will be made at that time. At present anti-personnel mines are not manufactured in, or exported from, Australia.

I cannot speculate as to what form the revised Convention will take or, what decisions we will make. However, I can confirm that Australia will remain a party to the Convention, and will comply with its rules, and I can guarantee that the position I stated in February 1994 will continue in force: Australia will not export mines to countries not party to the Convention. However, because there are so many different civil and military items which could be used in landmines, this does not apply to components or possible components of mines.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Transport, upon notice, on 9 May 1995:

(3) (a) What would the estimated cost be for the upgrading of the airstrip to enable it to be capable of receiving jet aircraft; and (b) how far would the runway need to be extended.
(4) Who currently owns the Dallachey airstrip.
(5) Would any land need to be resumed to extend the airstrip.
(6) Would any of that land include land that has previously been declared as national park land.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Transport has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) The CAA has advised that it has not received a formal request for upgrading or extending Dallachey airstrip.

Dallachey airstrip is a privately owned airstrip and is not licensed by the CAA. The owner of the airstrip is Cardwell Shire Council. When contacted about this matter, the Council informed the CAA that it has discussed with a Queensland property developer the matter of upgrading Dallachey airstrip. However, the Council confirmed that it has not proposed or requested the upgrading of the airstrip through any Department.
(2) No. Refer answer to Part 1.
(3)(a) There is no requirement for aerodrome owners to advise the CAA of costings of airstrip development proposals. The CAA has no knowledge of costings for upgrading Dallachey airstrip.

(b) Runway length is dependent on the type of aircraft to be used at an airstrip and the desired aircraft payload (ie passengers and cargo). This question cannot be answered as the CAA has not received any such proposal from the airstrip owner or an air service provider.
(4) Dallachey airstrip is owned by Cardwell Shire Council.
(5) The CAA has no knowledge of the need to resume land.
(6) The CAA has no knowledge of the need to resume land.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: CSIRO: Gerard Cassegrain Pty Ltd and Cassiro Pty Ltd

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Industry, Science and Technology, upon notice, on 15 May 1995:

PARA.TAB: With reference to a series of answers given to the Senate Economics Legislation Committee to questions on notice regarding the Commonwealth Scientific and Research Organisation (CSIRO) and its involvement with Gerard Cassegrain Pty Ltd and Cassiro Pty Ltd (which answers are undated but which include answers to 23 questions lodged by Senator Ferguson on notice):
