(2) What is the total amount of money contributed by the Commonwealth to CSIRO and otherwise related to this project, expressed in terms of capital and in kind contributions made.
(3) What monies were paid by way of the settlement referred to, and what was the source of those funds and ministerial authorisation or otherwise given for their payment.
(4) Exactly what legal costs were paid in relation to this dispute and its settlements.
(5) What rules, regulations or conventions are in place for the oversight by the Minister or the department of any expenditure by CSIRO for major commercial decisions.

(6) Making reference to any dates where the rules and regulations change, what are the details of the amount of monetary commitment above for which it was necessary for the CSIRO to obtain ministerial approval.

(7) In relation to the subject matters of these questions, what ministerial approval was sought and what ministerial approval was given in relation to what expenditures or commitments, and what are the relevant dates in all instances.

(8) Can minutes of the authorisations given by the Minister or the relevant minister to CSIRO in relation to expenditure and commitment of amounts for which ministerial approval was required be provided.

(9) With reference to information on a page identified as page 800, that is in the third page in the answers titled `Introduction', where it is indicated that `the mediation of settlement identified a monetary sum of $9.5 million agreed to by GC and Co., Mr. Cassegrain, CSIRO and Sirotech in comprehensive discharge of all claims and rights', was a payment of $9.5 million paid by CSIRO to Cassegrain and/or other entities associated with those last mentioned entities and persons.

(10) Whilst it is understood that this amount was paid pursuant to the Deed of Settlement, on what basis it was (sic) that the Commonwealth taxpayers were in a position whereby they were required to pay out $9.5 million.

(11) (a) What was the justification for such payment, other than as a consequence of the Deed of Settlement; (b) why was it appropriate for these monies to be paid by CSIRO; (c) what were they buying or what were they compensating or why were those damages payable.

(12) With reference to the answers given in relation to questions of Senator Ferguson numbered 13, 14 and 15, was the approach by a CSIRO officer direct to Cassegrain's bank with a letter which could have had the consequences alluded to an appropriate, commercially and morally acceptable action; if not, would the Minister identify what action has been taken against the officer involved and whether this officer is still employment (sic) by CSIRO or the Commonwealth Government, if so, in what department and capacity.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have referred the Questions on Notice to CSIRO for response. Attached are the answers it has provided.

PARA.TAB: (1) In summary, the Court proceedings involved disputes over:
the value of two technologies and the extent of associated intellectual property;
the interpretation and contents of the various agreements, understandings and discussions between the parties;
the motives and purposes of certain dealings with third parties relating to the relevant technologies;
the size of the respective contributions made by the parties;
the respective responsibilities and capacities of the parties in respect of further funding;
the respective responsibilities of the parties for the various disputes and the motives and purposes associated with events that occurred in the course of the disputes; and
overall, whether the joint relationship should continue and if so, on what terms.

Further details can be found in the Introduction to Answers provided in response to previous Questions on Notice. As noted there, the matters in dispute were not resolved during the Court proceedings or, in most cases, in the Settlement Deed. Under the final settlement which was mediated by Sir Laurence Street, it was agreed in the Settlement Deed to resolve the disputes without admission of liability and without reaching any specific factual conclusions as to most of the disputes.

The legal actions were settled on 27 September 1993 on the basis that neither party would pursue any such claims against the other party, nor would any party encourage or assist the other party to do so.

(2) There were long-standing and factually complex disputes between the parties as to the extent of the respective contributions made to the project and the extent to which certain personnel had performed functions on behalf of Cassiro. Conclusions resolving this area of dispute were not reached by the Court. It was agreed in the Settlement Deed to resolve the disputes without admission of liability and without determining the extent of overall contributions of the parties to the project.

To determine the facts in this area would require significant resources, which would not be justified, given the procedures subsequently put in place by CSIRO aimed at preventing the recurrence of problems such as this.

The legal actions were settled on 27 September 1993 on the basis that neither party would pursue any such claims against the other party, nor would any party encourage or assist the other party to do so.

(3) The monies paid by way of settlement were $9.5 million. This sum was obtained by a call on all Institutes and Divisions in CSIRO based on a formula, in which the major Institute involved paid the larger proportion of these funds. Ministerial authorisation was given in September 1993 under Section 50 of the Science and Industry Research Act 1949 for CSIRO to enter into the Deed of Settlement and Release and pay the settlement sum in accordance with the conditions of that Deed.
(4) The estimate, to date, is $4.772 million

(5) The Science and Industry Research Act 1949 requires that all contracts in excess of $1 million of expenditure or receipt of funds require Ministerial approval. It is CSIRO policy that the Chief Executive may refer to the Minister contracts which are potentially onerous or politically sensitive, irrespective of the amount involved.

(6) The current requirements for Ministerial approvals are described in Question 5. Up to 18 October 1990, CSIRO was required to obtain Ministerial approval for the receipt or expenditure of funds exceeding $250,000.

(7) It is assumed that this question relates to the initial contractual arrangements. A Ministerial Minute was forwarded to the then Minister the Honourable B. O. Jones seeking his approval for the Cassegrain Group and CSIRO to enter into a joint venture without prior public advertisement in March 1988. The Minister cleared this proposal on 29 March 1988. The estimated initial contribution by each party was $1.5 million. The approval associated with this minute provided the rationale for entry into the Memorandum of Commercial Intent which was signed by the parties in June 1989.

(8) No; the Minutes provided to the Minister by CSIRO contain information of a commercial-in-confidence and confidential nature under the Deed of Settlement and Release. The authorisation is an integral part of these Minutes.

(9) The reference to information by Senator Macdonald was on page four of the answers titled "Introduction". The Settlement Deed did not become binding on the parties until CSIRO had paid to or at the direction of GC & Co and Mr Claude Cassegrain the sum of $9.5 million.

In accordance with a written direction from GC&Co and Mr Cassegrain the sum of $9.5 million was paid, as to the sum of $8,309,502 to the State Bank of New South Wales; as to the sum of $1,170,000 to Messrs Garrett and Walmsley; and as to the sum of $20,498 to Messrs Garrett and Walmsley on account of income tax calculated for Cassiro.

The legal actions were settled on 27 September 1993 on the basis that neither party would pursue any such claims against the other party, nor would any party encourage or assist the other party to do so.

(10) As stated in the answer to Question 3, CSIRO Institutes and Divisions were required to contribute to the payment from existing funds. Taxpayers were not asked to provide an "extra" $9.5 million. The basis for this payment rests on the concept that the Commonwealth of Australia is responsible for liabilities incurred by statutory authorities such as CSIRO.

(11)(a)(b)(c) Payment of the settlement sum terminated the potentially very lengthy Court proceedings to determine the outcome of the many disputes that existed. It provided CSIRO with a comprehensive discharge from GC & Co and Mr Cassegrain of all claims and rights in respect of the relevant technologies and all claims relating to all the allegations made in the Court proceedings and associated costs. Payment of the settlement sum also purchased for CSIRO all the direct and indirect interests of GC & Co in the relevant technologies.
The circumstances in which this need for a settlement developed are further explained in the Introduction to Answers furnished in answer to previous Questions on Notice.

The legal actions were settled on 27 September 1993 on the basis that neither party would pursue any such claims against the other party, nor would any party encourage or assist the other party to do so.

(12) As explained in answers to previous Questions on Notice, the motives and purposes of the personnel involved in forwarding the letter to the bank were never determined by the Court or resolved in the Settlement Deed, and CSIRO did not reach specific conclusions on those aspects.

The answer to this question could reflect upon particular individuals who should, as a matter of fairness, be given an opportunity to state their position. To embark upon that procedure would require CSIRO to take on the fact finding role of a court.

Senior management of CSIRO did not exhaustively investigate all the circumstances surrounding the various inadequacies identified, but informed itself sufficiently to form the view that they may well have been occasioned be honest misunderstanding rather than deliberate misconduct. Procedures have subsequently been put in place, aimed at preventing a recurrence of problems such as this.
The legal actions were settled on 27 September 1993 on the basis that neither party would pursue any claims against the other party, nor would any party encourage or assist any other party to do so.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Human Services and Health, upon notice, on 24 May 1995:

PARA.TAB: (1) Is it the case that the National Food Authority is arguing against a labelling requirement for genetically engineered foods.
(2) Does the Minister believe that the general public should have the opportunity to know whether food they might purchase is genetically engineered.
(3) Will the Government be adopting any requirements for genetically engineered foods to be labelled as such at the point of sale to the public.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Human Services and Health has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) No. The National Food Authority is currently considering a proposal to vary the Food Standards Code to regulate foods produced using gene technology. Section 10b of the National Food Authority Act 1991 requires the Authority, when considering food standards, to have regard to the provision of adequate information to enable consumers to make informed choices about food and to prevent fraud and deception. Before developing a draft standard the Authority will give due regard to the full range of sources, including labelling, from which consumers may obtain information about the use of gene technology in food production.

Once the Authority has developed a draft standard it will undertake a round of public consultation before making a recommendation to the National Food Standards Council, a body comprised of the Health Ministers of the State and Territories and of the Commonwealth.
(2) and (3) Yes, it is consistent with the principles already applied in the Food Standards Code for consumers to be informed about the true nature of a food.

The use of recombinant DNA technology as a part of a plant or animal breeding program can result in foods with characteristics which are qualitatively or quantitatively different to a conventional counterpart. However, in many cases the use of the technology will result in foods which are not chemically and physically different. It would not be appropriate to require food producers or retailers to label food in ways which may be factually incorrect or which could not be verified by independent analysis.

Further information about food produced using gene technology may also be supplied in response to specific consumer or market requirements, for example, organic fruit and vegetables or dolphin safe tuna, providing that it is not misleading or deceptive.

Under current federal arrangements, food standards are developed by the National Food Authority and endorsed by the National Food Standards Council and then adopted and enforced in respect to food offered for sale under State and Territory food legislation.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories, upon notice, on 5 June 1995:

PARA.TAB: (1) Does the Cockatoo Island site in Sydney Harbour, currently managed by the Commonwealth Government, contain significant areas of heritage value.
(2) Who is responsible for the maintenance of heritage sites if a dispute remains ongoing, as is currently the case with Cockatoo Island.
(3) Were the two dry docks known as the Sutherland and Fitzroy docks flooded in late 1992.
(4) Can reasons be provided for the flooding of the two dry docks on Cockatoo Island.
(5) Will the flooding of these dry docks contribute to an overall decline in any heritage value.

(6) Given that the site is currently listed as one of the Commonwealth assets to be sold, has the Government considered the possibility of permitting non-commercial use and maintenance of the dry docks by non-government organisations committed to the preservation of Australia's maritime history, prior to the settlement of any transfer of use pertaining to Cockatoo Island.
(7) Is it likely that the docks areas on the island would pose a threat to the safety of workers restoring or undertaking maintenance of historic vessels.
(8) Can an undertaking be given to allow divers to assess the current state of the flooded dry docks and to ensure that no further deterioration has taken place.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) The Australian Heritage Commission has listed the whole of Cockatoo Island on the Register of the National Estate, as the Cockatoo Island Industrial Conservation Area, for its heritage value.

On the island, the Sutherland Dock, Fitzroy Dock, Power House/Pump House, Biloela Group, Underground Grain Silos, Prison Barracks Precinct, Mess Hall, Military Guard Room, Barracks Block and Blacksmith and Machine Shop are individually listed in the Register.

(2) The Commonwealth is vested with title to Cockatoo Island pursuant to Section 5(l) of the Cockatoo and Schnapper Islands Act 1949. Title to the island passed from the Commonwealth Shipping Board to the Commonwealth effective from 4 September 1950. Under the Administrative Arrangements Order of 3 July 1990, implementation of the Act is listed as being the responsibility of the Department of Defence.
Accordingly, the Department of Defence is responsible for maintenance of heritage sites on Cockatoo Island until Cockatoo Island passes into the hands of its new owner.

The Department of Defence has recently carried out repair and maintenance work on 14 buildings of significant heritage value on the island, in accordance with the Commonwealth's Cockatoo Island Conservation Policy, and in recognition of the significance of these historic buildings to the National Estate.

(3)-(5) The Department of Defence has advised that the two dry docks were flooded in late 1992 for reasons of public safety, and because it was advised that it would have cost millions of dollars to maintain their operability following closure of the dockyard in 1992. The Department has further advised that, prior to flooding the dry docks, views of potential damage were sought. A definitive view was not reached. Marine growth would be expected to occur over time.
(6) The Department of Finance Task Force on Asset Sales has advised that it is too early in the sale process at present to consider options for the future use of Cockatoo Island.

(7)-(8) The Department of Defence has advised that an assessment of the occupational risks for workers on this former industrial site would depend upon a range of factors including those specific to the nature of the activities involved in the maintenance work itself. A case by case assessment might be required, depending upon what redevelopment takes place. The Department further advised that there is no intention to assess the condition of the flooded docks at this stage, until the future of the island is clear.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Human Services and Health, upon notice, on 6 June 1995:

PARA.TAB: (1) In the past have haemophilia sufferers been infected with blood-borne viruses such as HIV and Hepatitis C through plasma-derived products, do such products continue to be used to treat haemophilia sufferers and could the risk of infection be substantially reduced if the high purity Recombinant Factor VIII were to be used instead.
(2) Is the Minister prepared to give priority to the purchase of Recombinant Factor VIII in applying the $47 million allocated in the human services and health budget.

(3) While the report of the working party convened to seek an ongoing solution to the problem of intermittent shortages of treatment products for haemophiliacs will be discussed at the Health Minister's meeting on 16 June 1995, it will clearly be some time before a comprehensive plan of action can be implemented. In those circumstances is the Minister prepared to proceed immediately to minimise risk of infection for haemophilia sufferers as suggested in (2) above.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Human Services and Health has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) Before the introduction in the 1980s of a range of measures designed to minimise the risk of transmission of blood-borne viruses through blood and blood products, a number of people with haemophilia were infected with blood-borne viruses such as HIV and hepatitis C virus (HCV). Since the mid-1980s however, there have been no recorded cases of the transmission of HIV or HCV through Australian fractionated blood products.
Plasma derived products continue to be used by people with haemophilia.

The Australian Health Ministers' Advisory Council's Working Party on Factor VIII Supply concluded in their report that `The view that the current plasma-sourced Factor VIII carries a higher risk of viral contamination than synthetic Factor VIII cannot be established especially since human-sourced albumin is used to stabilise the recombinant product.' and that `The Working Party considers that the current evidence does not confirm immunological compromise through the use of Factor VIII products with less than a `very high' purity level.'
The full report of the Working Party has been provided to the honourable senator's office.

2.(2)-(3) The decision of the Australian Health Ministers' Conference (AHMC) is that the main priority of Governments should be to increase the supply of plasma derived Factor VIII in Australia. Recombinant Factor VIII will be used to supplement the supply of plasma derived product. Therefore, the funds allocated in the 1995-96 Commonwealth Budget for the purpose of increasing the supply of Factor VIII will be used in accordance with the AHMC decision, that is, to increase the supply of plasma derived Factor VIII to in excess of 2.0 International Units per capita per year, and to supplement that supply with recombinant factor VIII.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Human Services and Health, upon notice, on 6 June 1995:

PARA.TAB: With reference to monies provided by the National Health and Medical Research Council, the Australian Research Council and any other Commonwealth funding bodies to institutions for medical or other research purposes in Australia involving the use of animals:

(1) What species, and the numbers of these individual species, have been used by institutions, research establishments and private companies in Australia over the past 5 years, and from where were these animals provided.
(2)(a) What primate species are being used and have been used over the past 5 years, by recipients of Commonwealth grants; and (b) from where have these animals been sourced.
(3) Of the primates used, how many are subject to research with the end being lethal, and how many are subject to multiple experimentation.
(4) What are the requirements that need to be met, in relation to animal welfare matters, by institutions receiving moneys for research on animals.
(5) Are recipients required to show conclusively that their work is incapable of being conducted by any other means than by use of live animals.

(6)(a) What research effort has been carried out using Commonwealth funds over the past 5 years in relation to alternatives to animal usage in research; and (b) what has been the total financial allocation, and whom are the recipients for such grants.

(7)(a) What future efforts are planned by the Commonwealth, or any of its grant recipients, in relation to the development of alternatives to animal research in Australia; and (b) will the various Commonwealth funding agencies be gradually phasing in proven alternative research methods.

(8) How many of the current research grants, as a percentage figure, allocated by Commonwealth research funding agencies, have been provided to recipients using recognised alternatives to testing on animals.
(9) Who are the present recipients of Commonwealth research grants that involve using animals in testing, and what is the nature of the experiments being conducted.
(10) How do the various Commonwealth funding agencies decide whether proposed research projects using animal testing are humane, duplicatory, scientifically necessary or medically reliable.
(11) What guidelines or practices do the various Commonwealth funding bodies have in relation to the use of animals in research in educational institutions.
(12) Will the use of primates in research be phased out in the near future.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Crowley Sen The Hon R.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Human Services and Health has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: While the National Health and Medical Research Council (NHMRC) places stringent requirements on the recipients of funding it does not control the research or its conduct directly.

The Australian Research Council is the responsibility of the Minister for Employment, Education and Training. The question was referred to the Department of Employment Education and Training on 20 June 1995.
The following answer relates to research funded through the NHMRC.

(1) The attached table (Attachment 1) shows estimated numbers of animals used in research projects funded through the NHMRC from 1990-1995. The Department does not collect figures relating to animals used in research funded by other bodies or private companies.

It is important to note that these figures represent estimated numbers, not actual numbers used. The NHMRC database does not contain data on the actual numbers of animals used in research. Therefore, these figures are a guide only.
(2)(a) The primate species used in NHMRC funded research over the past 5 years include: Macaques, Baboons, Marmosets, Tamarins and Green Monkeys.

(2)(b) All animals used for NHMRC funded research are issued from recognised supply units, usually associated with the research institution. In states where licensing procedures are in place, it is a requirement that such supply units are licensed or hold appropriate accreditation.

Most of the non-human primates used in NHMRC funded research projects are from one of the three central breeding colonies. The NHMRC provides partial funding to support these breeding colonies. They are: the National Macaque Facility, the University of Melbourne National Baboon Facility, Royal Prince Alfred Hospital, and the National Marmoset colony, CSIRO Division of Human Nutrition.

(3) Of the non-human primates used in NHMRC funded research projects, during 1990-1995, it is estimated that 156 have been subject to experiments without recovery. This figure is derived from the NHMRC database which contains estimated numbers only, not actual numbers used, the actual numbers of animals used often vary from these estimates. The NHMRC does not collect data on the individual history of the animals used in experiments and cannot provide data on animals subject to multiple experimentation.

(4) and (11) All applications for NHMRC funding using animals must be accompanied by an ethics clearance from the institutional Animal Experimentation Ethics Committee (AEEC). The code specifies the responsibilities and operation of the AEECs, including details of balanced membership to ensure that a broad range of views are represented, as well as operating procedures.

The NHMRC has been involved in setting standards for the use of animals in research for the last 25 years. It acknowledges the importance of animal-based research to find better ways of preventing, treating and curing human disease, and takes the view that this places a special responsibility on investigators to use animals humanely and to treat them with respect. In 1969 the NHMRC issued the Australian Code of Practice for the Care and Use of Animals for Scientific Purposes, in conjunction with the CSIRO. Since then the Code has been reviewed regularly in conjunction with the CSIRO and the then Australian Agricultural Council, to take into account changes in biological science and in community attitudes. In 1985 the NHMRC established the Animal Welfare Committee (AWC) to advise the NHMRC on all matters relating to the conduct and ethics of animal experimentation in medical research. The AWC together with other code sponsors and State/Territory animal welfare representatives is responsible for the regular revision of the Australian Code of practice for the Care and Use of Animals for Scientific Purposes.
The purpose of the Code is to ensure the humane care of animals used for scientific purposes. Its aims are to:
emphasise the responsibilities of both investigators and institutions using animals;
ensure that the welfare of animals is always considered an essential factor;
ensure that animal use is valid;
minimise the number of animals used in projects and limit or avoid pain or distress; and
promote the development and use of techniques which replace animal experiments.

In addition to the Code, the NHMRC Animal Welfare Committee has developed a range of policies, guidelines and publications on animal welfare issues to assist investigators. These are to be used in conjunction with the Code, and include the following titles:
An introductory guide to: Minimising the numbers of animals used in research projects
Background paper: Strategies for minimising the numbers of animals used in research projects
Ways of minimising pain and distress in animals in research
Australian animal experimentation ethics committees, 1987-1989: Protection for animals in biomedical research
A guide to the use of Australian native mammals in biomedical research

(5) and (10) The NHMRC relies on the researcher and the institutional AEEC, in the context of the Code and relevant guidelines, to ensure that the use of animals in research is fully justified and that no proven alternative could be used in its stead.

Each application for NHMRC Medical Research Project Grant Support must be accompanied by an Institutional Approval form for Experiments on Animals. This form must be signed by an AEEC giving approval to the project. It is the responsibility of each AEEC to approve only those experiments which conform to the requirements of all relevant sections of the Code and of relevant animal welfare legislation, taking into consideration ethical and welfare aspects as well as scientific or educational value.
The Animal Welfare Committee also conducts a yearly check of proposals for funding, examining in detail the ethical, welfare and scientific value of the proposed project.

6(a) and (b) While the NHMRC does not collect data on this topic, it is clear that advances in experimental systems and understanding have led to the replacement of animal models with simpler tissue culture or laboratory methods in many fields of research.

(7)(a) The NHMRC Animal Welfare Committee is currently arranging two workshops on alternative research methods in order to encourage future research projects using and developing alternatives. The specific areas targeted are:
minimising trauma to animals and exploration of alternatives to using animals in arthritis related research; and
antibody raising, and the use of the technomouse to replace animals as incubators.

NHMRC funds are being used to assist with bringing a world leader in alternative methodology in each of these areas to address meetings of researchers in Australia. This type of discussion on the development of alternative methods is designed to assist in minimising the numbers of animals used in experiments in the future.

(7)(b) The NHMRC's Animal Welfare Committee is committed to minimising the numbers of animals used in experimentation, and replacement of the use of living animals by alternative methods wherever possible.
(8) The NHMRC does not collect data on this topic. Projects are not identified specifically on the basis of whether they are using recognised alternatives to testing on animals.
(9) Attached is a list of the present recipients of NHMRC funding for research which includes animal testing (Attachment 2).
(12) The use of primates and other animals in research is supported only because, to date, there are no credible and proven alternatives which can provide answers to key medical questions.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Social Security, upon notice, on 5 June 1995:

PARA.TAB: With reference to concerns that have been raised about the operation of the Commonwealth-State protocols in relation to young people seeking the Young Homeless Allowance (YHA) from the department:
(1) In each State, how many young people have been referred from the department to the relevant State authorities since the protocols came into operation.
(2) How many young people have subsequently been paid the YHA.
(3) Has a national instruction been issued within the department to the effect that young people cannot be paid the YHA while they are being assessed by the relevant State authority.

(4) Has the Minister been informed of cases in which State authorities have failed to provide support for a young person during the assessment period; if so, what investigations has the Minister made of such occurrences, and what has been the result of such investigations.

(5) Has the Minister been informed of cases in which State authorities have failed to complete an assessment within the defined period; if so, what investigations has the Minister made of such occurrences, and what has been the result of such investigations.

(6) Has the Minister been informed of cases in which State authorities have refused to investigate a young person's claim; if so, what investigations has the Minister made of such occurrences, and what has been the result of such investigations.
(7) How many cases of State authorities failing to commence income support immediately for a young person referred by the department have resulted in special benefit being paid.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Crowley Sen The Hon R.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Social Security has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) Three groups of homeless or unsupported young people are referred to State/Territory authorities when they seek income support from DSS: all those under 15 years, those who are in the legal care of the State/Territory, and 15-17 year olds who are at imminent risk. The following numbers of young people in each target group were referred between October 1994 (January 1995 in Tasmania) and the end of March 1995:

ANSWER.PARA: State/Territory Under 15 years In legal care At risk Total

PARA.TAB: (2) Forty-eight under 15 year olds have been paid special benefit at the homeless rate following completion of an assessment by a State or Territory agency. Payment of DSS income support to those aged 15 and over is not related to the outcome of an assessment by the State or Territory but depends upon the young person meeting standard eligibility criteria.

(3) Departmental staff have been advised through a national instruction that as a general rule special benefit should not be granted to homeless under 15 year olds during the assessment period because State and Territory welfare departments have agreed that they will meet the young person's needs during that time. Staff have also been advised that, if it appears that the State/Territory department may not be meeting its obligations to provide support during this period, the matter should be taken up at a senior level with the State/Territory department.

(4) There have been a number of cases in which support has not been provided promptly during the assessment period. The approach set out in (3) has been followed by staff of my Department in order to resolve these difficulties.

(5) There have been cases where delays in completing assessments have occurred, especially where there was industrial action in State departments. Department of Social Security staff have been advised that claims for income support must be determined within a reasonable period and of steps to take to ensure that this occurs. The Department has also written to State/Territory Departments explaining the need for assessments to be completed within agreed time frames.

(6) There have been a small number of cases in which a State department has assigned very low priority to conducting an assessment, based on lack of perceived risk to the young person. My Department has usually pursued these cases with more senior staff in the State/Territory department. Where such action is unsuccessful, the claim for income support is determined without waiting for an assessment to be completed.

(7) State authorities are not obliged to pay income support immediately for a young person whom they are assessing. During the assessment period, State authorities are required to arrange appropriate accommodation and other support where necessary. Where State departments provide income support, the payment may be paid to a carer rather than going directly to the young person.
However, my answer to part (6) is also relevant to this question.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 6 June 1995:

PARA.TAB: With reference to the answer to question on notice 1992 (Senate Hansard 16 December 1994, page 2091) concerning arms sales to Indonesia and comments in the West Australian 23 March 1995 attributed to the Minister for Development Cooperation and Pacific Island Affairs (Mr Bilney) that the Government `always addresses human rights concerns before granting overseas aid':

(1) Does the Government address human rights concerns when assessing applications for arms sales export licences; if so, what is the assessment of the human rights record of the Indonesian armed forces.
(2) If the Government does not undertake such assessments, why not.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) and (2) As explained in the Defence publication Australian Controls on the Export of Defence and Related Goods—Guidelines for Exporters March 1994, the Government, on a case-by-case basis, considers a number of relevant factors in its appraisal of defence export proposals.

As noted in the Guidelines, one consideration that is taken into account in every case is human rights issues. Exports will not be permitted to governments that seriously violate their citizens' rights unless there is no reasonable risk that the goods might be used against their citizens in violation of their human rights.

We are generally aware of political and other developments including the human rights situation in other countries, including Indonesia, and these are taken into account when considering defence export proposals.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories, upon notice, on 5 June 1995:

PARA.TAB: With reference to Western Mining Corporation's (WMC) expansion plans at Roxby Downs, and in particular to the implications for the waste water from the mine:

(1) Has WMC, or any of its subsidiaries or associated companies, prepared an environmental impact study in relation to the new borefield which it is envisaged will provide the additional water; if so, what does it show.
(2) What suitable sub-surface connections lie between the proposed Borefield B and Big Spring.
(3) What is the expected effect on Big Spring arising from the added pressure of WMC's new water needs.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) Western Mining Corporation (WMC) produced an Environmental Impact Statement (EIS) for the Olympic Dam mine in 1982, which included some consideration of Borefield B. South Australian authorities foreshadowed the need for additional assessment when the location and need for Borefield B became clear.

In light of the proposed expansion of the mine, WMC is now proposing the development of Borefield B. The SA Government has required an environmental impact assessment process to evaluate the environmental impact of the development of Borefield B.

The guidelines for the assessment of Borefield B require the proponent to undertake field studies, laboratory work and modelling investigations to determine the nature and characteristics of springs, vascular and non vascular vegetation, vertebrate and invertebrate fauna, water chemistry, water flow and draw down.

(2) & (3) There are several springs in the area that have `big' in their name and it is not clear to which spring Senator Chamarette is referring. The SA assessment process described above will evaluate the effects of the proposed development of Borefield B on springs throughout the region.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 5 June 1995:

PARA.TAB: (1) Has the Minister's attention been drawn to a recently published book entitled `Mortgaging the Earth: The World Bank, Environmental Impoverishment'.

(2) Does the Minister agree with the views of the author Mr Bruce Rich that the World Bank and other similar agencies have fostered economic policies and funded specific projects which have resulted in widespread environmental damage in developing countries.
(3) What measures is the Government taking to voice concerns about such projects in the world community.
(4) What alternatives have been explored for assisting developing countries to protect the earth's environmental heritage.
(5) In what ways has the Australian overseas aid policy been devised to ensure that our aid dollars are not contributing to environmental destruction.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) I am aware of the book published by Mr Bruce Rich, the full title of which is `Mortgaging the Earth: The World Bank, Environmental Impoverishment and the Crisis of Development'. It was published in early 1994.

The literature on the policies and operations of the World Bank is extensive. My department has monitored the disagreements between Mr Rich and the Bank's External Affairs Department over the accuracy of the claims made in this literature.

(2) The Bank is self critical and acknowledges that due regard has not always been given to environmental sustainability, and that assessment of the environmental impact of projects has in some cases been inadequate. However, since 1987 the Bank has made substantial and far-reaching progress in integrating environmental concerns into the mainstream of its operations. The Bank now requires borrowing countries to prepare detailed Environmental Assessments for projects with significant environmental impacts; encourages and assists borrowers to prepare National Environmental Action Plans (NEAPs); and supports the development of regional environmental strategies and action plans. The Bank has also expanded its support for the international conventions on climate change, biodiversity, ozone depletion and desertification and is a key implementing agency of the Global Environment Facility and the Multilateral Fund for the Implementation of the Montreal Protocol. The portfolio of active environmental projects financed by the World Bank now stands at over $US10 billion.

(3) The Government voices its concerns about the environmental aspects of projects directly to the Bank through its Executive Director. Comments on Environmental Assessment Summaries for World Bank projects with significant environmental impacts are sought from the Environment Protection Agency and from non-government organisations through the Australian Council for Overseas Aid. Comments received are passed to Australia's Executive Director at the Bank who raises issues of concern with the Bank.

The transparency and accountability of all aspects of Bank operations has increased substantially as a result of decisions by the Bank's Board to adopt a new information disclosure policy and to establish an independent Inspection Panel to investigate complaints from affected groups who believe they have been adversely affected by a failure on the part of the Bank to act in accordance with its own policies and procedures—including those relating to environment and resettlement. Australia strongly supported the establishment of the Inspection Panel, the first such body in any multilateral organisation, and has also supported a proposal for the Asian Development Bank to establish a similar panel.

(4) Australia places great importance on the growing and urgent environmental needs in developing countries, particularly in Asia. This is reflected in the increase in AusAID funding for environmental activities from an estimated $120 million in 1992 to over $160 million in 1994. Such activities include promoting cleaner energy, strengthening environment agencies in developing countries, monitoring global climate change, assisting with national park management, protecting endangered species, improving agricultural practices, encouraging sustainable forest practices, protecting coral reefs, improving urban planning, supporting pollution control and cleaner production activities, and supply of water and sanitation facilities.

(5) Australia's overseas aid policy explicitly addresses environmental issues. Ecologically sustainable development is the development philosophy which underpins Australia's aid program. The policies and processes for achieving this are set out in the 30 page publication launched in 1994 by the Minister for Development Cooperation and Pacific Island Affairs titled `Towards a Sustainable Future: Ecologically Sustainable Development through Australia's Development Cooperation Program' (copies of which are available from the Public Affairs Section of AusAID).

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs, upon notice, on 9 June 1995:

PARA.TAB: (1) Does letter GNL.5/61/1 of 9 January 1957 from the Official Secretary of the Office of the United High Commissioner occur in Australian Archive series A446/182 item 60/66767.

(2) Does that letter refer to Annex B to a letter written to voluntary child migration organisations after a meeting with representatives of those organisations by the United Kingdom Parliamentary Under Secretary of State for Commonwealth Relations on 14 December 1956.
(3) Did Annex B require voluntary organisations to provide information under various heads about their arrangements for the reception and care of emigrant children in Australia.
(4) Does information about St Joseph's Farm and Trade School in Bindoon, Western Australia, appear in that file.
(5) Can a copy of letter GNL.5/61/1 and any description of St Joseph's Farm and Trade School provided under Annex B heads be provided.

(6) Does an inspection report on St Joseph's Farm and Trade School signed on 21 September 1948 by F Mather occur in the general correspondence file accession number PP6/1 item 1949/H/ 1168 of the federal Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs, Western Australian branch.
(7) Does that report note that boys attaining the age of 14 years were leaving school rooms and doing manual work on the school site.

(8) Does that report describe 3 classes of boys at Bindoon, some of whom did work after school hours and some of whom worked during the day with evening classes and weekend classes said to be of the nature of trade-training.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 13 June 1995:

PARA.TAB: (1) Did AESOP in fact present details of its proposed programs at budget consultations for funding in the 1992-93, 1993-94, 1994-95 and 1995-96 financial years as required under the grant agreement.
(2) What were: (a) the date(s) of the budget consultations; (b) the place(s) of the budget consultations; and (c) the names of those who participated in the consultations.
(3) Can copies of any documentation showing details of AESOP's proposed expenditure and programs tabled during budget consultations be provided.

(4) Was the 1994-95 financial year grant to AESOP of $1.589 million based on a one page letter from AESOP which advised AusAID of the `level of funding AESOP would be able to absorb'in the 1994-95 financial year.
(5) Does the Minister accept that this one page letter constituted sufficient details for the expenditure of public funds on overseas aid projects.

(6) Will an undertaking be given to review the basis on which funding has been provided to AESOP given the absence of detailed budget proposals or consultations between AESOP and AusAID; if not, why not.
(7) Will the Minister confirm that the BDO audit report into the Kane allegations did not canvass or state its own view of the ratio of direct and administrative costs within AESOP.

(8) (a) What objective criteria are available to the Minister and AusAID to judge whether grantee bodies such as AESOP spend an appropriate ratio of funds on program and administrative expenses; (b) if these criteria are available, have they applied to expenditure by AESOP; and (c) if such criteria are not available, on what basis does the Minister state that the Kane allegations about AESOP expenditure were `based on an overly narrow definition of direct costs',

(9) (a) What is the remuneration package for the position of Director General of AusAID; (b) what are the responsibilities of the position; and (c) how many staff and resources does the Director General manage.

(10) Does the Minister consider a remuneration package of approximately $135,000 for the position of managing director of an Organisation with 9 staff and a budget allocation of around $1.5 million is reasonable; if not, why not.

(11) Is the Minister aware that overseas aid funds are being used by AESOP to place volunteers with private sector businesses which could afford to engage staff and consultants from their own resources.

(12) (a) What criteria did AESOP use to approve 29 applications for Ramu Sugar, Papua New Guinea, a company with 1,000 employees and annual sales of K24,000,000; and (b) does the Minister consider this an appropriate use of funds allocated for overseas aid.

(13) On what basis have applications for volunteer assistance been approved for the following private sector businesses: (a) Club Andaman Resort Hotel, Phuket, Thailand; (b) Diamond Cliff Resort Hotel, Phuket, Thailand; and (c) Edgewater Resort Hotel, Cook Islands.

(14) (a) Is the Minister aware that overseas aid funds were used by AESOP to supply a volunteer to landscape a new car park for a private company with extensive interests in the commercial and business districts of Majuro in the Marshall Islands; and (b) does the Minister accept that this is a legitimate use of overseas aid funds.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's questions is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) AESOP did not present details of its proposed programs at budget consultations for funding in the 1992-93, 1993-94 and 1994-95 financial years. Information on each year's budget was included in the papers for the Board of Director's meetings in August of each year at which AusAID participated in discussions. Budget papers have been submitted for 1995-96.

(2) Meetings at which budget figures were discussed were held: for 1992-93, 16 April 1992 at AusAID between Dr Bob Dun, Director General, AusAID and Mr Rod Cheatley, Managing Director AESOP; for 1993-94, 3 June 1993 at AusAID between Mr Ken Aspinall, Assistant Director General, Community Commercial and Refugee Programs, Mr Kerry Keneally, Director, NGO Programs and Liaison, and Mr Ray Riches, Program Officer, AusAID and Mr Cheatley; and for 1993-94, 10 March 1994 at AusAID between Mr Tim Terrell, Deputy Director General, Asia Africa and Community Programs, AusAID and Mr Cheatley. On 5 June 1995, a meeting at AusAID between Mr Colin Lonergan, Acting Deputy Director General, Asia Affica and Community Programs, Mr Angus Macdonald, Acting Assistant Director General, South Asia Africa and Humanitarian Relief, and Mr Salale Salale, Acting Director, NGO Programs and Liaison, AusAID and Mr Malcolm Overland, Deputy Chairman and Mr James Leedman, Director, AESOP discussed audit findings from BDO's report and possible funding levels for 1995-96.
(3) The papers presented to the Board of Director's meetings in August of each year were included in the 230 pages of documents supplied in answer to Senator Newman's question on notice number 2074.

(4) The 1994-95 financial year grant to AESOP was based on the March 1994 meeting between Mr Terrell and Mr Cheatley, the letter from AESOP, budget information presented in the papers for the Board of Director's meeting of 22 August 1994, and the AESOP 1993-94 Annual Report.
(5) As indicated in my response to Part 4, the letter received from AESOP was not the sole basis on which the budget allocation was reached.

(6) AusAID is reviewing the contract and the administrative processes with a view to improving their efficiency. In addition, the effectiveness of the four volunteer agencies funded by AusAID, including AESOP, is being reviewed as part of a current Volunteer Programs Effectiveness Review by AusAID.

(7) During the audit, BDO explored the issue of the ratio of direct and administrative costs within AESOP, but did not reach any conclusion about appropriate ratios in its audit report. This is a complex issue which is being considered by Mr Bilney's Code of Practice Advisory Committee.

(8) (a) There appears to be no standard criteria to judge whether grantee bodies such as AESOP spend an appropriate ratio of funds on program and administrative expenses. The bottom line for assessing cost-effectiveness would appear to be the cost per placement and the ratio of employees to placements. Based on figures provided by AESOP, obtained at a recent international meeting in Paris of similar agencies, the unit cost for per placement for AESOP is USD4,128, for the British agency USD4,242, the Germans USD6,495 and the Canadians USD9,458. AESOP has 19.8 placements for every employee, the British 17, the Canadians 13 and the Germans 9. AusAID is not presently in a position to validate these figures, but its Volunteer Programs Effectiveness Review will attempt to provide an objective basis to compare agency performance. (b) As stated in response to Parts 7 and 9(a), there is no standard definition of an appropriate ratio of funds for program and administrative expenses. The issue is being considered by the Code of Practice Advisory Committee. (c) The statement referred to in the question is a paraphrase from the BDO Audit Report, which states "Kane's definition of direct costs is too narrow" (p. 30).

(9) (a) Up to $140,000. (b) Provide advice to the Ministers and the Secretary on all matters concerning the overseas development cooperation program, be responsible for the management of AusAID including forward planning, undertake high level representation in Australia and overseas and liaise and negotiate with the heads of other departments as well as industry, academic and community leaders and organisations. (c) 586 fulltime equivalent staff and approximately $1.5 billion a year.

(10) Determination of an appropriate remuneration package for the Managing Director of AESOP is a matter for the Board of Directors, however the package does appear to be high. The BDO report recommended that the Managing Director's remun eration level be reviewed by the AESOP Board of Directors, which has commissioned Coopers and Lybrand to review the salaries of senior staff and indicated that it will act upon the recommendations. The Coopers and Lybrand review is not yet available to AusAID.

(11) Use of overseas aid funds to place volunteers with private sector businesses is appropriate if it leads to developmentally beneficial outcomes, as required under AESOP's project approval guidelines. The guidelines are: projects must aim to strengthen the effectiveness of indigenous businesses and organisations, projects must contain a strong training element, assistance will not be provided where professional consultants should be engaged on a commercial basis, priority is given to projects which will benefit the greatest number of individuals in the recipient country, where possible and appropriate projects should endeavour to advance mutually beneficial business and commercial links between Australia and developing countries, and projects from all recipient countries receive equal priority.

(12) (a) Since 1994, AESOP has approved 31 project proposals submitted by Ramu Sugar on the basis of the above guidelines. Of these, 26 have been implemented, three are on hold, a volunteer is being sought for another and one has been withdrawn. Ramu Sugar is a Papua New Guinea company whose principal shareholders are the Independent State of Papua New Guinea (59.3%) and the Commonwealth Development Corporation, a non-profit investment Organisation originally financed by the Government of the United Kingdom as a vehicle for development (I8.4%). In the early years of the company's existence, disease and crop failure meant that loans had to be rescheduled, and resources diverted from training. AESOP was approached to assist in providing training where commercial consultants could not be used. A large labour force has meant that many Papua New Guineans have benefited from the training provided by AESOP. Mutually beneficial trade and commercial links have been advanced as a result of AESOP projects, for example, European harvesting equipment has been replaced by Australian. (b) This appears an appropriate use of funds allocated for overseas aid.

(13) AESOP advises that the same criteria were used to approve the projects listed in the question. In Thailand, the principal activity has been the teaching of English as a second language to hotel employees, which has improved their ability to perform their duties. In the Cook Islands, development of tourist infrastructure and training the workforce to support that infrastructure are among the Cook Islands' Govemment's key objectives. All projects at the Edgewater Resort Hotel have had a strong training element.

(14) (a) AESOP advises that the following project summary, prepared by then AESOP Project Manager, Mr V J Kane, indicated the benefits of the Marshall Islands project: `The client is seeking an experienced landscaper, familiar with tropical climates who can advise staff how to design appropriate landscaping for newly reclaimed land, and around newly constructed facilities. The client has a team of landscapers for this purpose, but their lack of knowledge and experience limits them in what they can do. These people desperately need training, so that they can apply their gained knowledge both presently and in the future. The client is continually expanding, and new buildings are constructed regularly. Without proper landscaping however, these buildings become eyesores which detract from the natural beauty of these islands'.
(b) Maintaining environmental quality appears a legitimate use of overseas aid funds.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 13 June 1995:

PARA.TAB: With reference to recent reports that Australia will collaborate in anti-ballistic missile research with the United States (US) in what is known as the Strategic Defence Initiative (SDI):

(1)(a) Has there been any contract, exchange of letters or agreement signed between Australia and the US to formalise this agreement; if so, what is in this agreement, statement, contract or exchange of letters; and can a copy be provided;

(b) if the agreement is yet to be signed or formalised, when will this be done and which people and agencies will be involved; and (c) is the agreement between Defence Science and Technology Organisation (DSTO) and the US Ballistic Missile Defence Organisation; if not, then who is the agreement between.

(2)(a) How will Australia be helping the US with the SDI; (b) given that reports show that our part in the project is researching computer technologies, is this correct and what aspects of computer technology will we be researching.

(3)(a) What are the benefits to Australia; (b) what are the benefits to the US; (c) which statutory authorities, Government agencies and sections of Government departments in Australia will be participating in some way with research into the SDI; (d) how will each contribute to researching this computer technology; (e) what financial resources will each commit to which budget programs and over what time period; and (f) what is the general time frame of the project.

(4)(a) In what specific technological areas will Australia be lending expertise to the SDI project; (b) will Australia be sending any experts over the US to participate or lend expertise in the project; (c) what is their expertise and from which departments, statutory authorities or Government agencies do they come; (d) how many are there; (e) similarly, will any US experts be coming here to participate in our related projects; if so, how many; and (f) what are their areas of expertise.

(5)(a) Will the Australian Government be signing any contract, exchange of letters or any other kind of agreement with any companies (Australian or foreign) to do with the SDI project or any project related to the SDI; (b) what is the expected financial value of the contract or agreement; (c) what will the company be providing the Australian Government with; (d) what technological advantages can any of these companies provide which the Australian Government cannot; (e) which companies are they; (f) will any of these companies be able to have access to the Government's 150 per cent tax concession on research and development; (g) are there any contracts or agreements already signed; (h) if they are not yet signed, are there any negotiations expected in the future which may lead to the signing of any such agreement; and (i) which companies and what sorts of agreement.

(6) Is it possible for any Australian company which will be involved either directly in the SDI project or in related projects to be able to have access to the 150 per cent research and development tax concession for this project.

(7) Does the Government know which Australian companies, whether independent from the Government or in some joint agreement with the Government, will be involved in the SDI project; (a) what are the companies; (b) how many are there; and (c) how much are they investing.

(8) Will any Australian companies be sending any experts over to the US to participate or lend any expertise in the project; (a) what is their expertise and which companies are they from; (b) what is the particular technological competence of these Australian companies; and (c) how many experts are they sending.

(9) Similarly, will any US companies be sending experts to Australia to participate in our related projects; (a) how many; (b) what are their areas of expertise; and (c) what is the particular technological competence of these US companies.
(10)(a) What technological development of the SDI is each company (Australian or US) to lend its expertise to; and (b) how much will each of these companies invest in this project.

(11)(a) What is the time frame for Australia's involvement in this project; (b) is Australia expected to be involved in the project until completion or for a fixed time; and (c) what is the level of time commitment.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: Regarding the many references in the question to the US Strategic Defense Initiative (SDI), it is important to note that in May 1993 the US Secretary of Defense announced that the Strategic Defense Initiative Organisation had been renamed the Ballistic Missile Defense Organisation (BMDO). In addition, the Strategic Defense Initiative was renamed the Ballistic Missile Defense Program. This change was made to reflect the basic shift in the ballistic missile defence program in the United States away from defences against a massive strategic nuclear missile attack on the US by the former Soviet Union and toward the threat posed by shorter range, or theatre ballistic missiles, including missiles of the kind used by Iraq in the Gulf War.

(1)(a) Yes. The Chief Defence Scientist (CDS) and the Director of the US BMDO exchanged letters in April and May 1995 establishing a broad framework for cooperation between the Defence Science and Technology Organisation (DSTO) and the Ballistic Missile Defense Organisation (BMDO). Copies of the letters have been forwarded to Senator Margetts.

The letters acknowledge that cooperation between DSTO and BMDO will be aimed at the common objectives of preventing the proliferation of weapons of mass destruction and affording protection from missile attack. Exploratory discussions to identify cooperative projects that would meet these objectives were foreshadowed in the March 1994 Australia-United States Ministerial Talks (AUSMIN) communique. The subsequent exchange of letters is the outcome referred to in the communique issued after AUSMIN in April 1995, which noted that an initial program of cooperative activities was expected to begin this year.

The letter from CDS notes that Australia's contribution will be focused on activities that also support Australia's national defence needs and priorities, and which are consistent with the Government's support for a stable and effective nuclear deterrent as well as its position on the 1972 Anti-Ballistic Missile (ABM) Treaty and the deployment of weapons in space. The letters establish that cooperation will focus on a modest initial program of activities that might include some or all of the following:
a cooperative research project designed to take advantage of some civilian rocket launches planned at Woomera in late 1995;
an exchange of data and results from previous research of mutual interest;
personnel exchanges, initially involving the placement of a DSTO scientist with the BMDO in the US; and possibly

a demonstration exercise with the US Navy to familiarise the Australian Defence Force (ADF) with the BMDO's cooperative engagement concept relating to the detection, tracking and targeting of a theatre missile attack.
(1)(b)-(c) See response to 1(a).

(2)(a) DSTO and BMDO will be engaged in a modest program of cooperative activities that reflects common Australian and US interests in preventing the proliferation of weapons of mass destruction and affording protection from missile attack, involving a range of activities described in the answer to part (1).

(b) The cooperative activities between DSTO and the BMDO will involve a range of technologies having application to ballistic missile defences and also to Australian defence interests and priorities, such as advanced sensor, tracking and communications technologies. Computers are basic to all these capabilities but cooperation in computer technology per se is not an objective under the cooperative program.

The cooperative project at Woomera later this year will involve advanced sensor, tracking and communications technologies. The project will help develop concepts for real-time tracking of targets and widespread dissemination of information to distributed command and control centres.

(3)(a) Cooperation with the BMDO will contribute to DSTO efforts in developing familiarity with space systems and research, and in key technology areas relevant to the ADF such as command, control and communications; information technologies; and surveillance technologies. Defending Australia highlights the importance for the ADF of technologies in these areas in the next 15 years. They relate to ADF interests in areas such as advanced defences for its combat forces, and command, control and surveillance capabilities. Cooperation will also allow Australia, as a US ally, to share with the BMDO expertise developed to meet Australian needs, thus advancing our common interests in strengthening global security, including cooperation in defence against ballistic missiles. The ADF has no current interest in the acquisition of ballistic missile defence systems.

(b) The US view on the benefits of cooperative research into anti-ballistic missile defences is reflected in the 1995 Annual Report of the US Secretary of Defense, which says that cooperation in theatre missile defence will help strengthen security relationships with allies, enhance the counter proliferation strategy of discouraging acquisition and use of ballistic missiles and, should that fail, protect against the threats posed by such systems.
(3)(c)-(f) There are no current plans to involve agencies outside the Department of Defence in the cooperative research program with the BMDO.

Cooperation between DSTO and BMDO will be modest and is in its early stages, with only one cooperative research activity in the planning stage (as identified in the answer to part (1)). The activities so far identified are expected to be largely completed by late 1996 at a cost to DSTO of less than $0.5 million.

(4)(a) The DSTO contribution to cooperative research with the BMDO will be based on, and reinforce, expertise developed by DSTO in support of Australian Defence programs. The research is expected to have applications to a wide range of priority projects for the Australian Defence Force, in areas such as information processing, surveillance technologies, and command, control and communications systems.

(4)(b)-(f) The framework arrangements provide for DSTO and BMDO to exchange personnel. Initially a DSTO scientist will be attached for one year to the Applied Physics Laboratory of Johns Hopkins University to work on data fusion from electro-optical sensors. This will be implemented through the longstanding Scientist and Engineer Exchange Program between the Australian Department of Defence and the US Defense Department. A US Government scientist from Naval Research and Development (NRaD), San Diego, will participate in the Woomera trial. His area of expertise is in satellite communications, an area where DSTO and NRaD have collaborated for many years.

From time to time Australian and US defence scientists and officials will also visit each other to plan, implement and review cooperative projects. The areas of expertise and numbers of personnel involved will be determined by the needs of the cooperative project under discussion.

(5)-(10) DSTO currently has no plans to involve Australian or US companies in cooperative activities. Opportunities may emerge in future, depending on how the cooperative program evolves, but at this early stage any further comment would be speculative.

If an Australian company became involved in ballistic missile defence research and development, its eligibility for research and development tax concessions would be determined by the Tax Concession Committee of the Industry Research and Development Board, in accordance with section 73 B of the Income Tax Assessment Act and section 39 of the Industry Research and Development Act. The company may of course be eligible for such concessions on the basis of its other activities.

The BMDO engages research institutions as well as private contractors in its research and development activities, and it is possible that future cooperative activities between DSTO and BMDO may involve such institutions and contractors. The BMDO has engaged the Nichols Research Corporation (NRC) to provide an opto-electrical tracking mount and track fusion algorithms for the Woomera trial. Up to four NRC technicians will be at Woomera to operate this equipment during the trial. All equipment and personnel will return to the US after the trial.
(11) See response to (3)(c)-(f).

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Employment, Education and Training, upon notice, on 20 June 1995:

(6) How many editions have been prepared.
(7) What is the average cost per edition.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Employment, Education and Training has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) The total cost of `The Young and Jobless' comic series (3 comics) to DEET was $215,650 including authoring, printing, distribution and evaluation.

(2) The purpose of these three comics is to motivate long term unemployed young people to participate in training and vocational courses and to give them information to help them get a job. The comics provide text and visuals which describe the support framework available through DEET and other government agencies using specific examples. They promote the Department's services and initiatives to help unemployed young people in a format and style which they find helpful.

(3) The comics are distributed by Streetwize in bulk to 300 DEET outlets (Youth Access Centres and CES Centres) and by mailout to 1200 other employment-related services such as Skillshares, TAFE employment programs and to youth workers in community agencies. The third comic in the series will be distributed in early July.
(4) Distribution costs of $24,500 are included in the contract.

(5) A formal evaluation of the series will be undertaken as part of the contract. This evaluation will begin after distribution of the third comic. The evaluation will be completed at the end of 1995. Positive written feedback has been received from youth workers in the Vietnamese community on the comic that depicted issues for young unemployed Vietnamese people.
(6) 180,000 copies of comics have been printed (60,000 for each of the three titles).
(7) The average cost per copy, based on the total cost of the contract, is $1.20.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Housing and Regional Development, upon notice, on 20 June 1995:

PARA.TAB: (1) What is the total cost of monitoring the `Synemon plana' moth at York Park, Barton, Australian Capital Territory.
(2) What is the total cost of preparing draft management guidelines for the `Synemon plana' moth at York Park.
(3) In what other areas has this moth been located.
(4) What changes have had to be made to departmental plans due to this moth.
(5) Why is it necessary to monitor and prepare draft management guidelines for the `Synemon plana' moth at York Park.
(6) (a) What is the total cost of maintaining grass at the moth site at York Park; and, (b) why is it necessary.
(7) What other costs have been involved with the moth site at York Park.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Housing and Regional Development has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) From 1992/93 to 1994/95 monitoring costs totalled $14,650.

(3) The current known distribution is a series of sites in the ACT, Jerrabomberra (NSW) and a few sites in Victoria. Distribution is critically linked to the presence of remnants of native grassland containing a high density of species of Danthonia (Wallaby Grass). The other main ACT sites are Belconnen Naval Base, Majura Army Firing Range, near `Woden' Homestead (Jerrabomberra Valley), and three areas in Gungahlin.

(4) None to date. To exclude negative impact on the moth site, the National Capital Planning Authority will place development conditions on the site adjacent to control such design factors as shading, drainage and access in respect of future development proposals for the area.
(5) Draft management guidelines are necessary to manage the high quality native grassland found on the site which is critical to the existence and well being of `Synemon plana'.
`Synemon plana' is a member of an ancient family, their lineage being able to be traced back over 100 million years. They are of considerable scientific interest.
It is anticipated that in 1995 `Synemon plana' will be considered for listing under both the Commonwealth's Endangered Species Act 1992 and the ACT's Nature Conservation Act 1980.

The York Park site is small (1/3 hectare) but very high quality native grassland. It is one of the largest suburban sites and probably has the largest moth population of any known sites. The site has been monitored for three consecutive years and the population has shown no decline in that period.

(6) (a) Maintenance cost in 1994-5—$12,532; (this includes costs for native grass re-establishment on former highly weed invaded areas near Sydney Avenue construction and tree stump removal and replanting totalling $9,532)
Estimated maintenance cost 1995-6—$2,500.

(b) Maintenance of the high quality native grassland on the moth site is the key to maintaining the moth population. Basic maintenance (common to all urban grassland sites) includes mowing and weed control. Given the substantial moth population on this site, special attention has been given to controlling weed invasion and increasing the area of native grasses.
(7) Grassland monitoring (the site is one of 14 scientific reference sites for intensive native grassland monitoring in the ACT)
TOTAL—$4,628
The Sydney Avenue road batter works necessitated some land regrading and translocation of native grass to the periphery of the moth site plus follow-up maintenance.
