TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Transport, upon notice, on 20 June 1995:

PARA.TAB: (1) Why has there been a failure to implement the National Bicycle Strategy.
(2) Does the Minister realise that the lack of support and clear direction is hampering the integration of strategies between the States.
(3) Does the Minister concede that national guidelines and standards should be put in place immediately so that a situation such as the ad hoc national rail gauge fiasco is avoided in future.

(4) Does the Minister concede that significant environmental, health and economics would flow from promoting cycling, and that failure to realise these benefits affects the Government's own environmental and greenhouse policies.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Transport has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1)-(3) The Commonwealth initiated and actively participated in the development and implementation of the National Bicycle Strategy (NBS), which was endorsed by the then Australian Transport Advisory Council in October 1992. While the Commonwealth facilitated the NBS process, it was clearly recognised that the main responsibility for the implementation of the NBS rests with the State, Territory and Local Governments which actually deliver initiatives under the Strategy. This position was acknowledged by State and Territory Transport Ministers at the Australian Transport Council meeting in October 1994.

Following the endorsement of the Strategy, the Federal Government provided almost $4 million for bicycle facility demonstration projects in capital cities and some provincial centres around Australia, and allocated an additional $29 million for bicycle path projects from the Local Capital Works Program which was funded by the former Department of Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs. The Commonwealth Government also provided $50,000 towards the cost of developing a national information and data base.
(4) Clearly there are environmental, health and economic benefits from increased cycling. These are being realised from the State and Territory implementation of the NBS.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Social Security, upon notice, on 27 June 1995:

PARA.TAB: (1) Does the Department allow electoral roll enrolment to be presented by a claimant as proof of identity when making a claim; if so, for what payments is electoral roll enrolment used as proof of identity.
(2) Does the Department use electoral roll enrolment as a subsequent check when pursuing claims or investigating potential fraud.
(3) If the Department does not use electoral roll enrolment as proof of identity now, has it ever; if it did, when did it stop using the electoral roll.
(4) What was the Department's reason for deciding not to continue using the electoral roll as proof of identity.
(5) If the Department becomes aware of potentially fraudulent enrolments, is the Australian Electoral Commission notified as a matter of course.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Social Security has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) The Department does not accept electoral roll enrolment as standard proof of identity (POI). It may be used as supporting evidence.
(2) The Department does utilise electoral enrolment information to assist in the detection and investigation of fraud.

(3) Electoral roll enrolment by itself has never been acceptable POI. Up until 13 March 1995 letters from government departments, including the Electoral Commission, were an acceptable component in proving identity if the claimant's address was shown.
(4) See answer to Question (1).

(5) On some occasions the Department has notified the Australian Electoral Commission directly of fraudulent enrolments. However, most cases of this nature entail identity related fraud and are referred to the Australian Federal Police for investigation because of their complexity and the potential for other Commonwealth offences having been committed.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Housing and Regional Development, upon notice, on 28 June 1995:

PARA.TAB: (1) What amounts were spent in relation to comics for the Job Placement Employment and Training program, and for what purpose were these amounts spent.
(2) Can copies of the comics be provided.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Housing and Regional Development has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) In April 1994 Streetwize Comics were commissioned to produce a comic story to inform young homeless people about the JPET program, and how it can help them access employment and training. The story line of Hanging In focuses on the issues surrounding unemployment and homelessness, providing the information in an appropriate and accessible format. It raises awareness of the issues a young person at risk of homelessness encounters when attempting to enter the workforce.

The comic was designed in consultation with young homeless people, and workers in health, welfare and community organisations. It is based on the real life experiences of young homeless people and directed at those with poor literacy skills.

Reaction to the comic has been favourable. Streetwize Comics are able to reach young people effectively, particularly those with communication problems who do not readily access conventional sources of information.
A total of $63,700 was paid to Streetwize Comics which comprised:
$29,200 for the development, design and production of an 8 page colour comic;
$27,000 for the printing and distribution of 90,000 copies of the comic; and
$7,500 for the development, design and printing of 2,500 sets of Workshop Notes to accompany the comic (to assist those working with young people).
(2) A copy of the comic and workshop notes have been forwarded under separate cover.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, upon notice, on 6 July 1995:

PARA.TAB: (1) Is it a fact that Energy Resources of Australia (ERA), in 1990, had a contract with the French Government-owned nuclear fuel cycle firm Cogema, for 125 tonnes per year of uranium; (b) is it also a fact that ERA had, in the same year, contracts with Saarberg Interuran and Urangesselschaft, both largely owned by Cogema, for 250 tonnes per year and 100 tonnes per year respectively; and (c) can details be provided: (i) of the present status of those contracts, (ii) when they date from, and (iii) whether or not they were entered into contrary to Government policy.

(2) Is it a fact that ERA now has contracts with Cogema or Electricity D'France (EDF) for 300 tonnes per year; (b) is the Minister cognisant of the difference between the two bodies; and (c) can the Minister state exactly with which body the 300 tonnes per year contract is placed.

(3) Can confirmation be given that Cogema is a major processor for uranium for other customers outside France; (b) can details be provided of how much of Australia's uranium is converted, enriched or fabricated in France for ultimate use by non-French customers.

(4) (a) Is it a fact that, in June 1988, the then Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Kerin) said in relation to the plant in which Australian-uranium is enriched for use in France, that the `Australian Safeguards Office has advised that the plant, in producing low-enriched uranium, does process other obligated nuclear material, which remains in civil use, and non-obligated material, which can after further enrichment, be used for military purposes'; (b) has this situation changed in the past 7 years; if so, how; if not, will the Government concede that current sales of uranium to France contravene Government policy and contribute, however indirectly, to French military activities; and (c) will the Government give serious consideration to the possibility of legislation to render French contracts with ERA null and void.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's questions is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) (a) No Australian obligated nuclear material (AONM) has been directly sold to Cogema; (b) details of uranium contracts submitted to the Government for approval are commercial in confidence. However, in its 1990 annual report, Energy Resources of Australia Ltd (ERA) stated that Interuran, formerly known as Saarberg-Interplan Uran, and Urangesellschaft (which did not become majority owned by Cogema until 1992) were two German customers of the company at this time; and (c) (i) (ii) for commercial in confidence reasons, the present status of Australian uranium contracts cannot be disclosed; and (iii) no contract for the sale and export of Australian uranium has been entered into contrary to Government policy.

(2) (a) As noted in the answer to (1) (a) above, no AONM has been directly sold to Cogema. Further, ERA has confirmed that it supplies 300 short tons (272 tonnes) of uranium per year under a long term contract with Electricite de France (EDF) that was executed, and accepted by the Government, prior to the imposition in February 1988 of the present ban on any further contracts, or extension or acceptance of any options which existed in current contracts; (b) yes; and (c) EDF.

(3) (a) Yes; (b) no. The precise details of how much AONM converted, enriched or fabricated on behalf of specific customers are confidential. However, as an indicative figure, the amount of AONM transferred to France for conversion, enrichment or fuel fabrication on behalf of non-French end-users equates to some three times the level of AONM sold to EDF.

(4) (a) Yes, in a media release of 2 June 1988 in relation to the Eurodif enrichment plant at Tricastin; (b) We are unaware of any change in the situation in the past 7 years. It remains the case, as Mr Kerin also said in his media release of 2 June 1988, that `The Australian obligated nuclear material which passes through the facility at Tricastin, however, remains confined to exclusively peaceful non-explosive use, that is there is a quantity of low-enriched uranium and depleted tails, equivalent to the Australian obligated nuclear material and which may only be used for peaceful, non-explosive purposes.' Accordingly, current sales of Australian uranium to France, which constitute less than 3% of EDF's requirements, neither contravene Government policy nor contribute in any way to French military activities; and (c) No. Any ban on the small volume of existing Australian supplies would only benefit France as EDF could readily substitute these supplies with much cheaper uranium from other suppliers, including some whose safeguards arrangements

ANSWER.PARA: may be less stringent than those required by Australia.
